Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

At six different places arrangements have been in effect for some time whereby a grant is paid to a white school for the education of Indian children for whom no Indian day school is available.

These schools are as follows:

PROVINCE OF ONTARIO

Hiawatha - Rice and Mud Lake Indian Agency
Honey Harbour - Parry Sound Indian Agency
Mattawa - Mattawa, Ont.
Michipicoten Harbour - Sault Ste. Marie Indian Agency

PROVINCE OF MANITOBA

Moose Lake - The Pas Indian Agency

PROVINCE OF SASKATCHEWAN

Round Plain - Carlton Indian Agency

Provision was only made in our appropriation for our grant to these schools for a nine-month period during the academic year 1940-41. However, they will be open for a ten-month period to accommodate the white children attending and I consider that we should allow the Indian children also to attend for the ten-month period.

Aug 7
To do so would require an amount of $265.00 more than provided in the current year's appropriation for the six schools mentioned above. There are two other combined schools to which we have been making grants; namely, Whitefish River in the Manitoulin Island Indian Agency, and Jack River in the Norway House Indian Agency. The attendance at both these schools has decreased to such an extent that the authorities in charge of the Whitefish River School were advised that no further grant would be allowed to them after June 30, 1940, and in the case of the Jack River School our yearly grant of $650.00 is being reduced to $175.00 from September 1, 1940. As a result there will be an unexpected balance in the case of these two schools of $887.50.

You will, therefore, note that we can allow the Indian children enrolled at the other six combined white and Indian schools to attend for the full ten-month period without any increase in the total expenditure.

I should appreciate having the Minister's approval.

[Signature]

MEMORANDUM:

DEPUTY DIRECTOR

Each residential school forwards to this Branch a return at the end of each quarter. This return shows the number of pupils enrolled and the number of days during which the pupil was present in the quarter covered by the report. The per capita allowance is paid on the basis of attendance, provided this is not in excess of 92.35% of the authorized pupilage at the school.

There has been considerable illness among the pupils enrolled at Indian residential schools during the current year. For instance, pupil roll records show that there were breaks in the Prairie provinces about the latter part of August, 1941, and as a result, the Indians returned home instead of going back to school. Pupils should not return to Indian residential schools on September 1, as we have found that in many cases too many of the children did not get back to school until October or even November.

The above has resulted in a decrease in the average enrollment of our residential schools and therefore, the schools have not earned the per capita allowance which they are claiming here. It is estimated that at the present time there is approximately $80,000.00 left in the annual allotment for per capita allowances. The total allotment for per capita allowances to all Indian residential schools in 1941-42 was $175,000.00, so the maximum amount for which grant is paid would be $92.50.
Due to increased cost of many commodities and higher wages for staff members, the Churches engaged in Indian work have urged us to make a special grant this year. In view of the amount that remains in the per capita allowance allotment, I recommend that a special payment of $10.00 per capita be made on the average attendance at each school as shown by the quarterly returns. The maximum amount required in order to carry out this recommendation would be $79,450.00.

In making the above recommendation I suggest that the Churches concerned be informed that this payment must not be considered a precedent for future years.

Director.
February 27, 1948.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are 77 Indian residential schools in the Dominion of Canada;

THAT the Churches co-operating with the Department in the operation of these schools have directed our attention to the increased cost of many commodities and the higher wages now being paid to staff members;

THAT, as a result, the Indian residential schools have been obliged to incur extraordinary expenditures and consequently the Churches have appealed to the Department of Mines and Resources for a special grant in order to assist them to meet their obligations;

THAT, due to various causes, funds to an amount of $78,676.93 are available in the appropriation for the current fiscal year and that this amount would be sufficient to make a payment of $10.00 per pupil based on the average attendance as shown by the quarterly returns for the calendar year 1941.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that approval be given for the expenditure of a sum not in excess of $78,676.93 as a special grant at the rate of $10.00 a head on the pupilage at the Indian residential schools in the Dominion of Canada, same to be chargeable to Vote 165, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.
February 27, 1943.

Memorandum to:

Dr. H.W. McGill

The Governor in Council has now approved of the special payment of $10.00 per capita to the Indian Residential Schools, based on the recommendation enclosed with your memorandum of the 27th ultimo.

In submitting this recommendation to Council the Minister asked me to prepare a letter for the Secretary of Treasury Board. This was done and I am enclosing a copy. Ottawa, March 5, 1942

W.G. Ronson, Esq.,
Secretary, Treasury Board,
Department of Finance,
OTTAWA, Canada.

Dear Mr. Ronson,

The attached Recommendation to Council, which has been signed by the Minister, refers to the matter which I discussed with you a few days ago, and that is, the request made by a committee of all the churches operating residential schools that some additional allowance should be made to the churches in order to assist them in meeting their increased expenditures arising from the higher cost of food, supplies and wages. You will recall that the matter was discussed by Treasury Board when our estimates were up for consideration and it was suggested then that an item might be included to provide for this additional assistance. However, no action was taken at that time.

In the current year's estimates, Vote 168, $1,398,944.00 was provided for grants to residential schools. It would now appear that all of this sum will not be used owing to the fact that the attendance at the schools was materially reduced during the summer and fall by reason of the epidemics that were prevalent at that time, particularly in western Canada. It is expected that there will be approximately $90,000 remaining in this vote at the end of the year. It is therefore recommended that a special payment to the churches be made of $10.00 per capita, based on the average attendance at each school, as shown by the quarterly returns. The amount required to provide this grant would be $75,876.90.

In support of the request, the committee representing the churches has pointed out that the cost of maintaining the residential schools has increased very
materially since the beginning of the war and similar conditions existed in respect to the cost of food, household equipment, fuel and clothing.

In considering the request the Minister pointed out to the committee that if any additional assistance should be granted this year it would not in any way be considered a precedent and that there would be no obligation to grant similar assistance in other years. It was also made clear that if additional assistance were granted now it would only be because there were funds available in the estimates and that the Government could not, during the war, provide for additional funds for residential school training over and above the sums which have been provided during the past few years.

Yours very truly,

Chief Executive Assistant.

DEPARTMENT OF MINES & RESOURCES
INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH

Ottawa,
March 25, 1942.

Reverend Sir:

On the recommendation of the Minister an Order-in-Council was passed on March 16, 1942, authorizing payment of a special grant to the Indian residential schools for the calendar year 1941. This is being made on the same pupilage as per capita grant was allowed during the year 1941 and is at the rate of $10.00 per pupil.

The special grant being made for 1941 must not be considered as a precedent for future years, and the Department does not obligate itself to give similar consideration in other years. I therefore, urge the Principals of our residential schools to effect every reasonable economy in the operation of their schools in order that the financial resources may be conserved to the advantage of all parties concerned.

You are no doubt aware that at this date there is an acute shortage of certain commodities. We have in mind gasoline, rubber, steel, tin, etc., and we have no assurance that the list will not be greatly extended in the immediate future. In view of these shortages we are requesting Principals to do everything humanly possible to conserve these and other commodities essential to our war effort.

[Signature]
Director.

Dear Dr. McGill:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo, #1-1-3, and with it the copy of your circular letter of the same date addressed to Principals of the Indian Residential Schools, in connexion with the special $10.00 per capita grant for the year 1941. I have not yet had an opportunity of presenting your letter to our Commission, but I am confident the members would desire me to express their high appreciation of this financial help, coming as it does at a time when it is very greatly needed.

As I have learned from our General Secretary that he also received a copy of your circular letter to the Principals, I am assuming that he will write to you direct in the matter, and convey to you an expression of our Society's hearty thanks for your kind consideration of our needs. On behalf of our Commission, on whom rests the responsibility for the administration of the Church of England Schools, I can assure you that every possible effort is being made to keep them in operation at a minimum cost. The standards of efficiency, possible under normal conditions, cannot easily be maintained, but you may rest assured that we will do our utmost to "carry on" until happier days have come back again.

With very kind regards,

Faithfully yours,

Cranbrook, B.C.

Minister of Mines & Resources

Dear Sir:

May I personally thank you for the additional grant of $15.00 per pupil for the fiscal year just ended? This grant, I think, should be most appreciated by the smaller schools which, handicapped by a comparatively higher overhead, have been most hard hit.

Even in normal times, the Kootenay School appears to be financially hard to conduct. Eight or nine years ago, the Oblate Fathers paid off debts amounting to $1,000.00.

In the three years preceding March, 1941, when I arrived, a debt of over $5,000.00 had accumulated & there was a Bank balance of only $37.00 on hand. We are now on our feet again thanks to a contribution from the Oblate Fathers of about $700.00 in the last twelve months. Of this, $485.00 was in cash & the balance was made up of meat, vegetables, etc., supplied free of charge from the Oblate farm.

I mention that to indicate that we sincerely appreciate the extra grant just received.

I hope to remain

Yours sincerely,

G. Forbes O.M.I.

APOSTOLIC VICARIATE OF JAMES BAY

Moosonee, Ontario, April 8, 1942.

Hon. T.A. Crerar,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Honourable Minister,

We have heard that you had granted to our Indian boarding schools the sum of $10 per pupil for the year 1941-42.

In my name and that of the principals of our two boarding schools, I thank you sincerely for having made such a grant.

The boarding school of Albany, James Bay, was burned down in August, 1939; already partially rebuilt at the expense of the Apostolic Vicar and his missionaries, it has this year 48 pupils. On account of this reconstruction, the financial position of that house is far from being prosperous.

The boarding school of Fort George, also at James Bay, has almost 50 Indian pupils this year. The subsidy "per capita" of that school is for 20 pupils only (less 7.76%).

You may imagine how welcome will be the sum of $10 for each child that you grant this year. The personnel of our boarding schools makes every effort to give formation which is best suited in their condition. All encouragement and cooperation from the Government is very much appreciated.

Wishing you all success in your work so full of responsibility, I remain,

Honourable Sir,

Yours very truly,

Henri Belleau, O.M.I.

Apostolic vicar of James Bay.

MOOSONEE, ONT. — le 8 avril, 1942 —

A l'Honorable T.A. Crerar
Ministre des Mines et des Ressources
Ottawa

Monsieur le Ministre,

Nous avons appris que vous avez octroyé à nos pensionnats indiens, la somme de $10.00 par élève, pour l'année 1941-42.

En mon nom et au nom des principaux de nos deux écoles-pensionnats, je vous remercie bien sincèrement de cet octroi.

Le pensionnat d'Albany, à la Baie James, a été incendié en août, 1935; déjà partiellement rebâti aux frais du Vicaire Apostolique et de ses missionnaires, il garde, cette année, quarante-huit élèves. Du fait de la reconstruction, les finances de cette maison sont loin d'être prospères.

Le pensionnat de Fort George, aussi à la Baie Jam, reçoit près de 60 élèves indiens, cette année. Or, l'octroi "per Cap" à cette école, n'est que pour 20 élèves (moins 7.76 %).

C'est vous dire combien sera bienvenue la somme de $10.00 par enfant, que vous octroyez cette année. Le personnel de nos écoles-pensionnats s'efforce de donner aux enfants indiens la formation qui leur convient le mieux dans leur condition. Tout encouragement et toute coopération de la part du Gouvernement sont très bien appréciées.

Vous souhaitant un succès plein et entier dans votre travail si chargé de responsabilité, je demeure,

Monsieur le Ministre,

Votre bien dévoué,

+ Henri Belleau O.M.I.
Vicaire Apostolique de la Baie James.

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. McGill,

I wish to thank you personally for your successful efforts to get us a special grant of $15 per pupil for the fiscal year just ended. While all schools will appreciate this grant, I believe that the smaller schools, being the hardest hit, should appreciate it more than others.

The Kootenay School appears to be in a particularly difficult position: a few years ago, the Oblate Fathers had to pay off debts amounting to over $1000. When I came here, a year ago, I found about $375 in the Bank and bills amounting to about $500. The Oblate Fathers have, since March 1941, contributed about $700 to the school, - $4850 in cash and the balance in beef, pork, vegetables, etc., furnished free of charge from the Oblate farm.

Re: Special Cost-of-living grant to Indian Residential Schools.

Dear Doctor Cochrane:

May I refer to departmental letter dated March 25, 1942, relating to the marginally noted subject.

When the desirability of paying this grant was under consideration, the opinion was expressed by one or two of the officials here that the grant should be limited to certain schools that had been unable to meet their obligations out of the ordinary per capita grant. After further study of the problem, however, we discovered that we had not at our disposal sufficient documentary evidence to justify the limitation of the grant. It seemed likely to incur deficits as the result of the year's operations.

It was finally decided, therefore, that a grant above the normal per pupil should be made to the Churches responsible for the operation of our schools.

The suggestion has not been made that the churches should be permitted to distribute the special grants in a way that will help the financially embarrassed schools to a greater extent than the schools that are in a position to carry on for the time being at least without special aid. The Department can see no serious objection to this suggestion. In times of normal as well as abnormal conditions, however, it would seem to us rather unwise to pass on special grants to schools that are not urgently in need of such funds. No objection will be raised -

Inspectors of white schools may find in Indian Schools the system they are used to well carried out by teachers trained and certificated in that system; may find the scholars bright, competent and praiseworthy but unless the home part of the education of those scholars is attended to in the school since it cannot be in the home, the results will be lost effort or effort almost lost. Experience has demonstrated that such less, in fact, occurs.

It seems to me imperative that from the moment of entering to the moment of leaving school our Indian children should be first and foremost taught the lesson I have indicated, viz—what the qualities and privileges of citizenship are and how much they are to be desired and that teachers, inspectors, agents &c., should be instructed to see that they are taught this lesson.

The impetus if it is to be given must emanate from headquarters where the need is discerned and understood. Insistence upon that need being supplied must also emanate from central authority and from that authority compulsion should be applied.

It is not to be expected that isolated teachers should discern a truth that it has taken years of the accumulated experience and thought of many to bring to light, nor that inspectors of many white schools with perhaps one or two Indian schools to inspect should discover a fundamental fact in respect to Indian education, and differentiate between what is necessary for the white child and what is necessary for the Indian child.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Indian day schools will close for the Christmas holidays on December 22 and re-open on January 4, 1943. As you are aware, a teacher of an Indian day school resides on an Indian reserve and it is the usual custom to go home for the Christmas holidays.

We have always issued the salary cheque for the month of December in time for it to reach the school before the commencement of the Christmas holidays. However, I am advised by our Representative of the Treasury that the recent regulation regarding suspension of December salaries of temporary employees previous to Christmas this year also affects teachers of Indian day schools and, if no exception is made, these teachers will not receive their December salary until December 31.

I believe that in many cases this would cause a special hardship, as it would, in all probability, prevent many teachers from enjoying their Christmas holidays at home.

Taking everything into consideration, I believe that an exception should be made in their case and I appreciate it if you could arrange to have the salary cheques of the teachers of Indian day schools issued previous years. The number of cheques to be issued slightly under 300.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are 76 Indian residential schools in the Dominion of Canada;

THAT the Churches co-operating with the Department in the operation of these schools have directed our attention to the increased cost of many commodities and the higher wages now being paid to staff members;

THAT, as a result, the Indian residential schools have been obliged to incur extraordinary expenditures and consequently the Churches have appealed to the Department of Mines and Resources for a special grant in order to assist them to meet their obligations;

THAT, due to various causes, funds to an amount of $75,000.00 are available in the appropriation for the current fiscal year and that this amount would be sufficient to make a payment of $10.00 per pupil based on the average attendance as shown by the quarterly returns for the calendar year 1942.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that approval be given for the expenditure of a sum not in excess of $75,000.00 as a special grant at the rate of $10.00 a head on the pupilage at the Indian residential schools in the Dominion of Canada, same to be chargeable to Vote 186, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

First of all I would like to express my gratitude for your kind assistance in expediting the cheque for the September quarter. I would not have troubled you, had it not been a matter of extreme importance. Now, I wish to lay the following situation before you, for your consideration and with the intention of asking for your good offices in helping solve the matter.

It is getting more and more difficult each month to finance this school. This is due to three things: the reduction in the grant; the increased cost of living; and above all to the extraordinary number of children that we are forced to maintain above the paid quota. You are well aware of the first two, as they have been discussed quite a bit between schools and the Department. However, it is about the third, that I wish to treat in this letter. We are carrying, at this time, 35 children above the quota, for whom we do not receive one cent from the Department. In dollars and cents, this means an added expense of about $5440.00 each year. One might say, why carry so many over; or why not get rid of some. The answer is that it is impossible to reduce the number. Far from soliciting enrolment, we have been, for the past years, discouraging and putting off the entrance of children into the school, and furthermore, trying to get the parents to try other schools more distant. This, in itself is a really miserable business; especially when it has been the aim of the Department and the priests to encourage among Indians, the desire to send their children to school for education. Here we are destroying a principle that we have worked so long to establish. Yet, apparently it has to be done, and I mention it, not with any satisfaction, but merely to show that we have taken extraordinary measures to keep down our pupilage. I have taken abuse and plenty of it from Indians, whose children I could not admit into school, and God only knows that they needed it. It is, of course, the responsibility of the Department of Indian Affairs to provide educational facilities for the Indians; but the Indians take it out on the principal when they cannot get their children into school. I guess we can "take it" all right; it is part of our job; but it is well to note and note well, that, while in the past, there were only a few such scenes, they are now more frequent and the particular dissatisfaction of individual parents is working together into a general movement of unrest and consequent bitterness. I dare say that this is not a common condition among other schools; they may even have difficulty in getting enough children in to fill
their minimum quota. Their difficulty is in getting the children in to school; ours, in keeping them out. The whole thing goes back to a problem that has been present in our area for years. There have never been adequate school facilities for the number of children in our district. And this is not some outlying district, remote and isolated, but the Fraser Valley, the most thickly populated portion of British Columbia. It is growing rapidly and war industry has given it added impetus; consequently, our Indians are in daily contact with white people. They discuss problems with them, see what they have and want the same for themselves. Education is important for everybody, but it is doubly important where it is needed not only for its aesthetic qualities, but for survival. Our young Indian boys and girls have to compete with others for jobs; what chance will they have if they have no education, and I am not referring to higher education, but merely grade school. The days are past when one could make a living panning gold, or trapping, along the Fraser.

It is not my intention to bring any religious issue into this discussion, but, since this is relative to the matter, here is a very pertinent point. Children apply to come into school -- we cannot take them in for maybe three years -- they are now ten and eleven years of age, instead of seven and eight -- the result: they leave school at sixteen with a five or six grade education instead of eight or nine. Therefore many of the Catholic children in our district are more poorly educated than others, because they have not had equal opportunities.

This crowded condition of our school continues, in spite of the fact that day schools have been erected by the Department, in our area, wherever possible. During the past years, I have not taken in a child from a day school district, unless for very special reasons, such as: 1. Very poor conditions at home and with recommendation of agent. 2. No responsible guardianship. 3. Parents living at considerable distance from day school. 4. Ill health and with recommendation of doctor. In other words, our residential school with its present limitations together with all the day schools possible are by no means adequate for the number of children.

Another point to be considered is, that we are so constantly filled up with pupils, we can never co-operate with the agents, should they have a special case arising during the year, where some child should be admitted to school. I imagine that the agents think that I am "stalling" sometimes, when I tell them I have no room for their emergency cases; however, they realize my great difficulty and are very understanding.

I have gone to great lengths here, merely to show how impossible it is to reduce the pupilage, because I can understand that this will be the Department's obvious answer to my problem. And I also maintain that this is a very definite and particular problem of our school. Hence, to solve it, I am not asking for an increase in the pupilage grant, but rather for a supernumerary grant for the children that we are maintaining over and above the paid quota.

The Department of Indian Affairs have willingly taken on the responsibility of providing education and care for Indian children at the rate of $175.00 per year. In spite of this fact the same
Department allows us to provide for about thirty-two children, without it costing them one cent. Thus, we are burdened, at a time when expenses are so hard to meet, with an amount of $5440, which, in all justice, should be the burden of the Department. Or, look at it this way. If I should turn out these children, quite apart from the loss of education, there would be the matter of maintaining them in dollars and cents. Many of them are orphans and some one would have to be paid for keeping them.

I am sorry that this letter is becoming so lengthy; but, it is necessary that you be aware of every angle so that my case will be well understood. I always felt that it was unfair for us to be placed in such a position, but I was willing to be patient as long as I could maintain the school even with its extra burden. Now, the situation has become critical. I had to appeal to you to try and have our last quarterly cheque rushed, because all my money was gone. It was found to happen sooner or later, and the crisis was held off mainly by two things, 1. We provided from our Oblate farm to the utmost. 2. We cut down expenses to the absolute minimum. It took very little to upset the balance. A complete fruit failure and the present increase in prices did the job nicely.

I wish therefore, to obtain a supernumerary grant, extending back to the first of September, for twenty-five of the pupils, who are at present not maintained by the Department. I will have their names prepared and the agents' recommendations attached, with whatever other data, that the Department would require. This is, I believe, a very just request. But, because it so just and so minimal, I am exceedingly serious about its fulfilment. I would ask you, therefore, to take this matter up with the proper officials, so that our present acute situation may be speedily remedied.

Please remember the following points:

1. It is impossible to reduce the present pupilage.
2. It is not altogether merely a problem of education of children, but one of welfare and maintenance.
3. The situation has been present for some time.
4. The financial situation is serious.
5. The loss of staple produce and the very high cost of living.
6. It is a simple question of allocating responsibility for the children.

I sincerely hope that the Department will give full and just consideration to my request. I have tried very hard to build up a good school. It is held in high respect in the locality. It is the oldest Indian residential school in British Columbia. Your inspectors, agents and doctors have given us good reports. The care and affection of the fathers, sisters and brothers is something that cannot be reckoned in dollars and cents. Yet all this good redounds to the credit of the Department of Indian Affairs. Surely, where so much is given freely, it is not much to ask for simple justice. It is good to remember that the money asked for, is not for ourselves, but, for the Indian children, that they may be trained, clothed and fed.

Very sincerely,

(Sgd.) A.H. Fleury, O.M.I.,
Principal.
Ottawa,
November 25, 1943.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

An unusually large number of requests for an increased enrolment at Indian residential schools has reached the Department during the last two-year period. These requests can be attributed, in part, to the difficulty experienced by principals in financing the operation of their schools. Recent audit reports indicate that few of our schools have escaped deficits. These requests can also be attributed to the tendency, or, one might state, the insistence of the Department, that accommodation be provided at residential schools for orphans and neglected children. I am sending forward herewith a letter dated November 16, 1943, received by the Chief of the Training Division from the Principal of the St. Mary's Indian Residential School, Mission, British Columbia. This letter is typical of a number recently received.

I am sending forward also a statement showing the authorized pupilage at this date, the actual number of pupils in attendance at June 30, 1943, or at the close of the last academic year, and the actual number in attendance on the last of September, 1943, the opening date of the present academic year. These figures indicate that we have enrolled at residential schools at the present time 578 pupils for whom no grant is being paid. The average per capita grant amounts to $171.00. This being the case, it would appear that the churches are providing food, clothing and instruction to pupils at an annual cost of approximately $99,000.00. The representatives of the churches feel that they should not and cannot continue to assume this obligation. These representatives point out that the cost of living has increased at least 17% during the last two-year period and that this, coupled with the 8% reduction in the amount paid annually by
the Government in the form of per capita grants, means that they are operating with a 25% reduction in their regular revenues. They remind us also that during the period 1914-16 they received cost-of-living bonus amounting in all to $20.00 per pupil per annum.

The officials of the Welfare & Training Division find it difficult to convince themselves that an increased enrolment at any particular school, or group of schools, would prove adequate in the solution of this problem. They rather feel that the grants should be restored and paid on the 100% basis. In addition to this it is just possible that an adjustment in the enrolments now authorized may be necessary. It will be noted that Indian parents in the southern sections of the Dominion, who are gainfully employed, appear to be increasingly reluctant to send their children to these institutions. Enrolments at the Mount Elgin and Mohawk Institutes are far below the authorized figure. May I suggest, therefore, that consideration be given to:

1. The payment of per capita grants on the full authorized enrolment rather than on a basis of 95.84%. To do this will require an additional appropriation of approximately $70,000.00.

2. That representatives of the churches be called into conference to discuss certain adjustments that might be made in the authorized pupilage at a number of residential schools, particularly schools established on northern reserves.

3. That consideration be given to the desirability of having a thorough survey undertaken at our residential schools with the object of determining the number of pupils for which per capita grants should be paid and the number of day school pupils that might attend such schools, on the understanding that only a noonday lunch would be provided.
The officials here feel that these are matters of extreme urgency. It is scarcely necessary to remind you again that our school population is increasing at the rate of 300 pupils per annum, while our school building programme has been practically suspended in recent years. In addition to this a large number of schools have been destroyed by fire during the war period. With the exception of two or three schools built to replace schools destroyed by fire, the last residential school (Shubenacadie) was built in the year 1940. It would appear, therefore, that unless provision is made for the accommodation of Indian pupils in either Indian day schools or residential schools, the conditions to which I have referred are apt to become increasingly acute during the period immediately ahead of us.

Director.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

In response to the suggestion made by the Minister, immediately following his interview with representatives of the Churches on December 1, I am submitting herewith, for your consideration, certain proposals relating to the payment of per capita grants and a cost-of-living bonus to Indian residential schools.

In this connection may I refer to my memorandum to you dated November 25, 1942?

You are probably aware that, in addition to the regular per capita grant payments, made in recent years on a 92.24% basis, we have during the last two years made an additional grant amounting to $10.00 per pupil of the authorized enrolment at all residential schools. We recommend that a similar amount be paid for the fiscal year 1943-44 and that this payment be made at an early date. This extra disbursement would enable a number of the principals to purchase coal at this season of the year and other supplies in bulk and thus effect certain economies. There are sufficient funds in this year's appropriation to make this payment.

In addition, we recommend that provision be made in the 1944-45 estimates for the payment of a cost-of-living bonus to residential schools at the rate of $15.00 per pupil. This payment, if approved, will amount to approximately $125,000.00 and it will be necessary to make provision for this amount in the estimates now under consideration.

We have already intimated that in recent years per capita grants have been paid at the rate of 92.24%.

Dec 3/43
We recommend that for the year 1944-45 these grants be paid at the rate of 100%. No provision has been made in the 1943-44 estimates for this payment, which will amount to $70,000.00.

The officials of the Welfare and Training Division are constantly confronted with the spectacle of Indian pupils, many of them illegitimate children and others from disrupted homes, for whom it is necessary to provide accommodation and institutional care at residential schools. A number of such cases are invariably brought to the attention of the officials after the residential schools have recruited their full enrollment. For a time these children were accommodated by the discharge of senior pupils, but during the last two years there have been few senior pupils sufficiently advanced to be discharged from the schools, with the result that principals have been asked to provide, without remuneration, for an additional number of pupils. We recommend that provision be made in next year's estimates for the sum of $25,000.00. This sum would enable the officials, with ministerial approval, to pay supernumerary grants to certain residential schools that are at the present time, without cost to the Department, providing care and instruction for a number of Indian pupils.

It will be noted that the additional amount for which provision should be made in the 1944-45 estimates, should these recommendations be approved, would be $20,000.

You may remember that the Churches, in presenting their case to the Minister, expressed the opinion that a cost-of-living bonus, in certain cases at least, should be voted to the Churches, as such, and not to individual schools. The representative of the United Church emphasized in his remarks that this procedure enabled him to extend a greater measure of assistance to certain schools where the need was most urgent, and that a distribution made in this way was on the whole the most equitable. We can see no serious objection to the payment of this cost-of-living bonus in the manner suggested. Cheques could be issued to the Home Mission Board of the United Church and to the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada.
In the case of the Catholic Church it may be somewhat difficult to follow strictly this procedure. Where schools are grouped, however, under a particular Bishop, as in the case of Grouard, this method can be followed and it might be possible to work out this method with the Oblate Provincials in the case of the Prairie Provinces and British Columbia.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are 76 Indian residential schools in the Dominion of Canada;

THAT the Churches co-operating with the Department in the operation of these schools have directed our attention to the increased cost of many commodities and the higher wages now being paid to staff members;

THAT, as a result, the Indian residential schools have been obliged to incur extraordinary expenditures and consequently the Churches have appealed to the Department of Mines and Resources for a special grant in order to assist them to meet their obligations;

THAT, due to various causes, funds to an amount of $75,000 are available in the appropriation for the current fiscal year and that this amount would be sufficient to make a payment of $10 per pupil based on the average attendance as shown by the quarterly returns for the calendar year 1943.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that approval be given for the expenditure of a sum not in excess of $75,000 as a special grant at the rate of $10 a head on the pupilage at the Indian residential schools in the Dominion of Canada, same to be chargeable to Vote 184, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Re: Adjustment of Per Capita Grant Payments to Residential Schools.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

The estimates for the fiscal year ending March 31, 1945, have been tabled in Parliament. I note that the appropriation under the heading "Grants to Residential Schools" has been increased from $1,247,866.00, the amount voted last year, to $1,522,774.00. This additional amount will enable us to pay our regular grants to residential schools at the rate of 100% rather than at the rate of 92.24%. It will enable us also to pay a cost-of-living bonus at the rate of $15.00 per pupil for the calendar year 1944, based on the average attendance.

In addition to these payments, a cost-of-living bonus, amounting to $10.00 per pupil and based on the average attendance, will be paid to residential schools for the fiscal year ending March 31, 1944.

I am naturally anxious to discuss the details of these payments and the effect they are likely to have on attendance at our residential schools, at the time of your next visit to Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re - Payment of Per Capita Grants

The other day when I was in Ottawa, in the course of conversation, the matter of the time of payment of per capita grants came up. Quite frankly, I do not see why the Church should finance the Schools. The United Church receives from the Department approximately $120,000 a year—which is $30,000 every quarter. We have to wait until the end of the quarter—and a couple of weeks beyond, before we get the payments. In the meantime, we have advanced to our Principals $30,000, which we have had to borrow from the Bank. I think that the Department should pay us one-tenth of the per capita grants each month, making an adjustment at the end of every three months when the returns come in; or, as an alternative, pay one quarter in advance, with the understanding that there should be adjustments.

So far as we are concerned, we do not think it is fair for the Church, not only to have to provide grants in connection with some of our Schools and provide for the retirement of the Principals, including, in the case of ordained ministers, payment of $100.00 to our Pension Fund, and at the same time to finance the Government to this extent. In view of the fact that taxation, including income tax, is collected on a pay-as-you-go basis, we expect the Department to put the Indian Schools on the same basis.

I should be very glad if you would take this matter up with the Treasury Department.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Doctor Dorey:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of February 25, in which you discuss the desirability of certain adjustments in the payment of per capita grants to residential schools.

I have already discussed the subject matter of your letter with the Chief Treasury Officer and it is my intention to send forward your communication to the Director, for submission to the Minister. The present payments, I may state, are made in conformity with the provisions of an agreement entered into by the Churches responsible for the operation of our residential schools and the Government, early in the year 1911. Article 2 (Section 1) of this agreement reads:

"To pay the management at the rate of ....... per annum for each pupil, but the number of pupils so to be paid for shall not exceed ......... in accordance with the restrictions hereinbefore set out; the payments shall be made quarterly and each quarterly payment shall be computed on the average attendance of each pupil; provided, however, that the said grant shall be allowed and paid during the vacation; but no payments will be made until return have been received by the Superintendent General duly certified by the Indian Agent for ......... that the said school has been maintained and managed according to the true intent and meaning of this contract."

It is true that this contract or agreement
was entered into for a period of five years, but it is also true that the agreement, as such, has never been formally rescinded or abrogated by either the Government or the Churches. I am disposed to think, therefore, that the passage already quoted is looked upon by the Treasury officials and the Auditor General as their authority and direction for the quarterly per capita grant payments.

It is just possible, of course, that the time has come when the payment of these per capita grants and more particularly the method of payment should be carefully reviewed and perhaps an agreement worked out, somewhat similar to the agreement in 1911. This is a matter that might be taken up by the representatives of the Churches with the Minister, at the time of their next visit to Ottawa.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Dear Major MacKay:

In your annual report which recently reached the Branch I note you refer to salaries at the Indian day schools in British Columbia. We are well aware that throughout the Dominion there is an upward trend in teachers' salaries in the white schools and consequently we will have to give serious consideration to increasing the salaries at Indian day schools.

It is sometimes overlooked by our teachers that we are paying 17% bonus to unmarried teachers and a flat rate of $18.48 a month to those with dependents. On several occasions the fact has been brought to my attention that many teachers compare their basic salary with the salary paid at white schools and do not allow for the bonus just mentioned. However, I simply mention this in passing, because I feel it is a point which should be kept in mind by all of us.

I enclose a list showing the day schools in British Columbia and the amount that we have provided for salaries for the academic year 1944-45. It would be appreciated if you would review this list and suggest any changes which you think should be made in order to bring all salaries in line with your ideas. When this is received your recommendations will have very careful and sympathetic consideration. Although it may not be possible to adjust all salaries during the coming year, changes could be made at those schools where new teachers are being appointed.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY,

On this file you will find Commissioner MacKay's letter of August 9. You will remember that we wrote to him on June 9, suggesting that he submit a revision of the salaries of the day school teachers in British Columbia.

The amount involved to cover all the increases recommended on the attached list by Commissioner MacKay is $3,750.00 for basic salary. In addition, of course, there would be the bonus.

To handle only the increases mentioned on the two pages of Commissioner MacKay's letter would involve an amount of $650.00.

Both amounts - $3,750 and $650 - are annual amounts. For the balance of the current fiscal year we would only require to spend seven tenths of these amounts, which would mean 7/10 of $2,750 and 7/10 of $650.

I have today reviewed our expenditures under the headings of Salaries and Bonus for the three months of April, May and June and I feel certain that the appropriation provided in the current year's estimates is sufficiently large to handle all the increases suggested by Commissioner MacKay. I have not replied to his letter as I thought it advisable to have your opinion before doing so. If you wish to let the matter stand until I return on Friday or Saturday, I will discuss it further with you.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, August 11, 1944.

MEMORANDUM:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

This Branch is in receipt of a letter from Reverend George Dorey, D.D., Associate Secretary, Board of Home Missions, United Church of Canada, requesting that the per capita rate at the Alberni Residential School be increased from $170.00 to $180.00 per annum. I understand that Dr. Dorey also spoke to Mr. Jackson regarding this matter.

There has been no radical change in the basic per capita rate at Indian residential schools since 1931. At that time certain basic rates were established at all residential schools and the rate at the Alberni School was set at $170.00 per capita, while the rate at the Christie School, which is also on Vancouver Island but is more inaccessible, was placed at $180.00. Dr. Dorey has pointed out to me that while, geographically, Christie appears more inaccessible, as a matter of fact it costs the United Church practically the same rate to ship their supplies to Alberni. Taking everything into consideration, I would appreciate receiving the Minister's approval to increase the per capita rate at Alberni from $170.00 to $180.00 per annum, effective January 1, 1945.

At this time it might be interesting for you to have a review of the per capita structure at Indian residential schools. An Order-in-Council, passed on October 22, 1932, authorized the per capita grant method of financing what is now known as "Indian Residential Schools". At that time per capita grants
varied from $60.00 to $145.00 and the average grant for the succeeding twenty years was $84.00.

In response to a request from the Churches for larger grants for residential schools, the Department in 1911 prepared a schedule by geographic divisions and types of buildings and a formal agreement was made between the Department and the management of the residential schools. This agreement was in effect from April 1, 1911, to April 1, 1916. The average grant during that period was $115.00.

In 1919 a bonus or flat increase of $10.00 on the basic rate was allowed all residential schools and in 1921 an additional $10.00, or a total bonus of $20.00, made the average rate for all residential schools in Canada $135.00. In 1924 this bonus was incorporated in the regular scale of grants. In January, 1926, there was another upward revision and an effort was made to deal more fairly with the small school, also the school remote from markets and the school where farming and other facilities were inadequate. This particular revision was continued for five years, and by 1931 the average per capita grant paid to Indian residential schools in Canada amounted to $175.00. Owing to economic conditions existing following the year 1930, the per capita rate was reduced by 10%, or, in other words, the average per capita grant in Canada for 1932-33 was approximately $155.00. A further 5% deduction was made during the years 1933-34 and 1934-35, bringing the average to $147.00.

In 1935-36 and subsequent years the 15% deduction was restored, bringing the average per capita rate back to the same as existed in 1931-32, namely approximately $175.00. As a result of representations made by the Churches co-operating with the Department in the operation of residential schools, a special payment of $10.00 per capita, over and above the regular per capita rate, was made for the calendar year 1942 and a similar amount for 1943. For the year 1944, this special allowance was increased to $15.00.

Acting Director.
Ottawa, March 23, 1945.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

As you are aware, the teachers in the Indian Day Schools for the past few years have been affected by the general order which did not permit the payment of salaries to temporary Civil servants previous to Christmas.

It is a regular practice in white schools and was the practice in this Department for a great many years to issue the December salary cheques of the teachers in Indian Schools so that they would be received by the teachers on or about December 21st.

In view of the scarcity of teachers at the present time, we have had great difficulty in securing teachers for many of our Indian schools. All of the teachers are aware of the fact that in white schools their salary is paid previous to Christmas and if we continue to follow the same practice as in recent years, it will cause us additional difficulty in securing qualified teachers.

In view of the above, I would appreciate it if arrangements can be made to pay the salaries of all teachers in our Indian Day Schools on or about December 21st, 1946.

Director

The per capita allowance to Residential Schools was reduced by 10% during the fiscal year 1932-33. This reduction was increased to 15% in the fiscal years 1933-34 and 1934-35.

A restoration of 10% took place in the fiscal year 1935-36 and the remaining 5% was returned in the fiscal year 1939-40.

An extra allowance of $10.00 over and above the regular per capita grant, based on the average attendance, was paid for the calendar years 1941, 1942 and 1943 and an extra amount of $15.00 for the calendar years 1944, 1945 and 1946.

Manual Training Instructor's Grants

Provision was made in the Main and Supplementary Estimates for the fiscal years 1945-46 and 1946-47 for the payment of allowances towards the salaries of manual training instructors whose qualifications meet the requirements of the Department. In the appropriation for the fiscal year 1947-48 provision is being made for the payment of practically the whole salaries.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, November 29th, 1946.

Mr. Hoey,

In your memorandum of the 20th instant it is suggested that perhaps representations should be made to Treasury Board on behalf of teachers in Indian Day Schools to permit their being paid December salary before Christmas.

School teachers appear to be in exactly the same position as other temporary employees of the Dominion Government and there would seem to be a matter of general policy involved in that apparently pre-Christmas spending is not to be encouraged. It is realized that provincial public school teachers usually receive the December salary cheques at the completion of the term which occurs before Christmas but an early payment in their case is made to facilitate closing the books for audit prior to the end of the calendar year. In any event it would not appear that receiving the salary cheque on the 21st or 31st of December will make much difference in the actual securing of qualified teachers.

Chief Executive Assistant.

Memorandum:

Mr. HENRY,

Increased per Capita Grants for Indian Residential Schools

Further to our meeting on Monday morning, I submit herewith recommendations of this Service for increased grants to Indian Residential Schools.

Where at all possible, these have been based upon Auditors' reports. Where recent auditors' reports have not been available, we have settled the amount by placing the school in the same category as other schools in the same geographic locality. For example, in the Far North, we have recommended an increased grant of $50.00 for Fort George C.H., Fort George R.C., Moose Fort, Aklavik C.H., Aklavik R.C., Fort Resolution and Providence Mission. This brings the total grant for these schools to $265.00 per pupil. The only school exceeding this amount is the Carcross School in the Yukon, for which we have recommended a grant of $315.00.

In accordance with your recommendations, we have endeavored to keep this emergency grant to a reasonable figure. As it now stands the increased sum required in the Estimates would be $248,350.00.

Emil.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, March 6, 1947.

Mr. W. Smellie, For Secretary, Treasury Board,
Department of Finance, Ottawa.

Increased per capita Costs
for Indian Residential Schools

On November 29, 1946, I received a delegation from
the four denominations who are operating our Indian Residential
Schools. They presented to me a long brief detailing the rising
expenditures with which the managements of these schools are faced.
Their operating costs are largely concerned with the purchase of
food and the hiring of teachers, cooks, farming instructors and
other staffs for these schools. The recent prices in food alone
have resulted in much heavier expenditures at these institutions.
For example, a recent Treasury Auditor's report on one of these
schools reveals the following increases in food costs:

| Average Cost per Mo. for previous audited period | Average Cost per Mo. for current audited period | Increase |
|--------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------|----------|
| Mar. 1/43 - Apr 30/45                            | May 1/45 - Dec.31/46                             | $168.37  |

Rising labour costs have also made it very difficult
for these schools to operate. This is especially the case in the
payment of salaries for teachers.

The picture they painted was indeed a very black one,
especially in the instance of the Church of England. In spite of
every effort to cut expenditures as low as possible, the Indian
School Administration of this Church finds itself faced with an
operating deficit of $143,226.00 in the 1947-48 year. Our
auditors' reports show that during the fiscal year ending on
31 December, 1945, this denomination lost $73,890.81 in the oper-
ation of its Indian residential schools. This is indeed a serious
situation for this Missionary Society and they are greatly worried
as to whether or not they will have to withdraw entirely from the operation of these schools and let the Dominion Government carry on this educational duty.

The Chairman of the delegation was the Reverend Doctor George Dorey, Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada. He has recently written to the Indian Affairs Branch as follows:

"I should also like to say that we are anxious to hear from the proper authorities as to what has happened to our request for increased per capita grants. This is the time of the year when we are dealing with our church budgets; and I may say that we do not contemplate, with any sort of happy feeling, having to put in church money to do the Government's work; and further, that any request for an increased grant of church funds for the operation of Indian Schools is going to create quite a feeling in our Board that the Government is not discharging its obligation for the educational needs of the Indian people".

Other delegates represented the Roman Catholic Church and the Presbyterian Church in Canada. The information which they presented is very much the same as that of the other two denominations.

I have attached herewith for your information recommendations for increased grants to Indian residential schools. These figures have, where at all possible, been based upon our own auditors' reports. Where recent auditors' reports were not available, the amount was decided by placing the school in the same category as other schools in the same geographic locality. For example, in the Northwest Territories, we have recommended an increased grant of $85.00 for the four schools in this area. This will bring the total grant for these schools to $300.00 per
pupil, an amount exceeded only by the Carcross School in the Yukon, for which a grant of $315.00 is recommended. The reason for this large increase is partially based upon a recent ordinance of the Northwest Territories Council whereby a restriction has been placed upon the number of moose which can now be shot annually in the Territories. This will mean the importing of large quantities of meat from Alberta and a resultant sharp increase in operating expenses.

Every effort has been made to keep this emergency grant to a reasonable figure. It is felt that this need is temporary and you will note in the attached scale that it is entitled "Emergency Grant". It is hoped that this grant can be eliminated when living costs are reduced.

I would emphasize the need for immediate decision in this matter. The Churches are now preparing their annual budgets and they are frankly in a quandary as to how to plan their expenses for the coming year. It is recommended therefore that the Treasury Board approve now a sum of $256,575.00 for inclusion in the Supplementary Estimates for this expenditure, as detailed herewith.

(Yours sincerely)

(For The Minister's signature)
Ottawa, March 7, 1947.

This will bring the total grant for these schools to $300.00 per pupil, an amount exceeded only by the Carcross School in the Yukon, for which a grant of $15.00 is recommended. The reason for this large increase is partially based upon a recent ordinance of the Northwest Territories Council which has a restriction been placed upon the number of acres which can now be shot annually in the Territories. This will mean the importing of large quantities of meat from Alberta and a resultant sharp increase in operating expenses.

Every effort has been made to keep this emergency grant to a reasonable figure. It is felt that this need is temporary and you will note in the attached scale that it is entitled "Emergency Grant". It is hoped that this grant can be eliminated when living costs are reduced.

I would emphasize the need for immediate decision in this matter. The churches are now preparing their annual budgets and they are frankly in a quandary as to how to plan their expenses for the coming year. It is recommended therefore that the Treasury Board approve now a sum of $256,755.00 for inclusion in the Supplementary Estimates for this expenditure, as detailed herewith.
Ottawa, March 26, 1947.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY,

I have been anticipating arguments which will be presented by the various denominations when they present their briefs to the Parliamentary Committee. I feel certain that they will not be satisfied with the amount of the increase, especially after they had requested as high as a flat $90 increase. In other words, they will not be too happy about $256,000 when they asked for $720,000.

As you know, one of their strongest demands was for the provision of labour saving devices. It is my feeling that if the Minister is further approached by the denominations for additional per capita grant increases, we should consider advising him that such an increase should come in the form of a mechanical equipment grant.

If, for example, it was decided to bring the amount of the increase in per capita grants from $256,000 to approximately $300,000, then I would suggest that we allot a sum of $5.00 for each student for whom a school is entitled to receive grant.

For example, Kamloops School is entitled to 300 students. Then the Reverend Father O'Grady would be entitled to request that we purchase through the Departmental Purchasing Agent mechanical devices to the extent of $1,500. (300 x 5). These labour saving devices permitted would only be those listed by the Nutritionists of the Department of National Health and Welfare as previously submitted by this branch to the Minister's office.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt.; of Welfare & Training.

Dear Colonel Neary: Per Capita Allowances

I have to thank you for your letter of April 21st, giving information about the increases which are to go into effect from January 1st, 1947. I need scarcely say that this information is most gratifying and the total addition to our income will represent a very considerable relief. The amount will not of course enable us to advance very much and we regret that we cannot pay the increased salaries which seem to be necessary to secure qualified workers. We are, however, grateful for the assistance which the Branch is now making in connection with the salaries of Manual Training and Handicraft instructors and this is proving most helpful.

May I point out a slight error in the statement appended to your letter. In connection with the Sioux Lockout School, I estimate the total grant as $210.00 instead of $205.00 as shown. I shall be glad if you will kindly verify this; but for the present we are assuming that the figure of $210.00 is correct.

Thanking you, I remain

Yours sincerely,

H. A. Alderwood
Superintendent.

MR. GEORGE W. CAMPBELL

Mr. George W. Campbell died on April 10 at Guelph, Ontario, in his 97th year. He started teaching at the school in the Owen Sound area, and in 1903 came to Carman, where he began a service in the schools which lasted until 1924. He then went into business which he continued until a few years ago when he went to Guelph where his daughter was Superintendent of the General Education. Mr. Campbell during his long, active life entered into the activities of the community whole-heartedly. It was a long life full of service for the people with whom he lived.

MRS. GLADYS A. CLINE

Mrs. Gladys A. Cline died on March 28th at the age of 43 years. Her service in the Manitoba schools covered a period of fourteen years and was of a very high order. Whilst her span of life was comparatively short, it was full of deeds of service.

MISS JESSIE ELLIS

On February 14th Miss Jessie Ellis, a retired Winnipeg teacher, died at the age of 64. She rendered a splendid service over a period of more than thirty years before her retirement in 1932. We bear tribute to the excellence of her work.

MRS. C. V. GUNN

The funeral service for Mrs. Hazel Adele Gunn, wife of the Principal of the Arden School, who was burned to death on March 11th in the garage of her home, in Glenella, was held March 15, in the Arden United Church, with burial in the local cemetery. Formerly of Arden, Mrs. Gunn taught school for a number of years before her marriage, and all her life showed keenest interest in the welfare of boys and girls.

MISS S. ANNIE HODNETT

Miss S. Annie Hodnett died on April 18th at the age of 76 years. Her peculiar name to Birtle in 1882 but most of her teaching service was in Alberta. We bear tribute to her because of her service in the early and formative days in the rural schools of Manitoba.

MISS FLORENCE IRWIN

Miss Florence Irwin who died on March 15, aged 57 years, taught for more than thirty years in Winnipeg. She came to the staff in 1914 as a teacher of Household Science and served at Aberdeen, Grey, Kenaston and Gordon Bell Schools. She traveled widely in the interests of her profession taking courses particularly in Columbia University and University of Chicago. Her interests were widespread and she was a member of the Professional and Business Women's Club. Her service was of a very high order.

Elementary Principals — $50.00 per class room.

One Room High — Minimum $1,800.00, with seven annual increments of $100.00 each in addition to $50.00 per classroom.

Coronation Department — Minimum $2,000.00, with ten annual increments of $100.00 each in addition to $50.00 per classroom.

Degree and Faculty of Education Training — Minimum $2,025.00, with seven annual increments of $100.00 each in addition to $50.00 per classroom.

Collegiate Institute — $2,800.00, with ten annual increments of $100.00 each in addition to $50.00 per classroom.

REGULATIONS

1. No teacher to be required to accept a salary on this schedule lower than that received on present schedule.

2. Change of status (marital—undergraduate to graduate) salary to be the same as it would have been had new status applied from time of appointment.

3. Probation—one year—all new teachers to receive minimum salary for their classification during this period.

4. (A) Teachers transferring from one district to another shall receive one year's credit on schedule for each two years' experience up to a limit of three years' credit on schedule. A maximum of three years' credit is to be given for experience of six years or more limited to classification to which teacher is being appointed.

(B) In the case of teachers who are already on the staff, credit shall be given for experience on the staff plus outside experience as outlined in the clause above.

5. All teachers must take, at least once every five years, some course of study to improve or refresh his or her academic or professional qualifications in order to advance on schedule or to maintain schedule level if on maximum.

6. In all cases, "number of rooms" means total number, both High School and Elementary.

Pensions

The first meeting of the Pensions Committee was held Thursday, April 17th with the following members present: Mr. W. Murphy, Chairman, Mrs. L. Houston, Misses E. Miller, E. Denair, and Messrs. Gray, Quelch, J. K. Gordon, Henderson, Wallace and the General Secretary. Apologies for non-attendance were received from Mr. W. Hawn, Mr. F. D. Baragar and Miss Hilda K. Kinney.

The Chairman welcomed all members, old and new, and proceeded with a resumé of the work of the Committee for the past year.

A general discussion re plans for the coming year took up the major part of the two-hour meeting.

Research

The first meeting of the Research Committee was held on April 12th with the following in attendance: Mr. C. S. Quelch, Chairperson; Misses Hilda K. Kinney, Sybil Shack, Messrs. Laurie, McMurphy, Newfield, Shearer and the General Secretary.

The Chairman outlined two immediate projects for the consideration of the Committee, viz:

A. An enquiry into teacher-shortage, initiated primarily by a sub-committee of the C.T.F.

B. An enquiry into the distribution of the new provincial grants to education, initiated by the Provincial Executive and requested by June 7th.

It was agreed also that the Rural Questionnaire be studied in order that additions be made to it if necessary. It is the hope of the Committee that more rural teachers will reply to these questionnaires in future thereby giving us a more adequate sampling of conditions and trends.

Finance

The first meeting of the Finance Committee was held on April 28th with the following members present: Mr. M. R. Conway, Chairman, Messrs. Beer, Gendron, Hall, MacDonell, Marshall and the General Secretary.

Rulings were made in connection with certain claims for expenses other than those provided by the authorities of Provincial Council. In all cases, the policy laid down by Council was maintained.

The setting-up of a new system of bookkeeping was discussed at length. The society's business has developed to such an extent that more frequent audits and a more streamlined, up-to-date method of posting seemed necessary.

A special sub-committee of Messrs. Gendron, Beer, Herron and the General Secretary was appointed to engage the firm of Chartered Accountants in order that the new system be established on a perfectly adequate and sound basis.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Increased Per Capita Grants
for Indian Residential Schools -

After considering the requests of the recent delegation of the Churches to the Minister, it was decided to work out an overall cost increase for the various items included in the normal budget of an Indian Residential School.

In order to arrive at this index, the following steps were taken:

(a) Our Treasury and Schools officials carefully considered a sampling of auditors' reports in order to derive the various items upon which the residential school dollar is spent. The figures below are based on a sampling of twenty (20) residential schools selected across Canada and representing the four denominations concerned.

| Item                        | Percentage |
|-----------------------------|------------|
| Food                        | 36 cents   |
| Light, Fuel and Water       | 9 cents    |
| Clothing                    | 8 cents    |
| Salaries                    | 30 cents   |
| House Expenses and Sundries | 17 cents   |

Total: $1.00

(b) The Dominion Bureau of Statistics was then requested to calculate the cost increase index on the basis of the above breakdown of the residential school.
They were asked to work out this index as showing the increase in costs of the above items since January 1, 1947. We have now received this figure from them, namely a 17% increase. You will find attached hereunder a letter from Mr. Rosebottom, Statistician, Prices Branch, Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

The total sum included in our Main and Supplementary Estimates for 1947-48 for the payment of per capita grants to Residential Schools is $1,932,220.00. A 17% increase in these per capita grants would require an additional sum per fiscal year of $330,000.00.

Therefore, if it is desired to recommend to the Minister that increased grants based on this figure be provided, it will be necessary to consider provision of the following supplementary amounts:

(a) If the grant is to be dated from October 1, 1947, an amount of $330,000.00 will have to be included in the 1948-49 Supplementary Estimates. You will note that two quarterly payments (namely December 31, 1947, and March 31, 1948) at the increased amounts, can be met from our present funds because of the following facts:

1. Our present Vote is in a sound position and we are far enough ahead in funds to pay out an extra $80,000.00 for the quarter ending December 31, 1947.

2. As payments to residential schools are made at the end of each quarter, based on quarterly returns, we will make payments for the March 1948 quarter out of funds provided in the Main 1948-49 Estimates.

(b) If the grant is to be dated from January 1, 1948, an amount of $250,000.00 will have to be included in the 1948-49 Supplementary Estimates.

It is recommended that consideration be given to
starting these grants from October 1, 1947, as requested by
the denominations. This will then adjust per capita to
the present cost of living and enable them to prepare their
1948 Budgets with the knowledge that all back accounts have
been settled.

Therefore, I would appreciate being advised as
to whether this increase has been approved and also as to
the effective date.

Director.

MEMORANDUM FOR THE SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY BOARD

To provide for an additional sum of $330,000.00 in the 1948-49 Supplementary Estimates for increased per capita grant payments to Indian Residential Schools.
January 5, 1948.

The Secretary,
The Treasury Board,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there have been requests and delegations to me from the various denominations operating Indian Residential Schools that an increase be made in the per capita grants made to them for the conduct of such schools;

THAT their requests were that this increase should be based upon the increased costs of operating such schools in view of the rise in prices;

THAT Treasury and Education officials of the Indian Affairs Branch considered a sampling of the auditors' reports upon these residential schools in order to derive the various items upon which the average residential school dollar is spent;

THAT the figures below are based on a sampling of twenty (20) residential schools across Canada and representing all four denominations:

| Item                        | Cost |
|-----------------------------|------|
| Food                        | 36 cents |
| Light, Fuel and Water       | 9 cents |
| Clothing                    | 8 cents |
| Salaries                    | 30 cents |
| House Expenses and Supplies | 17 cents |

THAT the Dominion Bureau of Statistics was then requested to calculate the cost increase index since January 5, 1947, based on the above breakdown of the residential school dollar;

THAT the Prices Branch, Dominion Bureau of Statistics, reported as follows:

"Further to our conversation and in reply to your letter of December 15, we have calculated an index on the basis of the breakdown of the Residential School dollar over January 5, 1947, and this shows a cost increase of 17 per cent."

THAT the total sum included in our Main and Supplementary Estimates for 1947-48 for the payment of per capita grants to Residential Schools was $2,793,228.00;
THAT an increase in these per capita grants would require an additional sum per fiscal year of $330,000.00.

It is, therefore, recommended that approval be given for the inclusion in the 1948-49 Supplementary Estimates of $330,000.00 for an increase in per capita grants to Indian Residential Schools.

It is further recommended that the undersigned be authorized to pay, in addition to the already approved grants, this increased grant effective from 1 October, 1947, out of the monies at present on hand in Vote 182 because of the following facts:

(a) This Vote is at present in a sound position and funds are available for the payment of an extra $330,000.00 for the quarter ending December 31, 1947.

(b) As payments to Residential Schools are made at the end of each quarter, based on quarterly returns, payments can be made for the March 1948 quarter out of funds still available for 1947-48 and the balance from funds provided in the main 1948-49 Estimates.

Minister of Mines and Resources.
