Dear Dr. Dorey,

I am enclosing a letter I have received from the Manager of the Bank of Montreal which carries our account. Mr. Wylie spoke to me about the increasing overdraft. He is not, of course, worried about the account, but only about the irregularity of permitting a $7000.00 plus overdraft where the authorization is only for $4000.00. You will remember that this matter came up before when I first took over. The prospects then, however, were that the overdraft could be reduced. This was done, down to the approximate amount of $3000.00 at one time. The situation now has changed, however, and I see no prospect of anything but ever increasing expenditure if the present price and wage trend continues.

The overdraft for January is $6221.00, with a total adverse Cash Book balance of $7425.00. January accounts and salaries are still to be paid (on February 15th, when the remittance advance of $4000.00 is received). This will approximate $6000.00. The arrears of revenue due to the school amount to $1500.00, leaving an overall deficit of some $11,000.00, bringing us back to where we were three and one-half years ago.

First, there is the absolute necessity of increased Government revenue. Procrastination should no longer be tolerated. Also, the Government should either assume definite responsibility for the deficit to date, either by payment of the deficit or satisfying the carrying banks that it is a Government responsibility. In the meantime it is necessary that the Principal should have authorization to incur an overdraft to the amount of his expenditure under the present and prospective operating cost.....to what amount I cannot estimate, but I would say the authorization should be for $10,000.00. I still suggest that the expenditure over revenue should be carried as a deficit and Bank overdraft. Subsidization by the Church in the reduction of deficit or the augmentation of current revenue would simply encourage the Government to continue its policy of evading its Indian education responsibilities.

Further, may I suggest that the deferring of proper action on the part of the Government and the Church in dealing promptly and decisively with the matter of school finance tends to debase the functional value of the school.
I have already lost one of the best Boys' Supervisors in the educational system, a man who has made this work a vocation, because of lack of opportunity and security afforded in employment by the school. There is no inducement given to the teachers to continue employment in a residential school. They are sacrificing salary, experience scale increases and superannuation by teaching in a residential school. It might be noted here that teachers in all the Alberni Public Schools have this week been awarded an "across the board" increase of $200.00 (retroactive) by an Arbitration Board. I have been fortunate in obtaining a very good slate of teachers this term, but I cannot hope to engage them for another year. We must be able to offer teachers inducements at least the equal of the Public Schools, otherwise we must put up with the left-overs (if there are any) to the detriment of our standard of teaching.

Also there is the functional value of the Principal to consider. No Principal could be expected to continue to give efficient attention to all the many duties that make for the efficient operation of an institution such as Alberni School, and carry, at the same time, the constant burden of ever increasing debt, about which one can do nothing and of which there is no end in sight.

Surely the Churches ought to be able to impress the urgency of the emergency on the Government, so that immediate action can be taken. It is absolutely useless for the Government or the Church to counsel retrenchment or economy. This has been practised to the limit beyond which we cannot go. It is false economy, and functional suicide, to attempt further economy in food. The late Principal of the Alert Bay School foolishly tried this experiment at the beginning of this term, resulting in his resignation, and a loss in prestige of that school with the Indian people from which it will take them a long time to recover. Salaries must be held down, at the cost of operating with a mediocre staff. The present supply situation in clothing, boots and shoes, soaps, and in practically every necessary line, is such that we cannot bargain or question either price or quality.

MEMORANDUM of a PRESENTATION regarding the need for increased Grants to Indian Residential Schools, made by the Representatives of the Churches co-operating with the Government, to the Minister, the Honourable James A. Glen, Friday, November 29th, 1947.

The Committee representing the Churches which co-operate with the Government desires, first of all, to express thanks for the increase made during the year by the Department in the per capita Grant. We trust that we shall not be misunderstood if we describe this increase as in the nature of 'small mercies' for which we should be thankful. To-day, however, we desire to put before you certain facts which make it necessary for us to ask for further increases in the per capita grant. The reason for the request for these increases is based on the following:

I. SALARIES

The Schools have been paying a very low salary to the teachers and other personnel employed. As an example, The Church of England in Canada pays an average of $600.00 in cash to its teachers. In addition, they receive board, etc., which is conservatively estimated to cost another $400.00 a year, making a total salary for the teacher of $1,000 as an average.

May we point out that we cannot expect to continue to engage teachers that are even modestly qualified unless salaries are raised very considerably, and we should point out to you that one reason why we cannot do this is because we have such competition from another section of the Department, namely, the Training Division, which employs day school teachers, and according to whose schedule a second-class teacher, with two years' experience -- which, after all, is just a modest professional qualification -- is to be paid $1250 a year. If you deduct $400 for board, that would mean that the Department is paying $850 to a teacher as against the average of $600 which is being paid currently by The Church of England.

The Department is continually pressing -- and we think rightly so -- for teachers with better professional qualifications; for more supervision; for more specialized activities; and this will add to the salary budget.

The Schools are also faced with the fact that they are paying salaries to other personnel, such as cooks, engineers and supervisors, etc., which are ridiculously low. Here, again, they come into competition with the Department of National Health in some cases. There has been brought to our notice an instance where the Church was paying a cook $60.00 a month and she was offered and accepted a salary of $125.00, which was paid by the Department of National Health.

May we point out with all due respect that if the Government of Canada can find money in the Estimates to pay teachers $1250, and cooks
at the rate at which they are being paid by the Department of National Health, there would seem to be, on the face of it, no reason why it could not find money to enable the Church to pay at least the same salaries to the same quality of personnel.

The Churches are also faced with the fact that in certain of the Provinces, Labour Relations Boards are insisting on minimum wages, beyond those which we are paying, and on hours of work which are very considerably less than our staffs are giving, and also on such general conditions as will make it necessary, not only to pay higher salaries, but to increase the personnel very greatly.

II. OTHER ITEMS OF EXPENDITURE: Food - Fuel - Clothing and Home Furnishings:

We are setting before you a Schedule extracted from a Dominion Bureau of Statistics Bulletin, which shows the increase in the cost of various items: first, in relation to 1939, and, secondly, the increase in the calendar year 1947.

From this table it will be seen that food costs have increased 71 per cent. over 1939, and also that there has been a further increase of 21.3 per cent. in this calendar year.

The figures for fuel, clothing and house furnishings show a similar sharp increase in 1947.

Special emphasis is now being placed on better diet in the schools, and the rations which are furnished by the schools have been examined by the Department of National Health and recommendations made that the ration of fish and meat should be increased by 25 per cent.; fats, by 40 per cent.; and that the consumption of milk should also be increased. This would, of course, mean a reduction in the amount of bread and certain other items, such as potatoes, which would be consumed.

Nevertheless, the Principal of a Residential School, with an enrolment of one hundred, operated by one of the Churches, has calculated that the change in the diet for his School would cost $3,200 a year.

The Churches are honestly trying to raise the standard of operation of the schools, but up to the present the increase in the per capita grant has hardly met the increase in the cost of living, and has not made possible the higher standard of maintenance which is desired by everybody.

Clothing is an item which should be improved. The Principal of a School operated by one of the Churches estimates that it would cost, on the basis of the prices in a mail order catalogue, an average of $35 to clothe a girl for a year, and $70 to clothe a boy. This would mean that in a school of 125 pupils, the clothing budget would be $7,868.00.

The Indians themselves are demanding that the children be sent from the School to their homes, at holiday time, with a complete new outfit, but they send them back after the holidays with very little clothing,
and the School has to start all over again with a clothing issue.

The members of the deputation are quite well aware that the standard of clothing in the schools is not that mentioned above, nor can it be, because the policy of keeping per capita grants down to the minimum has simply meant that, in order to make ends meet, the Churches have had to find large sums of money from their missionary budgets and at the same time to keep the maintenance of the schools at a lower standard than is desired.

With regard to the estimated cost of higher standards, - we beg to place before you the estimates prepared for the Committee by the officials of the Indian School Administration of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, which show that if salaries of teachers were to be raised $200.00; if an average increase of $10.00 were to be given to engineers, cooks, etc.; if 10 cents per day were to be added to the cost of diet; and if an increased staff of twelve were added to the whole of the Schools operated by that Church -- it would mean a total of $93,000, which is 27 per cent. on the present per capita grant.

The figures submitted by the representatives of The Woman's Missionary Society of The Presbyterian Church in Canada show that, for the period January 1st, 1946, to November 30th, 1947, for the maintenance of the work at two residential schools and at the Mistawasis day school, the Society has contributed $56,500.

The Church of England in Canada has already submitted to the Department figures showing how much it has contributed, in addition to the per capita grants, for the maintenance of its Indian Residential Schools.

The United Church of Canada in 1946 and 1947 spent, in addition to the per capita grants, an amount of $32,000 from its Missionary Funds. The figure is considerably lower than it normally would be because the Norway House Residential School was destroyed by fire in the middle of 1946 and has not yet been rebuilt.

We therefore request the Minister to consider some way of tying up grants which are being paid for the maintenance of these Schools to the increased cost of living, and that these grants be adjusted half-yearly. Specifically, we request that there be a special grant for 1947 so that the actual costs of operating the Schools may be met.

From the figures which we have submitted, there is no question that the increase in the cost of operation is far more than was estimated when the figures were being prepared for submission to Parliament. With a jump of 21.3 per cent. in the cost of food in the period - January 1st, 1947, to October 1st, and in the prices of other commodities accordingly, it is quite obvious that, if the Government does not come to the help of the Schools by making grants to cover this increased cost, it will have to be met out of the Missionary funds of the Churches, or else by making
further drastic cuts in the operation of the Schools, which simply cannot be faced.

The Committee further requests that, as a general policy, consideration be given to adjusting the per capita grant every half year so as to meet any increase in the cost of living. This might be done by making an examination of the expenditures of the Schools at the end of the first six months' period and a supplementary grant being paid, and the same thing being done at the end of the next six months. We feel that in a day of rapidly increasing cost of living, it is impossible for the Churches to bear the burden.

III. There are certain other matters which may be minor but which affect our operation of Schools, which we present for the attention of the Minister:

(a) Transportation of Pupils: The Act says that the Department "may" pay the cost of transportation of pupils to and from their homes, but we find that it is very difficult to get this item met. It is really thought that the Indians themselves should pay the amount necessary for the transportation of their children to their homes and back again to school — and many of them are able to meet this, — but, unfortunately, it is left to the Principal to collect this money and he has very little success. We think that this ought to be the responsibility of the Agent.

(b) Recruiting: We also believe that the onus for recruiting should be on the Agent and not on the Churches. We are quite prepared to cooperate to the fullest possible extent with the Department; but the law says that the children must go to school; it also lays on the Government, through the Indian Agent, the responsibility for enforcing attendance.

(c) Enforced Closing of Schools: There are cases in which Schools are closed, or attendance is seriously depleted, because of epidemics. The children are kept at home and not allowed to go to school, but the expenses of the school, apart from the actual expenditure on food, have to go on.

The same thing is true when a school is closed for a considerable time because of the need for major repairs, in which case the Church again has to bear the full brunt of the cost.

We would point out that, whilst it is an excellent principle that the Department should not be asked to pay for the education of children that are not actually in school, yet there are cases where the Churches have to keep the schools open even though the children may not be in attendance, and that works a hardship on the Church.

We believe that the Minister should have a wider latitude of authority so that he could authorize the payment of the grant where it is clearly proven that the lack of attendance is due to circumstances that are beyond the control of the Churches.

The representatives of the Churches would like again to thank the Minister, and everybody concerned, for the opportunity of presenting their case.

DEPUTY MINISTER

Increased Per Capita Grants for Indian Residential Schools -

Please find attached a submission to Treasury Board for the increased per capita grants previously approved by the Minister.

We have set out all the facts in the submission and have attached the following documents:

(a) Letter from Statistician of Prices Branch, Dominion Bureau of Statistics,

MINES AND RESOURCES

The Board had under consideration a memorandum from the Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources reporting:

"That there have been requests and delegations to me from the various denominations operating Indian Residential Schools that an increase be made in the per capita grants made to them for the conduct of such schools;

That their requests were that this increase should be based upon the increased costs of operating such schools in view of the rise in prices;

That Treasury and Education officials of the Indian Affairs Branch considered a sampling of the auditors' report upon these residential schools in order to derive the various items upon which the average residential school dollar is spent;

That the figures below are based on a sampling of twenty (20) residential schools across Canada and representing all four denominations:

Food ........................................... 36 cents
Light, Fuel and Water ......................... 9 cents
Clothing ....................................... 8 cents
Salaries ....................................... 50 cents
House Expenses and Sundries ................. 17 cents

That the Dominion Bureau of Statistics was then requested to calculate the cost increase index since January 1, 1947; based on the above breakdown of the residential school dollar;

That the Prices Branch, Dominion Bureau of Statistics, reported as follows:

"Further to our conversation and in reply to letter of December 15, we have calculated an index on the basis of the breakdown of the Residential School dollar over January, 1947, and this shows a cost increase of 17 per cent."

That the total sum included in our Main and Supplementary Estimates for 1947-48 for the payment of per capita grants to Residential Schools was $1,935,220.00;

That a 17% increase in these per capita grants would require an additional sum per fiscal year of $330,000.00.

It is, therefore, recommended that approval be given for the inclusion in the 1948-49 Supplementary Estimates of $330,000.00 for an increase in per capita grants to Indian Residential Schools.

The Honourable
The Minister of Mines and Resources
It is further recommended that the undersigned be authorized to pay, in addition to the already approved grants, this increased grant effective from 1 October, 1947, out of the monies at present on hand in Vote 182 because of the following facts:

(a) This Vote is at present in a sound position and funds are available for the payment of an extra $80,000.00 for the quarter ending December 31, 1947.

(b) As payments to Residential Schools are made at the end of each quarter, based on quarterly returns, payments can be made for the March 1948 quarter out of funds still available for 1947-48 and the balance from funds provided in the Main 1948-49 Estimates."

The Board concur in the above report and recommendation, and submit the same for favourable consideration.

Clerk of the Privy Council

An audit of the books and records of the above-noted organization for the fiscal (calendar) year ended December 31, 1947 reveals the following information:

(1) The Anglican Indian School Administration, 102 Bank St., Ottawa handles the accounting and administration of the following Anglican Indian Residential Schools: Carcross, Alert Bay, Aklavit, Whitefish Lake, Wabasca, Old Sun, Blood, St. Cyprian, Prince Albert, Elkhorn, Sioux Lookout, Shingwauk, Chapleau, Moose Factory, Fort George, Lac La Ronge and Gordon's. The Administration also handles the affairs of three Anglican Hospitals and two Missions.

(2) The firm of Welch, Anderson & Co., Chartered Accountants of Toronto have been employed as auditors. Audits were conducted regularly (quarterly) and one was made at the end of the fiscal (calendar) year. Annual financial statements were prepared by the audit firm and will be presented to the Administration in the near future.

(3) In the year ended December 31, 1947 the total expenditures for the 17 Indian Residential Schools and Head Office amounted to $440,135.00 (1). The per capita grant earnings for the same period was $337,344.63. The net difference (deficit) was $102,788.37 (1).

(1) The Administration also handles the accounts and administration of 3 Hospitals and 2 Missions. The total Head Office expense of $20,297.00 is included in the amount $440,135.00.
(4) The Residential school at Lac La Ronge was burned in February, 1947. Gordon's Residential School has been temporarily closed (July 1947) so that major repairs to the plumbing and heating equipment could be made.

(5) Statements prepared are as follows:

(a) Statement #1 - An analysis of per capita grant earnings and relative expenditures for the year ended December 31, 1947.

(b) Statement #2 - A comparative analysis of the Dollar cost per pupil and related information for the year ended December 31/47.

(6) The cost analysis is concerned only with the per capita grant earnings and the relative expenditures. Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

Re: Per Capita Allowances.

The increased per capita allowances from October 1st, 1947, were based on information obtained from the Dominion Bureau of Statistics and in setting the new rates effective from the date mentioned, per capita grant at each residential school was increased by 17%. For instance, in the case of the Chapleau Residential School, per capita allowance paid to this school as of October 1st, 1947 was $205.00. Owing to the 17% increase, the per capita rate at this school from October 1st, 1947 has been paid at the rate of $239.85.

In a letter dated May 5th, 1948 from the Dominion Bureau of Statistics it is stated that there has been an additional increase of 7% since October 1st, 1947. If the schools were allowed this rate it would mean 24% increase over the amount allowed them previous to October 1st, 1947. In the case of the Chapleau school this would mean they would be paid at the rate of $254.20 (24% additional to the rate of $205.00 which they were receiving previous to October 1st, 1947).

The provision of the 17% increase involved an additional expenditure of approximately $330,000.00 which will be included in the supplementary estimates for 1948-49 as authorized by P.C. 36/666 dated February 20th, 1948. To allow all residential schools 24% effective from April 1st, 1948 would involve an additional expenditure of $127,737.00.
In a telephone conversation on Friday, May 7th, Mr. Jackson mentioned the Church of England Schools and I prepared a statement showing what amount they would draw if they kept the enrolment at each school up to the authorized amount.

The expenditure for the calendar year 1947 as shown on the attached statement, was prepared from the reports of our own auditors.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Canon Dixon:

Please find attached a list showing the new per capita grants which will be made to the sixteen schools operated by the M. S. C. C.

You will note that considerable increases have been made in several of the schools and that the northern schools in particular have received large adjustments.

Based on fourteen schools (excluding Chapleau, Lac la Ronge and Gordon) our Auditor's statements indicate that your total 1947 expenditure amounted to $369,627.00. We have omitted Lac la Ronge and Gordon from these figures because they were closed during the 1947 calendar year.

Under the new rate you should have an income from these fourteen schools (at authorized enrolment) of $407,702.50. This should mean a surplus of $18,075.50.

It is realized that one of your problems is the operation of schools with enrolled pupilage less than those authorized. It is our intention to send a circular letter to all our field officials, impressing upon them the importance of assisting actively in the recruiting for residential schools. It is felt that this matter is one for the utmost co-operation between the Departmental and Church Officials. We will again remind our field officials of this fact. However, we would point out that if these schools operate on the same pupilage as last year a surplus of some $8,000.00 can be anticipated.

..... You
You will note that no reference has been made to the Chapleau Residential School in the above calculations. It is our feeling that this school should be closed at the end of June. Those children who cannot be looked after in day schools, can be accommodated at the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ontario, and at the Moose Fort Residential School. We understand that the dollar cost per pupil at this school during the 1947 year amounted to $339.35. This was based on an average attendance of 80, which is 20 under the authorized pupilage.

Yours sincerely,

BFN/RM
Ottawa, May 31, 1948.

Memorandum:

ACTING DEPUTY MINISTER

Increased Per Capita Grants.

On May 25, 1948, I sent to Dr. Keenleyside a submission to Treasury Board requesting $128,000.00 in additional funds for the increase of residential school per capita grants. This submission was approved and this sum was included in our Supplementary Estimates for 1948-49.

You will recall that this amount of $128,000 was arrived at by making adjustments in individual school grants. These adjustments were recommended by the officials of the Education Division and were based on

(a) latest auditors' reports,
(b) location of school and anticipated effect of increased freight rates,
(c) availability of farming land at school site,
(d) personal knowledge of local conditions at various schools.

Please find attached a statement (Appendix A) on these schools showing the rate of operation as revealed by the latest auditor's reports. You will recall that when we discussed this matter you felt that efforts should be made to get auditor's reports for every school. At that time 16 schools, due to their isolation, had not had auditor's reports.

Since then our Chief Treasury Officer reports that arrangements have been made to carry out audits in future in the
Roman Catholic Indian Residential Schools in the Lesser Slave and Fort Vermilion Agencies. As soon as Reverend Father Flourde, O.M.I returns to town, a meeting will be held with him to determine the best way of including the eleven other schools (all of which are R.C.) in future audits.

In the meantime it would be appreciated if we could have your direction as to whether the Minister would consider advising the denominations concerned as to the increases in per capita grants for which funds are now available. You will find attached as Appendix B a statement showing the new per capita grants recommended for each school.

MEMORANDUM TO MR. HOEY:

Referring to our telephone conversation of this afternoon, I am returning the statement marked Appendix "A" showing the operation of the Residential Schools as revealed by the latest auditors' reports. Also a statement marked Appendix "B" setting out the proposed new per capita grants recommended for each school.

You will recall that when this matter was last discussed by Colonel Neary and yourself with the Deputy Minister it was agreed that this additional grant was provided for the purpose of assisting only those schools which needed higher grants to cover the cost of operation. It should not be given to schools which were able to meet their expenses from the present grants.

The proposed new grants as set out in Appendix "B" would seem to include a number of schools where there is no evidence to indicate that such additional assistance is needed.

C.W. Jackson,
Director, Administration and Personnel.
Ottawa, August 16, 1948.

Memorandum:

ACTING DEPUTY MINISTER

Increased Per Capita Grants.

On May 25, 1948, I sent to Dr. Kenlayside a submission to Treasury Board requesting $125,000.00 in additional funds for the increase of residential school per capita grants. This submission was approved and this sum was included in our Supplementary Estimates for 1948-49.

You will recall that this amount of $125,000 was arrived at by making adjustments in individual school grants. These adjustments were recommended by the officials of the Education Division and were based on:

(a) latest auditors' reports,
(b) location of school and anticipated effect of increased freight rates,
(c) availability of farming land at school site,
(d) personal knowledge of local conditions at various schools.

Please find attached a statement (Appendix A) on these schools showing the rate of operation as revealed by the latest auditor's reports. You will recall that when we discussed this matter you felt that efforts should be made to get auditor's reports for every school, at that time 16 schools, due to their isolation, had not had auditor's reports.

Since then our Chief Treasury Officer reports that arrangements have been made to carry out audits in future in the
Roman Catholic Indian Residential Schools in the Lesser Slave and Fort Vermilion Agencies. As soon as Reverend Father Plourde, C.M.I., returns to town, a meeting will be held with him to determine the best way of including the eleven other schools (all of which are R.C.) in future audits.

In the meantime it would be appreciated if we could have your direction as to whether the minister would consider advising the denominations concerned as to the increases in per capita grants for which funds are now available. You will find attached as Appendix B a statement showing the new per capita grants recommended for each school.

Director.

Emil.

PRICE MOVEMENTS, NOVEMBER, 1948 (PRELIMINARY)

COST OF LIVING: The Dominion Bureau of Statistics cost-of-living index remained unchanged between October 1 and November 1, 1948 at 159.6. This interruption came after a series of 21 consecutive increases dating from January, 1947. The food index fell from 205.4 on October 1 to 204.7 on November 1 as declines in meats and vegetables overbalanced further increases in egg prices; other food groups showed no appreciable changes. The decline in foods exactly balanced small advances in four other budget groups. Home furnishings and services moved up from 165.1 to 166.0, clothing from 181.0 to 181.5, fuel and light from 128.8 to 129.0, and miscellaneous items from 124.4 to 124.6. The rent series is computed at approximately quarterly intervals and the next reckoning of the rent index will be for December 1; the latest figure is 121.6.

From August, 1939 to November 1, 1948, the increase in the cost-of-living index was 58.3 per cent.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Adjustments in Individual Residential School Per Capita Grants.

As decided in a recent conference in your office on per capita grants, we are carefully reviewing all residential school audit reports received here. I would recommend the following cases for increases for consideration by the Minister:

Kaskoose Residential School (R.C.)

This is our largest school with a pupilage of 306. Unfortunately, the last audit available until recently was made in October, 1946. The new audit report has been received and shows the following:

Present Per Capita (effective 1 January, 1948) ..... $239.85
Auditor's Report Cost per pupil per year
(1 October, 1946, to 30 September, 1948) ...... 220.52
Deficit ........................................... $2,263.19

Unfortunately, the auditor's statement of cost per pupil per year covers a 24 month period and does not reveal the present cost of feeding and clothing the children.

In a letter of December 13, the Principal of the School states as follows:

"With reference to the recent audited statement of this School, I wish to advise that in computing the deficit the outstanding account of $1,968.85 for rental and grading fees for the year 1947-48 only was taken into consideration."
A further outstanding account of $2000.00 for the current year, which is due and payable, was overlooked by mistake. The deficit should be computed as follows:

| Description               | Amount   |
|---------------------------|----------|
| Current                   | $2263.19 |
| Borrowed Loan             | 3000.00  |
| Rental & Grazing fees     |          |
| 1947-48                   | 1968.85  |
| Rental & Grazing fees     |          |
| 1948-1949                 | 2000.00  |

$9232.04

"In arriving at a new per capita grant for this School I would appreciate having the above figures taken into consideration."

In view of the above I would recommend that the present rate of $239.85 be increased by an amount of $15.15 per pupil to total $255.00 effective 1 January, 1948. The nearest school to Kamloops is St. George's (C.E.) at Lytton, B.C., now receiving $257.00 per pupil.

Shubenacadie Residential School (R.C.)

This school has an authorized pupilage of 160. The latest audit report shows the cost per pupil for the period 1 August, 1947, to 31 July, 1948, was $239.85. The present per capita rate effective 1 January, 1948, is $210.00.

As you are personally aware, this school is operated directly by the branch and does not come under the Oblate Marist or Jesuit Orders as is the case with our other R.C. schools. It has therefore no financial backing other than the per capita grant of the Department. Therefore I would recommend an increase in grant to $265.00 effective 1 January, 1948.

Fort George (R.C.) Residential School.

The first audit report on this school has just been received and covers the period 1 September, 1947, to 31 August, 1948. As you are probably aware, this is a church-owned school with 8 Indian, 9 Eskimo and 6 white pupils in attendance. The cost per pupil per year is shown by the auditor to be $824.85. However, in making his
report the auditor states that some of the factors for this very high cost per pupil are:

(a) The very low average attendance (16.85 pupils).

(b) Materials purchased for building and repairs amounted to $323.28 per pupil per year. Building supplies to the amount of $1519.57 were on hand as inventory. A large stock of food was also on hand.

(c) Construction during the period under review included a laundry house, a baking house, foundation for the school and some work on the chapel.

Therefore it is recommended that the per capita rate at this school be set at the same as that allowed the Fort George C.E. Residential School, namely $511.00 per pupil, effective 1 January, 1948. The present rate is $310.05.

Albany Residential School (H.C.)

The first audit report on this school has also been received and covers the period September 1, 1947, to August 31, 1948. It shows 75 pupils in attendance with an average of 62.2. The cost per pupil per year is $430.17. The present per capita rate is $310.05.

I would recommend that the new rate for this school be set at $411.00 which is the same amount allowed the Moose Factory C.E. Residential School. Unfortunately, the auditor was unable to isolate all costs in connection with this school as a small hospital is also operated in the same building by some of the same staff. I feel that the recommended rate of $411.00 would therefore be fair and reasonable.

Alert Bay Residential School (C.E.)

We have received strong representations with regard to increasing the per capita rate at this school. We are now paying a grant of $251.55 and the last audit report dated December 31, 1947, indicated an operating cost per pupil of $230.35. However, this was under the former Principal, who has now been replaced and our inspector's reports indicate that a much higher standard of clothing and food is now being provided. This inadequate food and clothing was the cause of much dissension under the former principal and it has undoubtedly
caused the M.S.C.C. a considerable expenditure to have conditions remedied. I would therefore recommend that the new rate for this school be set at $255.00, effective 1 January, 1948.

As other auditors' reports are received, similar recommendations will be passed for your consideration. To summarize therefore, I would recommend that you authorize payment of the following per capita grants effective 1 January, 1948:

| School            | Present Rate | Recommended Rate |
|-------------------|--------------|------------------|
| Kamloops (B.C.)   | $239.85      | $255.00          |
| Shubenacadie (N.S.) | $240.00     | $265.00          |
| Fort George R.C. (Que.) | $310.05    | $311.00          |
| Albany (Ont.)     | $310.05      | $311.00          |
| Alert Bay (B.C.)  | $251.55      | $255.00          |

Ample funds are available in our Vote to meet this additional expenditure.

We have received the increased living cost index figure from the Dominion Bureau of Statistics and will shortly be making a report concerning a cost of living increase in per capita grants to all schools.

Director.
January 14, 1949.

Kamloops Residential School (R.C.)

This is our largest school with a pupilage of 306. Unfortunately, the last audit available until recently was made in October, 1946. The new audit report has been received and shows the following:

| Present Per Capita (effective 1 January, 1948) | ... $239.85 |
| Auditor's Report Cost per pupil per year (1 October, 1946, to 30 September, 1948) | ... 220.52 |
| Deficit ........................................... | $2,263.19 |

Unfortunately, the auditor's statement of cost per pupil per year covers a 24 month period and does not reveal the present cost of feeding and clothing the children.

In a letter of December 13th, the Principal of the School states as follows:

"With reference to the recent audited statement of this School, I wish to advise that in computing the deficit the outstanding account of $1,968.85 for rental and grazing fees for the year 1947-48 only was taken into consideration."
A further outstanding account of $2,000.00 for the current year, which is due and payable, was overlooked by mistake. The deficit should be computed as follows:

| Description               | Amount   |
|---------------------------|----------|
| Current                   | $2,263.19|
| Borrowed Loan             | $2,000.00|
| Rental & Grazing Fees     |          |
| 1947-48                   | $1,968.85|
| Rental & Grazing Fees     |          |
| 1948-49                   | $2,000.00|

Total: $9,232.04

"In arriving at a new per capita grant for this School I would appreciate having the above figures taken into consideration."

In view of the above I would recommend that the present rate of $239.85 be increased by an amount of $15.15 per pupil to total $255.00, effective 1 January, 1948. The nearest school to Kamloops is St. George's (C.E.) at Lytton, B.C., now receiving $257.00 per pupil.

Shubenacadie Residential School (R.C.)

This school has an authorized pupilage of 160. The latest audit report shows the cost per pupil for the period 1 August, 1947, to 31 July, 1948, was $259.85. The present per capita rate, effective 1 January, 1948, is $240.00.

As you are personally aware, this school is operated directly by the Branch and does not come under the Oblate, Marist or Jesuit Orders as is the case with our other R.C. schools. It has, therefore, no financial backing other than the per capita grant of the Department. Therefore, I would recommend an increase in grant to $265.00, effective 1 January, 1948.

Fort George (R.C.) Residential School

The first audit report on this school has just been received and covers the period 1 September, 1947, to 31 August, 1948. As you are probably aware, this is a church-owned school with 8 Indian, 9 Eskimo and 6 White pupils in attendance. The cost per pupil per year is shown by the auditor to be $884.83. However, in making his report, the...
auditor states that some of the factors for this very high cost per pupil are:

(a) The very low average attendance (16.85 pupils).

(b) Materials purchased for building and repairs amounted to $323.28 per pupil per year. Building supplies to the amount of $1,519.37 were on hand as inventory. A large stock of food was also on hand.

(c) Construction during the period under review included a laundry house, a baking house, foundation for the school and some work on the chapel.

Therefore, it is recommended that the per capita rate at this school be set at the same as that allowed the Fort George C.E. Residential School, namely $511.00 per pupil, effective 1 January, 1948. The present rate is $310.05.

Albany Residential School (R.C.S.)

The first audit report on this school has also been received and covers the period September 1, 1947, to August 31, 1948. It shows 75 pupils in attendance with an average of $2.2. The cost per pupil per year is $430.17. The present per capita rate is $310.05.

I would recommend that the new rate for this school be set at $411.00 which is the same amount allowed the Moose Factory C.E. Residential School. Unfortunately, the auditor was unable to isolate all costs in connection with this school as a small hospital is also operated in the same building by some of the same staff. I feel that the recommended rate of $411.00 would, therefore, be fair and reasonable.

Alert Bay Residential School (C.E.)

We have received strong representations with regard to increasing the per capita rate at this school. We are now paying a grant of $251.55 and the last audit report, dated December 31, 1947, indicated an operating cost per pupil of $250.35. However, this was under the former Principal, who has now been replaced and our inspector's reports indicate...
that a much higher standard of clothing and food is now being provided. This inadequate food and clothing was the cause of much dissension under the former principal and it has, undoubtedly, caused the M.S.C.C. a considerable expenditure to have conditions remedied. I would, therefore, recommend that the new rate for this school be set at $260.00, effective 1 January, 1948.

As other auditors' reports are received, similar recommendations will be passed for your consideration. To summarize, therefore, I would recommend that you authorize payment of the following per capita grants, effective 1 January, 1948:

| School                  | Present Rate | Recommended Rate |
|-------------------------|--------------|------------------|
| Kamloops (B.C.)         | $239.85      | $255.00          |
| Shubenacadie (N.S.)     | 240.00       | 265.00           |
| Fort George R.C. (Que.) | 310.05       | 311.00           |
| Albany (Ont.)           | 310.05       | 311.00           |
| Alert Bay (B.C.)        | 251.55       | 260.00           |

Ample funds are available in our Vote to meet this additional expenditure.

We have received the increased living cost index figure from the Dominion Bureau of Statistics and will shortly be making a report concerning a cost of living increase in per capita grants to all schools.

Quarterly Report,
Babine Indian Agency,
December 31, 1946.

It is not the hardships of this country that make it difficult to hold good teachers but small matters such as slowness of pay when they first arrive and most of all the difficulty of securing needed school supplies. They order according to the "Bulletin" which is enthusiastically received, to find that what they consider the essential items of their requisitions are left off. It seems that it is easier to get a new school than half a dozen text books and this means long hours in the evening for a progressive teacher preparing material for the next day.

In the Babine perhaps more than anywhere, it will be a great day for Indian Education when our teachers are rated as Civil Servants without regard to institutions other than that required by our Act in respect to Protestants and Catholics.

James Coleman,
inspector of Indian Agencies,
In charge Babine Agency.

By Joseph M. Scott, Provincial Normal School, Calgary, Alta.

With Maps and Line Drawings by Lloyd Scott and Kathleen Mair.

In the pages of this new book, History, Geography, and Science meet to unfold the romantic story of the Canadian prairie lands for pupils of Grades V and VI.

It will be found equally useful whether the enterprise is the adopted technique or the traditional approach is still in use.

The following are among its outstanding features-

1. All material used was carefully tested with Grade V classes for interest, language difficulty and general suitability before it assumed final form. The word count is well within the bounds set by standard authorities for the grades in question.

2. The integration of history, geography and science broadens the basis of the content and leads the pupil to a more complete appreciation of life in our prairie lands both past and present.

3. Varied and stimulating activities are suggested at the end of each chapter.

4. Black and white sketch maps enable the pupil to fix the location of all features of the area as the story proceeds. Simplicity is the keynote of these maps which are specially drawn for use by children of 10 or 11 years of age.

5. Every illustration has definite value as a teaching device. The line drawings are the outcome of careful research on the part of the artist. They are authentic. In addition over eighty half-tone reproductions are used.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I am in receipt of a communication from the United Church authorities in the Montreal Conference, drawing my attention to a book, "Think-and-Do to accompany: Our New Friends," which is one of the Cathedral Basic Readers, and which I am advised has been sent for use in Indian Schools conducted under Protestant auspices - that is The United Church of Canada - in the Province of Quebec.

I want to say, first of all, that this is a very fine book but that it has in it certain passages which seem to me to be out of place, in their present form, in a school conducted under Protestant auspices to which children of that faith are sent. I should particularly draw your attention to p. 9. You will, I know, not misunderstand me when I say that such instruction should not be given to children in our schools -- not that we have any objection to children of the Roman Catholic faith going to mass; but simply that we feel that, if instruction is to be given to children concerning the forms in which the religious faith of their fathers finds expression, it should be given in that form and not in the form of another Church.

I feel that the circulation of these books in schools conducted under Protestant auspices is an error which needs only to be mentioned to be corrected by the withdrawal of the books from these schools.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Catholic Reader Series.

We have been receiving representations from Principals and Teachers of our Indian day and residential schools that the texts of the Corona Series in Grades One and Two are unsatisfactory for use with Indian children. This has been more seriously aggravated since the Department has been providing the Basic Reader Series for use in Protestant schools. This Series has been especially designed for use in Catholic schools by the Commission on American Citizenship of The Catholic University of America. The material of all the books centers around the social-religious life of the child in the home, neighbourhood, local community and nation. It provides him not only with interesting experiences similar to those which he himself has had but also with the types of conduct most in harmony with the teaching of faith and the ideals of the Christian life.

CATHEDRAL BASIC READERS.

This Series is an adaptation for use in Catholic schools of the Basic Readers, as already being provided to our Protestant Schools. This adaptation has been carried out, with ecclesiastical approval, by the Reverend Father J.A. O'Brien, of the University of Notre Dame.

Council authorized the payment of $100 to Mr. Totzke as Returning Officer and $100 to Mr. McLean for preparing the Voters' List at Yellowknife.

3. Resignation of Dr. Camsell as Commissioner of the Northwest Territories -

Council unanimously adopted the following resolution:

Resolved,

That the Northwest Territories Council records its profound regret that Dr. Charles Camsell has resigned as Commissioner of the Northwest Territories.

In the twenty-six years that Dr. Camsell has served on the Council and particularly during his more than ten years as Commissioner, he has made an outstanding contribution not only to public knowledge of the resources of the Northwest Territories but to their development as well. It was indeed fitting that he should play such a prominent part in the affairs of the land of his birth.

His Majesty the King and learned societies in Canada and other lands have honoured his distinguished efforts and ability.

The members of this Council join in paying tribute to their retiring colleague with the heartfelt wish that he may long enjoy
with health and contentment the fruits of his years of high achievement in the service of his country.

(i) Giant-Yellowknife Road

7. Travelling expenses of Rev. Maurice Flint

re preparation of Eskimo Grammar -

The Secretary explained that it had been decided to translate and publish a certain amount of literature in Eskimo syllabics. In addition to that Dr. Pack's Eskimo Grammar was revised and put in more modern form by Rev. Maurice Flint of Toronto who is an expert on the Eskimo language. It has been agreed to publish this in mimeographed form. This would be largely for white people to learn Eskimo. There is also an Eskimo lesson book prepared largely from data from Greenland to enable Eskimo children to learn English. Twenty-two pamphlets for the education of Eskimo will be completed in the syllabic. Mr. Flint is translating these for the Administration. He came to Ottawa about the grammar and about the other work and has submitted travelling expense accounts. It was agreed that they should be paid.

Consideration is also being given to paying Mr. Flint for the time he devotes to this translation work. It was explained that Mr. Flint is doing this work because he offered to do it and is very able. The Roman Catholic authorities who have a slightly different type of syllabics, have been told that if they want to go ahead with similar work they will receive the same consideration and treatment as Mr. Flint. A discussion followed regarding the honorarium to be paid Mr. Flint for his work on all these publications. It was agreed that a fair honorarium should be paid but the amount was not fixed. Stand.

8. Legislation -

(i) Amendment to the Ordinance to Prevent the Pollution of Running Streams

The Chairman explained that when Dr. Hayward was Medical Health
Officer at Aklovik he reported on the 14th January, 1946, that the police were having difficulty in enforcing his order to the owners of the local hotel in regard to dumping garbage and night soil into the river. It was doubtful whether they had the authority to enforce this order.

On the 19th February, 1946, the departmental solicitor advised that the Ordinance to Prevent the Pollution of Running Streams should be amended to give the medical health officer the necessary authority. The final draft of the proposed amendment gives the Medical Health Officer authority to issue such orders as he considers necessary. The amendment was approved in principle.

9. Education (Mackenzie District) -

(i) Verbal report of Mr. McKimmon,
School Inspector

The Chairman explained that it had been decided to do something about the matter of improving educational facilities in the Northwest Territories and the Administration succeeded in recruiting as School Inspector on its staff a man who has all the qualifications necessary for the job. The settlement of Yellowknife has been offered $150,000 to put in a school of opportunity and that will be one of Mr. McKimmon's first charges. He has an individual problem in each settlement, no two exactly alike, and in every case he will work with the Indian Affairs Branch to bring into existence whatever improvement is possible within the limits of the budget for that locality. It was thought that after his first trip to the Mackenzie District and the limited opportunities which he has had to observe conditions, it would be well to hear Mr. McKimmon's impressions on what he found there and his suggestions in a broad way as to what steps might be taken. In due course he will present a report which will be studied by Council but in the meantime the budget must be prepared as, in order to accomplish anything in the Northwest Territories, everything has to be started well in advance.

Mr. McKimmon said he appreciated very much the opportunity of meeting the members of Council. On August 10 he reached the Northwest Territories and spent two months investigating educational conditions in the north. He visited the tents of the natives along the Mackenzie River as far as Aklovik and one of the questions he asked was, "Did your wife attend a school?" He noticed that in every case where the mother had attended a school, conditions were much superior to those in settlements where the people had received no education. Mr. McKimmon was firmly convinced of the good effect of education in the life of the natives. He noticed that in many of the schools there was very little equipment and practically no library facilities; that the certification of teachers ranged from Grade VII standing to First Class. In other words, one of the things that impressed him was the lack of uniformity. He noticed that some of the schools used Canadian Readers which were in use thirty years ago; the Alberta curriculum is used in some schools and none at all in others.

Mr. McKimmon recommended that an Office of Education be set up where education would be co-ordinated and unified; that a grant of $7 per pupil be paid; that a salary of $1,500 per teacher be provided as this is the salary paid by Indian Affairs Branch throughout Canada; that $50 per class room be provided as a library grant; that a radio be provided for each class room; that a film library be set up, and that a qualified educationist be appointed as his assistant. The estimated pupilage of the Mackenzie District would be 2,000 children of school age and it is absolutely impossible for one man to attempt to give the services which are required at the present time.

Considerable progress has been made at Fort Norman, Fort Rae, and Hay River on an agreement made between the Northwest Territories Administration and Indian Affairs Branch. Plans have been made to open three temporary schools until the situation is clarified and it is known just what will be needed in various areas. The arrangement is that Indian Affairs will pay the
teachers' salaries and pay for textbooks, desks, and equipment; the cost will be taken on a pro rata basis between Indian Affairs Branch and the Northwest Territories Administration. There were some 70 children of school age at Fort Norman and the residents were very anxious for some type of education. The older boys and girls mentioned the idea of adult education and asked if classes could be given in the evenings. At Fort Rae the residents submitted a petition requesting a school. They plan to have a temporary school but the School Inspector would advocate this only as a temporary measure. A residential school will be needed ultimately.

He was convinced the schools at Fort Norman and Rae must be residential schools in the future because the Indians and Eskimos are both nomadic and that is the only way educational facilities could be provided for them. These views are endorsed by Bishop Trocillier, Bishop Fleming, and the residents in these various areas. There is also some talk of Fort Rae becoming a port when the mining development takes place in that area and that may be another factor in support of setting up an appropriate residential school there.

Mr. Gibson explained that the chief reason why there has not been more done in the past at this point is that it is generally believed that Rae is situated on a very poor site where there is poor water and everything has been against it. Even with the amount of business going up to the Slave River through Rae, it is found to be a very difficult place. Mr. McKinnon and Mr. Meikle looked for a site and there was only one where a residential school could possibly be built. It was planned to have temporary schools at Rae, Fort Norman, and Hay River, sometime in the near future. The one at Hay River would be in the old residential school. The residents there are in need of education and are very concerned about it; they have presented a petition.

Mr. McKinnon inspected educational facilities at Fort Smith. He had a talk with Mr. Capell the Secretary of the Public School, and there was a deficit of $687.20 owing to the Hudson's Bay Company from the previous year and the teacher's salary coming due. Fort Smith emphasizes the fact that the Administration's financial policy towards the Northwest Territories has to be revised within certain limits and Mr. McKinnon has tried to make arrangements in the 1947-48 Estimates whereby that will be done. In the meantime the Fort Smith Public School is in vital need of financial assistance and he recommended the grant be increased from $700 to $1,000 to take care of this special emergency and that the residents carry on as in the past until such time as the Administration's policy goes into effect. Council approved of increasing the grant to the Fort Smith Public School effective January 1, 1946.

The School Inspector noticed that the classes are too large. At Akavik the teacher had 76 children and 30 of them were non-English. One teacher was teaching as many pupils as the four teachers were at Yellowknife last year. Allowance will have to be made in the future for smaller classes in order to obtain greater efficiency.

In his 1947-48 Estimates Mr. McKinnon has made allowances for $1,600 for a teacher's average salary based on qualifications and experience; for an Office of Education—office rent, $50 a month; supplies $600; equipment $750, total $1,950—an educational library containing books and periodicals, $200; film projecting outfit to screen pictures before sending them to schools, $1,000; the salary of a supervisor of training, $3,000-$3,600; a stenographer $1,200. In his estimates he tried to make a very modest and small beginning in certain special projects—$50 per class room for a library, $1,400; 24 radios at $50 each, $1,200; $500 as a beginning in adult education; $250 for correspondence courses; $250 for handicrafts; home economics $500 in certain selected areas; manual training $500 in certain areas; and $2,500 for beginning teachers' institutes. The total for special projects is $7,100, half of which should be paid by the Northwest Territories Administration and the remainder by Indian Affairs Branch.

If possible, allowance should be made in the estimates for educational facilities at Good Hope where there are about 60 children of school age and also at Arctic Red River as the residents are alarmed about
the lack of educational facilities. Council decided that in addition to those two points the matter of opening a school at Fort Franklin be investigated and action taken to meet the needs.

In order to bring about the reorganization of education and extend existing facilities, the sum of $45,000 has been included in the 1947-48 Estimates for the Government of the Northwest Territories under the following consolidated headings:

Grants......................................................... $34,150
Printing and Stationery........................................... 500
Supplies and Materials.......................................... 3,555
Travelling Expenses.............................................. 3,000
Freight, Express, Telegrams, Postage, etc.................... 350
Equipment, Maintenance and Repairs............................. 2,625
Sundries.................................................................. 820

Total............................................................... $45,000

Owing to conditions existing in the Territories it may not be possible to confine expenditures as indicated above. Council, therefore, agreed that whatever reallocation is needed to meet requirements should be carried out.

At this point in the proceedings Mr. MacKinnon was asked if he was of the opinion that the Administration should pay the salaries of all teachers in the Territories. He replied that this should be the policy with the exception of those within organized school districts. Council concurred.

It was reported that the Indian Affairs Branch have a proposal before Cabinet Council to make all teachers of Indian day schools permanent Civil Servants. A new salary schedule has been worked out and the teachers will contribute to the superannuation fund. Grants to Indian schools are also being substantially increased this year. The Northwest Territories Council expressed the opinion that the teachers appointed to the main settlements of the Territories should be full-time Civil Servants and responsible to the school inspectors. The matter of setting up appropriate positions is to be dealt with as soon as possible.

It was agreed that the Administration should buy equipment, modern textbooks, etc., as needed and be reimbursed on a pro rata basis by the Indian Affairs Branch. It was also agreed by Council that wherever children of a school or a community desire to purchase a motion picture projector for educational purposes, the Northwest Territories Administration will contribute 50% of the cost either from the Territorial Liquor Fund or the Administration Vote.

They will also employ temporarily at $75 per month, the wife of one of their employees who is a qualified teacher. Later the company intend to provide a new school building and employ a qualified teacher on a full-time basis. The school will be operated in accordance with the regulations.

10. Eastern Arctic Matters -

(i) Appeal to Privy Council from the ruling of the Supreme Court that Eskimos in Quebec are Indians

Stand.

(ii) Use of poison on wolves by trapper at Eskimo Point

The Secretary explained that D.C. Turner, a trapper at Eskimo Point who is an ex-R.C.M.P. Policeman and well versed in the law, found that wolves were taking about one-half his fur catch. He set out poison around his traps in an attempt to reduce the number of wolves. He was arrested and tried last summer before a Justice of the Peace. He was fined $3 but immediately wrote out an appeal, his object being to force to the attention of the Administration the necessity of doing something to control the wolves. He wants the law modified to permit responsible trappers to poison wolves or, failing that, he wants the government to employ paid wolf exterminators.

The wild life authorities were consulted and said nothing could economically be done to reduce the wolf population in such an extensive area as the cost would probably exceed the value of the fox catch. Poison cannot be permitted owing to danger to other wild life. He has appealed but has paid no deposit in this connection.

It was suggested that the trapper in question be informed of the views of the wild life authorities in regard to wolf control and that any further use of poison by him may result in the cancellation of his trapping licence. He might be advised that since no deposit accompanied his appeal it is doubtful if it would be entertained by a stipendiary magistrate. He may wish to withdraw his appeal.

Re: Education in the Eastern Arctic.

The problem of education in the Eastern Arctic is very complex. The thinly scattered population, the transportation difficulties over great distances, the nomadic habits of the natives, the necessity for Eskimo children to learn the native way of life, the frequent changes in the personnel of the white population and, to some extent, the language and religious question, all have a bearing on the subject.

White Education

The white population numbers about 150 comprised of doctors, nurses, weather and radio station attendants, Royal Canadian Mounted Police, missionaries, traders and trappers. The majority of these people seldom remain longer than three years in the country without a furlough. Some missionaries remain longer and a few white trappers may remain indefinitely. The distribution of white children or those of mixed blood desiring education in English is approximately as follows:

- Lake Harbour: 5
- Chesterfield: 5
- Pangnirtung: 3
- Port Harrison: 5
- Pond Inlet: 1
- Southampton Island: 1
- Moffet Inlet: 2
- Eskimo Point: 2
- Fort Ross: 4
- Term Point vicinity: 10

A Total of 38

Of the above, 10 are infants under school age and the parents may move out before the children reach school age. There are, therefore, roughly 25 white or mixed blood children of school age widely scattered in the Eastern Arctic. Most of these children follow the correspondence courses supplied by one or other of the provinces and where the parents devote sufficient attention to teaching them, many of these children are said to be unusually well advanced for their age. Last summer I received requests for Ontario Department of Education correspondence courses from the following families:

- Mr. (Foxey) Brown, Rankin Inlet -
  Sons aged 7 and 1
  Daughters aged 16, 14, 10, 5, 3.

- Mr. Ernie Lyle, Fort Ross -
  Children aged 9, 6, 4, 3.

Arrangements will be made to have the courses supplied by the Department.

When the Patrol was at Chesterfield Cpl. Corey informed me that there are several white trappers and independent traders along the west coast of Hudson Bay centering at Term Point who intend to live permanently in the country and want a school for their children. There are also some well-to-do natives in this region who would be prepared to pay to send their children to school. Cpl. Corey thinks there should be a government residential school near Term Point where at least 15 children would attend.

I had a discussion with Father Fafard at Chesterfield in regard to education of both white and native children on the west coast. He said that in the Chesterfield region 95% of the population were Roman Catholic and that as far south as Eskimo Point over 50% of the population were Roman Catholic. He did not favour anything but separate schools or religious schools on the west coast. Father Fafard is, I think, more or less satisfied with the day school education they are giving the Eskimo and does not seem to be enthusiastic about starting a residential school. They would have to erect a building. I have no
information as to the religion of the group of whites and those of mixed blood who want a residential school at Term Point but it should be noted they request a government school.

Owing to transportation difficulties I can see no way of educating the scattered white children in the Eastern Arctic except by correspondence which has, so far, worked satisfactorily. The one exception might be the group on the west coast of Hudson Bay but it seems doubtful if the school could be run for 15 children only.

Eskimo education

There are only two residential schools for Eskimo in the Eastern Arctic both operated by missions at Fort George. The Roman Catholic mission has an average attendance of 8 Eskimo and the Church of England has 6. We pay these schools an annual grant of $200 per pupil.

The missions operate day schools at the following points which are attended by Eskimo children when they are in the vicinity:

| Location       | Religion | Average Attendance | Annual Government Grant |
|----------------|----------|--------------------|-------------------------|
| Eskimo Point   | R.C.     | 7                  | $250                    |
| Eskimo Point   | C. of E. | 33                 | $250                    |
| Chesterfield   | R.C.     | 21                 | $250                    |
| Baker Lake     | R.C.     | 14                 | $250                    |
| Baker Lake     | C. of E. | 6                  | $250                    |
| Igloolik       | R.C.     | 22                 | $250                    |
| Mistake Bay    | R.C.     | 6                  | $250                    |
| Total          |          | 108                |                         |

Funds have been provided in the Estimates for grants to day schools at a number of other points but hitherto there has not been sufficient attendance of children for a long enough period to warrant the schools being operated except at brief intervals.

There is considerable difference of opinion amongst the white residents in the north as to how much education should be given the Eskimo and how it should be provided. Some of the missionaries, of course, insist on religious schools. Those laymen who recommend education for the Eskimo want government schools. Some do not think the Eskimo should be given much education or he will become dissatisfied with his lot. There is little but the fur trade to support him in the north and he would have a hard time competing with whites outside. Practically all agree that any education given should be provided in the north and that it would be a grave mistake to transport native children any distance from their homes for education since they rapidly become unfitted for the native way of life. This has been amply demonstrated in the case of children brought outside for hospitalisation.

I have discussed this subject with many people in the north and the following seems to be the consensus of opinion of those best informed:

1. Education of the Eskimo should be designed to equip him to meet changing conditions in the north but should not make him discontented.

2. He should be taught English, as opportunity offers, so that he can read published matter.

3. He should learn simple arithmetic, hygiene, animal conservation, and the use and care of such white man's equipment as he needs.

4. His morale must be sustained and the development of any race inferiority complex avoided. The pride of race which he still has should be fostered.
and instruction in suitable folk lore should be encouraged. This is rapidly disappearing under missionary instruction.

5. Pending instruction in schools, much can be done to educate the Eskimo by supplying him with suitable pamphlets in syllabic. Nearly all Eskimo are literate in their syllabic script. Such pamphlets are now in the course of preparation.

6. When the Eskimo has been grounded in hygiene and sanitation, it may be possible to allow him to live in portable fabricated houses. There are already requests by well-to-do natives to purchase such houses but they would introduce a danger to health at present.

7. Medical health centers, operated by the government, should be the basis of all improvement in native welfare. Such a health center could be staffed by a man and his wife skilled in first-aid, who would prescribe for patients under radio advice. Some young natives would be employed and taught hygiene, infant feeding, and care of the sick. These would be charged from time to time and new ones taken on to learn while the older ones carried their knowledge back to the native camps. Under-nourished and ailing children would be nursed back to health at the centers. Reading, writing and arithmetic, and other useful subjects could also be taught at these centers and the Eskimo Grammar and book of Eskimo Lessons which we are preparing would prove valuable here.

8. Any children who showed marked promise at these centers could be taken outside for higher education and fitted to carry on work at the medical centers, hospitals, weather and radio stations, etc. No child should be taken out until he is at least 14 years old and he should be returned to his people for a month or two each year so he would not forget the native language and way of life.

Frankly, I can see no other suitable way than the above whereby we can begin the education of the Eskimo. It is, of course, closely linked up with the medical health programme but, as in most efforts in the north, the cooperation of all interested parties is essential. I think we should urge the Department of National Health and Welfare to proceed along the line of providing health centers and offer our cooperation in the matter of education. I doubt if a policy could be laid down in time to do much in the coming year and for this reason I have not recommended anything extra in our Estimates.

(sgd.) J. G. Wright.
Ottawa, April 5th, 1947.

Dear Doctor Palmer:

Re: Wetzel Grid

In a co-operative effort, the Indian Affairs Branch Training Division and Indian Health Services are going to introduce the Wetzel Grid method of recording growth and development into Residential Schools.

The initial trial will be made at the Mohawk Institute, a very important factor being your special interest in children.

No doubt you are familiar with the Wetzel technique but we are enclosing samples and literature from which you will easily see the method. Supplies of cards are being sent to Rev. Mr. Zimmerman.

While much of the recording can be done by the Institute staff it has been the general experience that it is very difficult for lay persons to do this work without professional supervision and it is our hope that you will assist Mr. Zimmerman in keeping this record.

We would be most interested in having your comments on the progress of this experiment and your recommendation about expanding the system into other schools.

Yours very truly,

Dr. H. L. Palmer,

On board the S.S. "Ariguani".

Dear Reader,

I am writing this letter on board the 6,746 ton ship "Ariguani" which is now more than half way on her 13-day voyage from Avonmouth, the port of Bristol in England, to the West Indies. The reason I am on the ship is because I am going to travel round the West Indies seeing everything possible by land, sea and air, and then I shall write personal letters to you, like this one, describing how people in these parts live. I expect you know that men and women who go abroad and write for newspapers or magazines are called foreign or special correspondents. Well, that is what I am - a special correspondent for young people in clubs, in school, or at home - in short your own foreign correspondent. I hope to describe the things about other countries that you really want to know - about the people, their homes and children, their games and food, their songs and flowers, their animals and birds and their way of getting around - in fact I hope to show you that they are people similar to those you know, but with all those little differences which make travel exciting and worth while.

I am very pleased at the opportunity of doing this trip for you. It is so thrilling to be setting off in the direction which so many explorers and travellers have taken, and if I come across traces of Drake or Magellan, Columbus or Cortes, I shall be sure to let you know.

In the lounge of this ship there is a chart which shows the Atlantic Ocean, on which there is pencilled a line marking the route the ship is taking. If you want to follow it, draw a pencil line from Bristol to the Azores in the middle of the ocean, then from the Azores to Barbados and from Barbados to Trinidad.

The first night of the voyage, after we had been about three hours at sea, I was sitting in the lounge when suddenly I saw a large red light floating past the porthole. I ran on deck, and looking
climbed down a ladder from our ship into the pilot ship, and all our officers leaned down and called out goodbye messages, and then the pilot ship turned and steamed away very quickly. As she turned I saw her name painted on the stern "Queen Mary".

Our ship, the "Ariguan" (the name of a river in South America) is a small, but very comfortable cargo vessel, having only one funnel which is painted banana yellow and black. I share a cabin with three other people. The cabin has four bunks, two on either side, two portholes, four wardrobes for our clothes, a wash-hand-stand-cum-dressing table, a chair and a long mirror.

Each of the bunks has a reading lamp at its head, and we have a thermos jug of iced water and an electric fan for use in the hot weather. The ship has a pleasant dining saloon and three sitting rooms, but most people prefer to sit on deck. At the beginning of the voyage we wrapped ourselves in coats and rugs and used the long, comfortable chairs, but now we have reached warmer waters, we are wearing shorts, cotton frocks and sun-glasses.

There are four games which people can play on deck, shuffleboard, deck tennis, deck golf and quoits. Shuffleboard is played by pushing circular wooden disks into numbered spaces with a long pole which has a kind of wooden hoe at the end of it. The game is rather like shove-halfpenny, but on a larger scale. Deck tennis is similar in rules and scoring to lawn tennis, but is played on a smaller scale by throwing a rope twist instead of hitting a ball with a racquet. Deck golf is played by pushing a numbered disc round the deck with a pole like that used for shuffleboard, but in the place of the holes on a golf course, chalk circles are drawn on the deck. For quoits a board, similar to an archery target is marked on the deck, and the idea is to try to throw rope rings into the numbered spaces. Many different games are arranged

for the evenings, and there is also a library on board.

Among the 128 passengers there are 40 children, as well as 5 babies under one year old who do not count at all. The older children join in all the ship's sports, but the smaller ones rush, stagger and crawl everywhere.

Before dinner every evening, I have a bath. It is rather an unusual sort of bath, too, as it is full of clean, hot salt water, and balanced across it there is a plank on which rests a basin full of fresh water. You soap yourself with the fresh water, because salt water will not produce a lather, and then rinse off with the salt. It is rather odd lying in the bath, because as the ship rolls gently from side to side, the water stays straight, and the bath does not.

The food is very good, and well cooked. Tea is served to everybody together in the lounge, but all the other meals are served in two shifts, the people with children having to go to the first sitting. We have ice-cream for dinner every day, and there is usually some kind of dessert in the form of a banana, apple or orange. The first two look quite normal, but the oranges, although quite ripe, are bright green, and I am told people often eat them like this in the West Indies.

Unfortunately we passed the Azores at night, and at first we could only see the distant flash of a lighthouse, but soon the little twinkly lights of a small town appeared. While I was admiring these, I noticed that the whole sea was also full of little twinkling lights, only these did not stay alight, but just flashed as the sea moved. They were formed by phosphorus, which is only found when the sea gets warmer.

Nine days out of Avonmouth the sky cleared, the temperature rose and the sea became a very dark blue, with here and there floating pieces of ginger-coloured weed. This is called Sargassum weed or Gulf weed, and is found in the sea is usually called the Sargasso Sea, but which is really not a sea at all, but a sort of backwash of the Gulf Stream, where all the weed collects. We also saw flying fish which are very much smaller than I had imagined - in fact they are rather like martins or swallows as they have white or silvery bellies, and they skim or dart over the water. They come out in the cool of
