the morning and evening.

The Chief Engineer, a Belfast man, thinking you might be interested, invited me to see the engine room. It is a very high room, and, as we entered, we were met by a blast of hot air, which of course, always rises to the top, but we had three ladders to go down, and, using dusters to protect our hands from the heat of the rails of the ladders, we found when we reached the floor it was much cooler - only 105 degrees. There was also a cool air shaft under which we could have a shower bath of cool air! In the engine room are the Glasgow-made triple expansion engines which drive the twin screws. I met the three trimmers and five firemen who keep the boilers going. I saw the machines which work the water system, and the extra machine which is used for making clear water out of salt, if supplies of clear water run short. Here too, was the refrigeration plant which keeps the provisions fresh for the voyage, and will preserve the bananas which the ship will take home on her return journey from the West Indies.

It will not be long now before we pass Barbados, where we shall not stop, and so my next letter will be written from Trinidad.

Sincerely yours,

Bridget Moss

Deformed bones, anaemia, skin affections, goitre, sore eyes, loss of weight, digestive disturbances and even milder unnoticed conditions may occur in humans as a result of the food they eat—or don't eat.

5. Meat and Fish—One serving of meat, fish, poultry or meat alternates, such as beans, peas, nuts, eggs or cheese. Also use eggs and cheese at least three times a week each, and liver frequently.

A fish liver oil, as a source of vitamin D, should be given to children and expectant women, and may be advisable for other adults.

Iodized salt is recommended.

2. Start A School Lunch

This makes it easier for all the children in the neighborhood to eat the above foods regularly.
Making One Food Do For Another

MILK—Nothing can conveniently replace milk and milk products in our Canadian diet.

FRUITS AND VEGETABLES—The important nutritional value in fruits is vitamin C, and this is richest the year round in citrus fruits. Money to purchase these for children is available from family allowances. Tomatoes are also those season. Berries in season are good. When fruits are difficult to obtain, your vitamin C may partially come from using vegetables, either raw or carefully cooked, especially potatoes, cabbage, kale, string beans, broccoli, turnips, peas, spinach.

CEREALS—If you eat more than half your cereals as refined ready-to-eat breakfast foods and white bread (except Canada Bread) rather than whole grains you will have difficulty making up the vitamin and mineral lost in milling.

MEAT OR ALTERNATE—A small amount will provide your absolute needs even if it does not satisfy you. See Canada's Food Rule No. 5. Cereals also provide protein and make the meat go farther.

FATS, SUGARS, AND EXTRAS like pickles, add palatability to meals, but not much food value except energy.

Food values are easily lost in storage and preparation, such as cutting, shredding and peeling. Overcooking or high temperatures, standing, and whipping, also reduce the food value. So serve fresh and raw with no delay, where possible.

Many good sources of information are available, such as the booklet "Healthful Eating", free from your Provincial Health Department.

Dear Sir:

Requisitions Nos. 27474 - 27454 - 27457.

Our records show that Requisition No. 27474 was dated April 25th, 1947. It was clearly marked for delivery to "Redwood Dock, Winnipeg, Man., by May 24th, 1947". We have now received your Delivery Records which indicate that shipment was made on May 23rd. Therefore, it is most unlikely that it would reach its destination on time.

Another instance is of Requisition No. 27454 for the Jack River C. E. Day School. This Requisition was dated April 23rd, 1947, and your Delivery Records indicate that it was only sent out by O. N. Freight on the 23rd of May; yet we specially requested that it should arrive at the Selkirk Navigation Company's docks in Winnipeg about May 24th.

Still another instance is of Requisition No. 27457 for the Little Grand Rapids United Church Day School. This requisition is dated April 24th and was clearly marked to reach Winnipeg by May 24th. Your Delivery Record shows that it left Ottawa on May 28th.

This year we have had many complaints from our teachers in the North about the non-arrival of supplies. This is especially serious in the case of day schools where there will be no teacher to accept delivery of school material during the summer. These parcels lie around while the school is closed and are often broken into, with a resulting loss of many items.

It would be appreciated if every effort could be made to have requisitions which have a delivery date marked on them given a priority. We are making every effort here to speed up delivery of supplies for these northern schools and hope that you will be able to do the same.

Yours truly,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Dear Sir:

Catechism Survey.

The problem of catechism manuals has been studied by the whole staff. We are of the opinion that the teaching of religion in classrooms depends on the organisation and modernization of our methods. Religion should benefit of the modern pedagogy as applied to secular matters viz:

- Induction: the manual of catechism is no more the starting point but a reference book.
- Activities: according to modern methods and tests.
- Unit system: divided in the 40 weeks. Quantity and importance taking the place of quality of tests to memorize.
- Gradation: age and grade being considered throughout the whole curriculum.
- Cycles: to cover progressively and under new angles the same matter according to the evolution of the mind and the needs of each age.
- Attractive texts and methods.

This called for an elaborated program set for the whole school as well as for each grade. A program which gives to the teacher the weekly details, the references to Bible, History, Liturgy etc. Of course such teaching requires more than a manual to be memorized and explained as it was done in the past.

In our school, we gave away the use of the old little manual of catechism furnished by the Department. We replaced it by "Catholic Faith" by Kirsch in three graded books. This book has a good wording, presentation, activities and tests. But it can be used only for references or for memorization. It cannot be the base of whole course of religion for nine years.

We must admit that "Father McGuire's New Baltimore Catechism No I and Dr. Horan Baltimore Catechism No I present a real improvement on the old manuals and can be of good use in many school especially day schools. We still use here the catechism by Kirsch for reference book and use the textbook for the reduced memorization required."
Indian Residential School

Lebret, Saskatchewan

We have adopted, for the time being, the course of the Diocese of Chicago by Schorsch, for the Grade II, III, IV, V. It gives us the framework of our organization in unites. Furthermore each teacher is given, for every weekly unit, a number of references in suitable books in order to make good use of the Bible, Liturgy and History as a base of induction.

For the higher grades (VI, VII, VIII), we give the teacher the three books of Bailerl, supplemented for activities, induction etc., with other reference books.

We are still receiving from the Department a very old fashioned manual for Bible study, I mean Gilmour's. Its vocabulary and presentation are not in accordance with modern pedagogy. In the past years we tried in vain to get, from the Department, the more up-to-date manuals of Johnson-Hannon or Newton's.

As for the Grade I, we have abandoned the idea of giving the children a textbook. It is only after many months that they can read it. The nice little manual "My First Communion Catechism" can be used only at the end of the year. These young children who are preparing themselves for first communion, learn by hearing their teacher telling them the Bible story, and the whole process is based on induction: story-telling, pictures discussions, projections, projects, drawing etc. No textbook is used for the memorization required from them. Full initiative is left to the Primary grade Teacher. This is more or less the attitude we have with Grade II also.

In brief, this is our standing:

1. Schorsch—a course in religion—gives us the framework for Grade II, III, IV, V. We do not say that it is the best author but it has a good value. We did not have the opportunity of comparing it with Fitzpatrick's "Highway to Heaven" and to "The Kingdom of God" by Newton-Harran.

2. In Grade I, the children do not use books but the teacher finds the proper didactic material for inductive teaching.

3. Bailerl's books are used by the senior boys and girls with Johnson's Bible history books which are far superior to the old and inadequate Gilmour's Bible.

4. All the other adaptations of Baltimore can be good but we find that they will always prove to be inadequate for a whole program of religious teaching during a period of 7 or 9 years. They are poor and feeble remedies to a great mistake in religious pedagogy which should not be different of profane pedagogy.

We do not expect that the Department will consider giving all the books mentioned; Schorsch-Fitzpatrick-Harran...but the teacher at least, should be supplied with them. And the pupils should have Johnson's Bible instead of Gilmour's.
McGuire's and Horen's improved text, is a progress and many teachers will consider it to be superior to McGuire's.

Hoping that your Catechism Survey will be a success,

I am,

Yours very truly,

P. Piche O.M.I.
St. Catherine's Indian Day School,
Duncan, B.C.,
June 18, 1947.

Bernard F. Neary,

Dear Mr. Neary,

Re: CATECHISM SURVEY

1) For the past three years we have been using "Father McGuire's New Baltimore Catechism #1."

For the first year we had a rather difficult time as the children found the wording quite difficult and it took much patience and time to get them to understand how the study sections were worked. Last year they did well, but this year they have handled them almost as well as any white child. I am now speaking of Grades 5 to 8. The Study sections (answer these questions in your notebook or on a sheet of paper as your teacher may direct) have proven very developing in English for Grades 6, 7, and 8. Grade 5 have a hard time to couch the answer into good English.

2) Baltimore Catechism #1 (Dr. Horan)

Since the word content of the questions and answers are the same as in Father McGuire's Catechism the children had no difficulty. They found the Study Exercises most simple. I found that the illustrations had more appeal for them and were more readily understood than those in the McGuire's Catechism.

Personally I like the lay-out of the Horan's Study Exercises. They are less congested. This along with the fact that the children had already worked on the McGuire's for three years was the reason they found the Horan Catechism so simple. They rarely made a mistake on any exercise assigned.
3) My First Communion Catechism.

This is a splendid little book. We find that many of the words are far beyond the Indian child's comprehension e.g., serve (God), quarrel, allowed, offered, satisfy for sin, gain (heaven), but the illustrations are so appealing that they do the greater part of the explaining to the child mind. The majority of our Indian children in this district have a very, very meagre comprehension of the English language. Many can read like parrots, but lack the reading comprehension.

Very truly yours,

Sister Mary Sheila

Principal.

Dear Sir:

We are proud to announce the forthcoming appearance of a work of first importance, Taylor-Seiveright-Lloyd: CANADA AND HER NEIGHBOURS. This book will be published in August in time for school opening.

CANADA AND HER NEIGHBOURS approaches the regional study of Canada from the standpoint of the occupations of the people who inhabit the regions. This text tells how the daily life of people in a given region is influenced by geography, and how the people, in turn, have modified the geographical aspect of their communities.

CANADA AND HER NEIGHBOURS will be an outstanding book. The text is being printed by offset process which will enhance the illustrations, sixteen of which will be printed in four colours. Eight pictures representative of Canadian life have been painted especially for this book. Copious use is made of photographs that teach. Many of these photographs have been taken expressly for use in CANADA AND HER NEIGHBOURS.

New physical maps of Canada in full colour, drawn by Richard Edes Harrison, will be a feature of CANADA AND HER NEIGHBOURS. In addition, there will be six double-page regional maps, and more than seventy single-purpose black-and-white maps. Some are drawn by Erwin Raizs.

The manuscript has been used experimentally and revised in the light of classroom experience. As a result, CANADA AND HER NEIGHBOURS meets the needs and interest of pupils in the elementary grades.

Professor Griffith Taylor is head of the Department of Geography, University of Toronto. Miss Dorothy Seiveright, Macdonald College, McGill University, has had long and successful experience both as an author and as teacher of geography and methods. Dr. Trevor Lloyd, formerly of the Winnipeg Public Schools, is an outstanding Canadian geographer, and one who has had wide teaching experience.

CANADA AND HER NEIGHBOURS is a book that will broaden rather than limit the Social Studies programme. It is so written that it provokes pupil-participation through questions, varied things to do, and informal stories. We are sure your pupils will profit immeasurably through its use. An order form has been enclosed for your convenience.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Neary:

Yesterday afternoon, just as we were closing, I got the copy of the letter you sent to Mr. Driscoll regarding our "Living Language" series, and this morning I have a copy of your second letter regarding the "Faith and Freedom" readers.

It is, of course, tremendously pleasing to me that you have decided to use these books of ours. I honestly think you are making no mistake. "Living Language" has been prepared with a special eye to situations such as you have in the majority of Indian schools.

It is also most encouraging that you will use the "Faith and Freedom" readers which we are, as Mr. Litch and Mr. Robinson explained, engaged in Canadianizing. For many years I have had a rather detailed knowledge of conditions in the Indian schools, both from personal observation in the schools and from my contacts with the members of your Department. Long, long ago I realized that many books contained statements which, from the point-of-view of the Indian schools, are unfortunate and it has been our constant aim in the production of Canadian books to make sure that they would contain nothing offensive to Indians and, indeed, that they should be especially suitable for use in the Indian schools. It is therefore doubly pleasing to me to have your seal of approval put upon our work.

We have only a handful of the circulars to which you refer here in Toronto, but we can probably get the 400 you require from our Boston office. I am enquiring about this and will write you as soon as I hear further about it.

I want to thank you for the courtesy you showed to Mr. Litch and Mr. Robinson the other day. I am hopeful that before long I may make a trip to Ottawa and meet you. If, of course, you are in Toronto at any time, I hope you will give me a call and perhaps we may have lunch together.

Dear Colonel Neary:

On my return to Toronto this morning I find on my desk your letter of September 11 regarding the Jolly Numbers books. This is one of the matters you discussed with me in Quebec and, as Mr. Robinson was able to explain, Book One was due here on September 11. Actually the books arrived on September 12 and shipment has already been made to the Stationery Office. We expect Book Two, First Half, around the end of this week and it will go out to you immediately.

The "Living Language" series, as I explained to you, is in press. We are sending you today 500 copies of the Level-Three book, "Word Ways," and the balance of your order for this book will go out to you within the next two or three days. The books for the higher levels will follow on in quick succession.

We also have an order from you for the workbook for "These Are Our Friends." We expect to ship this around the first week in October.

Apart from the books mentioned above, we have no outstanding orders from the Stationery Office. Therefore, if any other books are short, you should request them to order immediately and we will do our best to get them to you promptly.

I am sorry that we are late with some of these books, for I realize just what an annoying situation this means in the schools. However, as you know, manufacturing conditions are quite chaotic and the delays are beyond our control.

It was a great pleasure to meet you in Quebec and I shall look forward to seeing you again soon when both of us have more time to sit down and chat. If you are in Toronto any time, I hope you will give me a call and perhaps we can have a bite of lunch together.

Cordially yours,

Dear Mr. Chamberlin:

Further to our recent telephone conversation, I would like to confirm the following points made with you at that time:

(A) That in all three scribbler covers the words "Indian Schools" be deleted, because of the fact that these exercise books will be used in National Defence schools as well as our own.

(B) That Scribbler A (in error a "G" has been put on the front of this Scribbler) should have on the back page "Canada's Food Rules" rather than "O Canada". If the artist wishes to use, as an outline motif, illustrations of the basic points in these Food Rules it will be entirely satisfactory.

(C) That the back page of Scribbler B be amended by placing thereon "O Canada" in place of "Canada's Food Rules". In other words, these last two suggested changes involve a switch in scribbler back pages between A and B.

(D) Scribbler C is entirely satisfactory in its present form except that we would suggest that the capital city of the province and also Prince Rupert be marked in.

Dear Sir:

It is noted that in a Circular Letter of October 15th, the Comptroller of the Treasury has informed all Chief Treasury Officers of the necessity for Departments to secure written permission of the King's Printer in order to purchase certain articles, or things, on local purchase orders.

During recent inspections of Indian schools, both the schools officials of the Indian Affairs Branch and the inspectors of provincial Departments of Education have commented on the long delays which our teachers are experiencing before receiving their school supplies.

These requisitions call for supplies which fall mainly into two broad groups:

(a) **STANDARD SUPPLIES** such as Readers, Arithmetics, scribblers, pencils, etc., which are more or less common to the various courses of study of the provinces in which our Indian schools are located.

The Indian Affairs Branch informs the Stationery Branch of its requirements in these supplies, and a stock is held to be sent out when requisitions are received.

(b) **SPECIAL SUPPLIES** consisting mainly of text-books which are specifically authorized by a provincial Department of Education for that province.

As we have Indian schools located in each of the nine provinces and as each province has an entirely
different course of study, the Stationery Branch cannot be expected to stock these widely different text-books. This is particularly evident in the Senior Grades from Seven upwards. In the past, this has not presented too great a problem, but now Indian pupils in increasing numbers are passing into these grades and the situation has now become very difficult due to the non-arrival of the necessary text-books. Last year we were criticised by provincial inspectors for not providing required text-books for entrance pupils until November; yet these requisitions had been passed to the Stationery Branch during the summer holidays.

It is felt that the Stationery Branch is required to spend so much time in filling orders for these special text-books that it is not able to cope with our requisitions for standard supplies. At the present time, it has been estimated that a requisition goes through the following steps before the supplies actually arrive in the hands of the teacher concerned:

1. Teacher fills out requisition form.
2. Agent countersigns requisition form.
3. Requisition reaches Indian Affairs Branch where it is checked and typed on a special form required by the Stationery Branch.
4. This special requisition form is signed by the Superintendent of Welfare and Training.
5. It is signed by a Treasury Official.
6. It is sent to the Stationery Branch, where apparently two separate actions may take place.

(a) If an item is listed as in stock, it is copied on a Delivery Record.

(b) If it is an item of a special text-book not in stock, an order is prepared for the Text-book Bureau of the province concerned or publishing company or school supply company.
7. The order is filled or if an outside order is to be placed.

8. This order is sent to the firm or bureau concerned. The order is filled by the firm or bureau.

9. This firm or bureau sends bill to the Stationery Branch.

10. A monthly account is sent by the Stationery Branch to the Indian Affairs Branch for payment.

The schools officials of the Indian Affairs Branch have carefully studied the foregoing procedure with a view to eliminating as much of the delay as possible. At the present time it takes four to five months for supplies to reach our schools. Therefore, it is felt that you will agree with the following recommendations:

A. For standard items which are common to all schools or to most schools, such as readers, Arithmetics, pencils, chalk, etc., the following procedure is suggested:

(1) The teacher completes a standardized requisition form, such as attached hereto.

(2) The Agent countersigns this and sends it to the Indian Affairs Branch.

(3) The Branch attaches eight or ten of these special requisition forms to the form required by the Stationery Branch; the covering form is signed by a Training Division official and a Treasury Official and sent to the Stationery Branch.

(4) The Stationery Branch carries out its normal procedure with a requisition.

B. For special items which are peculiar to the province concerned and more especially for text-
books required for the senior grades, the following procedure is suggested:

(1) The teacher completes a special supplies requisition form.

(2) The Agent countersigns this and sends it to the Indian Affairs Branch.

(3) After checking to ensure that the text-books are as authorized by the provincial Department of Education concerned, that the Indian Affairs Branch be permitted to order these text-books directly from the provincial Text-Book Bureau concerned or the publishing company.

If it is decided to place a limit on these purchase orders, it is suggested that this be $100.00.

(4) That the Text-Book Bureau, or the publishing company, bill the Indian Affairs branch for these items.

Practically all provincial Departments of Education now maintain efficient Text-Book bureaus. These bureaus have a large supply of text-books - particularly those required in the province concerned. These have been established by the provinces in order to provide text-books at the lowest cost possible. Attached please find an order form from the Manitoba Text-Book Bureau, which should illustrate the scope of these bureaus.

It is felt that by the above two procedures we can eliminate these long delays at present being experienced, and thus greatly increase the efficiency of our Indian schools. At the present time a teacher will send in a requisition for school books and also a requisition for janitor
supplies. The janitor supplies, which we authorize the Agent concerned to buy by local purchase, reach her in ten days or two weeks, while the school books - so urgently required - often take four to five months to reach her. It is felt that action is definitely required to remedy this situation.

Yours sincerely,

H. L. KEENLEYSIDE
Deputy Minister.

OFFICE OF THE COMPTROLLER OF THE TREASURY

Circular Letter No. 1947-65
Ottawa, October 18th, 1947

TO THE CHIEF TREASURY OFFICERS:

Attached is a copy of Cabinet Directive No.1 of September 19, 1947, prescribing a procedure to govern departmental requisitions for printing and stationery and the distribution and sale of official publications by departments and agencies of Government.

The concern of the Treasury in this Directive is twofold, namely:

(1) The effect of the Directive on the requisitioning of printing and stationery for Treasury use.

(2) The policing action required of the Treasury to ensure that departments comply with the prescribed procedure.

With regard to No.1, Treasury Officers are instructed that under no circumstances should an agent of any printing or stationery firm be permitted to proceed with the work of drafting Treasury forms or furnishing specifications and prices for printing and stationery requirements on an understanding given by a Treasury Officer, verbally or otherwise, that the agent's firm will get the business. Should it become necessary to enlist the aid of agents of printing and stationery firms in determining the specifications of printing jobs or the drafting of forms to do the job in question, Treasury Officers will request the approval of Central Office before discussing the project with agents. Central Office will in turn seek the approval of the King's Printer.

With respect to the policing action required of the Treasury over the actions of departments, Treasury Officers are instructed that no suppliers' accounts for printing and stationery should, at any time, or under any circumstances, be paid directly from departmental appropriations, either by Receiver General cheques issued by Treasury Officers, or by payments made (usually) from Imprest Accounts; provided that if a department secures the written permission of the King's Printer to purchase certain articles or things on local purchase order, Treasury Officers may pay accounts which conform to such written agreement or may honour the relevant items in an Imprest Account, as the case may be.

If a claim for reimbursement of an Imprest Account contains an item of printing and stationery of a type which the department was not permitted, by the King's Printer, to purchase on its own authority, Treasury Officers will delete the item from the claim and advise the department to forward a covering requisition to the King's Printer for approval. When submitting such requisition the department must clearly endorse on the face thereof a statement that the account of the supplier has been paid in order to protect against a duplicate payment being made.

Comptroller of the Treasury.
(b) Any department, board, commission or other government agency with which such an agreement has been entered shall be required to comply with any regulations which may be issued from time to time by the Department of Public Printing and Stationery with respect to the stocking and distribution of such publications, and in the case of publications for sale with respect to the pricing, listing of such publications, the conditions of sale and payment, the disposition of moneys accruing from sales, the control of stocks and inventories, or other regulations that may be found necessary for the proper observance of the provisions of the Public Printing and Stationery Act.

All departments and agencies of government are directed to govern themselves accordingly.

(sgd)
A.D.P. Heaney
Secretary to the Cabinet.

On a recent visit to the Interior of this Province I have been confronted with a large number of complaints from teachers concerning the failure of the Department to supply books and materials requested. Much of this material may be secured locally and this has aggravated the situation.

I have asked the Indian Agents to purchase the most urgently needed supplies locally, and have asked the Department to approve my action. I do not know the reason for the failure to supply these things, but have tried to explain to the teachers that it is no doubt due to the present shortages. In one school in particular the teacher had visited schools in the east and made unfavourable comments concerning the difference in which materials are supplied to this Province.

In some cases, no doubt, requisitions were late in being sent in to the Department but I feel that this is not the whole explanation, as it seems unlikely nearly all the teachers would be late in forwarding their requisitions. If there is anything that you can do in the way of speeding up the delivery of the supplies requisitioned, it would be greatly appreciated.

I recently visited Bill Mouat who is expecting a by-law for the addition to his school to be put before the Municipality in January. He is very hopeful about the outcome. Bill and his family are well.

Best wishes to you, Betty and Patrick.

Yours sincerely,

Lieut. Colonel B.F. Neary, O.B.E.,
Superintendent of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, November 26, 1947.

Dear Bob:

Rest assured that I will let you know as soon as a reply is received from the King's Printer regarding my proposals for cutting short this long procedure.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I have had on my desk for some weeks your letter of December 12 to Mr. Robinson and his reply of December 22. This had primarily to do with your letters of September 12 and 13.

The strike which has been going on in Toronto for the past four weeks has now been settled, the men having gone back to work yesterday. The settlement includes a retroactive increase in pay from $1.07½ to $1.35, two weeks' holiday with pay as against one week, and eight statutory holidays with pay as against three. This, together with the sharp increases in the cost of materials, unfortunately is going to result in a very sharp increase in the price of books. So far we haven't worked out complete costs on our various titles. We were forced to raise a number of prices on January 1 of this year and other increases will probably have to be made when we have worked out complete costs.

For the time-being, however, we are able to quote you definitely on one book: CARIBOU ARITHMETICS, Grade Three. On this title we can give you a price of 80¢. It seems to me that this book should be particularly suited for your needs inasmuch as it is written primarily for use in the small school where a teacher has more than one grade. It is, as far as I know, the only arithmetic at this grade level written from this point of view. The Grade-Four CARIBOU ARITHMETIC is in active preparation and will be ready next fall.

The workbook for STORIES FOR EVERY DAY is almost ready for press. I am sending you under separate cover a set of page proof of this book. This is not final proof and there may be some errors in it. You may rely on these being corrected before the book is published. Also we are making some minor changes here and there in the exercises, particularly in the poetry selections where the exercises will be less factual and more imaginative.

We have had this proof read by a number of very good teachers, and the changes which are being made are the result of suggestions from them. I hope you will decide to use this in your schools.
Now that we have the workbook for STORIES FOR EVERY DAY practically finished, we are starting work on the workbook for TREASURE TROVE.

Cordially yours,

Dear Colonel Neary:

This, combined with increases in the price of paper and very drastic increases in the price of cloth have added tremendously to our manufacturing costs, and we are presently working on a new schedule of prices. This is just as astounding to us as it probably will be to you, but of course every publisher is in the same boat and there is nothing we can do about it. Our books could, of course, be cheapened by the use of lighter paper, the omission of colour, and that sort of thing, but the demand today is for a first-class book, and we don't think books cheapened in quality would meet with favour in the schools.

I am in receipt of copy of a letter from the Deputy Minister of the Department of Mines & Resources, dated October 31st, which you sent me for my comments.

In reply I wish to advise you that I see no reason for the Department of Mines & Resources not ordering their supplies through this office the same as the Indian Schools in the Department of Indian Affairs order theirs.

On many requisitions received from Mines & Resources they are asking for books which are stocked regularly for the Department of Indian Affairs. The only exception that might be made is where they are asking for textbooks of the different provinces which are not carried in stock and which are urgently required.

Regarding the delay, I might state there is no long delay if the department would send me their requisitions with a notation that the goods are urgently required. In many cases books that are required for Indian Schools are ordered from the publishers, but a delay is caused owing to the fact that they cannot be procured at once, in many cases they have not yet been printed.

Some items such as scribblers, pencils, etc., are carried regularly in stock and could be supplies at once providing the department states they are urgently required. Evidently a lot of the delay is caused by the department's regulations as to where the goods should be ordered. In the Deputy Minister's letter he quotes the procedure that requisitions must take before the goods are supplied. A lot of these regulations are inter-departmental and is not caused by any delay on the part of this Department.

I would suggest that before ordering goods the Department of Mines and Resources communicate with Col. B.F. Neary, Superintendent of the Indian Branch, Department of Indian Affairs, who will be in a position to state what text-books are used for his Indian Schools. As already stated many
of ones for the Department of Mines and Resources are the same as those stocked for the Indian Schools.

Goods that are not carried in stock are forwarded to the Controller of Purchases to be ordered. If there is any delay in ordering, it is not the fault of this Branch.

I would suggest that the Department of Mines and Resources forward their requisitions to this office and preference will be given where the goods are marked urgent.

(sgd.) J. W. DRISCOLL

Dear Mr. Luckett:

I have for answer your letter of March 18th, with regard to requests by some of our teachers for donations of pencils and crayons for use in Indian schools.

The information contained in your letter came as a complete surprise, as we have been filling requisitions for pencils and crayons in full. It would seem, therefore, that exaggerated statements have been made to you, and we would sincerely appreciate being advised of the schools from which you have received these requests.

It is quite possible that some of these requests may have been forwarded from combined schools for Indian and half-breed pupils which are operated jointly with the provincial Departments of Education. While we provide free pencils, books, etc., for Indian children, these are not provided for half-breed children.

In view of the contents of your letter of the 22nd ultimo, file O-11-1, we will in future address school supplies to "The Teacher" instead of the individual name of the teacher.

We have followed this procedure at some schools in the past but this practice also presents some difficulties and I therefore suggest the following:

(1) That you notify the Indian Agents that we will adopt this procedure in connection with school supplies for schools in British Columbia.

(2) That the Indian Agent in turn notify the schools in his Agency and advise each teacher that he or she should immediately get in touch with the post master of the post office where their mail is received and advise this official that any communications addressed "The Teacher" should be delivered to him or her.

This is especially necessary in the case of new teachers as it has happened in the past when the local post master is not personally acquainted with the teacher at an Indian day school. When he receives a letter or parcel addressed to "The Teacher" he is not definitely aware to whom it should be delivered.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Mr. Robinson has reported to me on his conversation with you and Mr. Doucet regarding the wood-working books. I understand that you do not care for either of the formats which I suggested but would prefer to have the book saddle-stitched, somewhat after the style of Jolly Numbers. This is perfectly feasible and we are working on this basis. I understand also that you do not like the idea of imitation typewriter type because you think that this would be harder for the children to read. That, also, is perfectly all right with us and we are planning to use regular school book type. I understand from Mr. Robinson that you wish a number of extra copies of the students' record sheet, the bill of material, and the chart of basic operations. Mr. Robinson said that you wished a price of $10,000 each of these sheets, as a separate form. It will be perfectly possible to have these made, but I wonder if it would not be better to provide a sample of each of these forms in the text of the book (which, I understand, is what Mr. Doucet wants) and then, at the back of the book, to print a number of copies of each of these and have the pages perforated so that they can be torn out. I think that you would find this much more satisfactory than handling loose sheets, and the difference in cost would be trifling.

Quite a bit of editorial work has to be done on these pages in order to secure an attractive format. One of the troubles is that the amount of material on the pages varies in length. Another thing is that where we have drawings which occupy a full page, as in the case of the tea-pot stand, the instructions should face the drawing, so that the student doesn't have to turn the page to and fro while he is reading the instructions. Also, as a matter of routine, we want to check the material against the texts which are referred to. We have tried to obtain copies of these texts in Toronto but have been unable to do so, except in one case, namely HAND WOOD-WORKING by Evans, Parks, and Slatterie. Dear Mr. Larson:

You will have received by now a set of the FAITH AND FREEDOM readers for Grades One to Three. Please accept these books with the compliments of Ginn and Company through me.

FAITH AND FREEDOM is a complete basal reading programme, made up of pupils' texts, workbooks, teachers' manuals and certain supplementary aids to reading. A list of all these materials with prices is attached to this letter.

FAITH AND FREEDOM readers, as you know, are the authorized texts in primary reading for the Separate Schools of Saskatchewan. In addition, this new series is prescribed for use in the Catholic Indian schools throughout Canada, being supplied through the Department of Indian Affairs. Col. B. F. Henry, the superintendent of Indian schools, has asked me to draw your special attention to the FAITH AND FREEDOM Readers. It is of prime importance that the teachers have, and use, the appropriate teachers' manuals.

In several ways, the FAITH AND FREEDOM Readers are far in advance of all basal reading programmes. First of all, the stories in FAITH AND FREEDOM present situations which are part and parcel of every child's life at home and school and at play, and which develop moral choice and ethical action. This feature in itself is by no means new, but it is unique so far as any modern reading programme is concerned. FAITH AND FREEDOM has led the way, and there are signs that forthcoming readers will reflect a return to content illustrating the simple virtues, such as brotherly love.

No basal reading series today present the techniques of reading better than FAITH AND FREEDOM. The teachers' manuals which accompany each reading level teach every page of the primary books. More important though, than the lesson plans, is the fact that the manuals keep constantly before the teacher specific and varied techniques in presenting basal reading.

In the final analysis, though, the pupils' books themselves determine the real worth of any reading series. Here, when you come to examine the readers, you will find content based
unmistakably on children's real life interests, yet the stories are always worthwhile and literate even at the pre-primer level. Even with this high literary standard, the first pre-primer, HERE WE COME, is the easiest pre-primer published today. In case you wish to make further comparisons with the FAITH AND FREEDOM Readers, I am attaching a pamphlet which gives a helpful analysis of the series. Please note particularly the vocabulary chart reproduced on Page 4.

There are many other features of the books that you will like. The vigorous and appealing illustrations by Charlotte Ware are works of art in themselves. Not least to the credit of the FAITH AND FREEDOM Readers is the sturdy binding designed to withstand the daily use to which basic texts are subject.

FAITH AND FREEDOM is without question the leading reading series in its field. It is used basically in seven thousand of the eight thousand parochial schools in the United States. In addition to this, the series has been adopted in the Province of Quebec and in Newfoundland for use beginning in September.

I had a long visit from Bill Houst yesterday afternoon and he is debating whether to apply for an inspectorate that has been advertised in B.C. with the provincial Department. LANDS AND PEOPLES, *The World in Color*, has as its Editor-in-Chief, Dr. Holland Thompson of The College of the City of New York, and contains an introduction by Dr. Isaiah Bowman, President of Johns Hopkins University and former Director of the American Geographical Society.

This is truly a de luxe edition, bound in rich purple Artcraft. Each cover is individually decorated in colors with an embossed picture reuse.
The text matter has been prepared by a number of noted authorities such as Vilhjalmur Stefansson, the famous explorer, and many others, who have traveled many thousands of miles with camera and typewriter to present this outstanding work to you.

LANDS AND PEOPLES PROMOTES PEACE THROUGH UNDERSTANDING

There would be no wars if the peoples of the world could visit each other, discuss their mutual problems, learn each other's viewpoints and traditions.

Lands and Peoples makes these visits practical. It takes you right into the homes and the hearts of the peoples of every country in the world—it teaches you to understand and sympathize with other cultures and other viewpoints.

"How can peoples get on with each other," says Dr. Bowman, in his introduction to Lands and Peoples, "unless they do talk over their problems and try to understand each other in all their common ways as well as in their unusual and peculiar manifestations? To help understand the citizens of other countries these books on Lands and Peoples have been brought together, with a wealth of color and story. With all of them we as heirs of a 'human civilization,' have business or political relations and all of them act as real forces playing upon us and the rest of the world. They are realities, profoundly interesting realities with their unlikenesses, their (to us) strange civilizations, customs, religions, dress and food. Who would not wish to go a-voyaging among them?"

GENERAL ARRANGEMENT OF LANDS AND PEOPLES

THE SEVEN VOLUMES of the work are arranged to bring, so far as possible, contiguous countries together. Beginning with Western Europe we move eastward until the globe has been encircled. The dominions, territories or dependencies of a nation in another continent are treated not with the nation itself but according to their geographical location. For example, Algeria is described not under France, but in the volume on Africa. The general scope of each volume is indicated below.

VOLUME I Western Europe
Includes England, Scotland, Wales, Ireland, Belgium, the Netherlands, France, Spain, Portugal and the islands of the Atlantic and of the Mediterranean, with 112 pages in full color.

VOLUME II Central Europe
Includes Norway, Sweden, Finland, Greenland and Iceland, Denmark, Germany, Poland, Latvia, Lithuania, Austria-Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Austria, Hungary, Switzerland, the Toy States and Italy, with 88 pages in full color.

VOLUME III
Includes a full treatment of Canada, Newfoundland and the United States, including Alaska and Hawaii, with special articles on...
In all the world there is no other set like it. It gives the student, the traveler, the lover of romance and the adventurer a true insight into the peculiarities, traditions, customs and backgrounds of every nation from the beginning of time to today.

It makes you understand the reason for national aspirations and ambitions; it puts action into history and makes the past live again.

While fascinatingly interesting, the authority of Lands and Peoples is so well established that it has been recommended by Boards of Education everywhere for school use in the study of the social sciences, and it is the standard set in hundreds of educational institutions. Lands and Peoples is ideally adapted for the arrangements of pageants and costume shows.

It is an inspiring source of material for artists and designers, for writers and research workers, for schools, women's clubs and other cultural groups. It is often chosen for special study on such topics as Transportation, Food, Clothing, Forms of Government and other comprehensive subjects. Lands and Peoples is a rich storehouse of information and pictures on these and hundreds of other subjects. A few of the index headings will serve to show the range of project material: Agriculture, Air Service, Art Treasures, Betrothal Customs, Bridges, Monuments, Burial Customs, Canals, Colleges, Costumes, Customs, Dancing, Festivals, Industries, etc.

Lands and Peoples fits perfectly into school curricula wherever the social sciences are taught. It is grouped and arranged to go along with school courses and, for the convenience of teachers, students and general readers, is indexed as follows: Alphabetical Index in each volume; Cumulative Alphabetical Index in Volume VII; Cumulative Index of color plates in Volume VII; Table of Contents in each volume.

Lands and Peoples is written in simple, narrative style, and in addition to the descriptive text, contains an encyclopedic article of facts and figures at the end of the article on each country. Each volume is also heavily gold-stamped and gold-topped, with headbands and strongly reinforced back.
Adventure... Romance... Thrills... Color... Understanding — are yours with this unique set... it truly makes the world an open book to you. It entertains you while it teaches... it takes you away from yourself, from your daily routine into the far-away corners of the globe... it hurdles time and space... it is the magic...
key that opens the doors of every country, every age and every race. It interprets the meaning of events...it explains the development of the human race...it makes you see with your own eyes why thrones totter, kings abdicate, dictators arise, why peoples rebel, why wars are fought, why old civilizations die and new ones are born.
WITH LANDS AND PEOPLES.

Travel and adventure need no longer be a dream. They become a delightful reality.

Don't wait for vacation time—travel now, tonight!

Do you feel like a trip into the thirteenth-century Mongol empire of Kublai Khan? Open the second volume of Lands and Peoples—and there you are!

Do you long for the gaiety of Rio de Janeiro or the sunshine of Argentina? They are yours in all their brilliance and splendor—and all you need do is sit down with Volume Seven in your easy chairs.

Or perhaps a quick journey to Alaska's frozen North or picturesque Canadian Lake Louise? There it is, as if by magic, in Volume Six.

Maybe it is far-away Tibet or Burma that strikes your fancy. It takes but a moment to reach for Volume Four, and you stand in the very heart of India. At your will, you are in Paris or Berlin, in Madrid or Rome, in Havana or Haiti, in Melbourne or Johannesburg.
TO THE STUDENT, the artist, the designer, Lands and Peoples is indispensable.

Arranged for easy reference, grouped according to classifications, indexed so that even a child can quickly find his way, of facts and figures.

It makes the study of geography and social science a pleasure, research work becomes entertainment, and the creative mind finds Lands and Peoples a veritable Fountain of Youth.

"Within twenty-four hours after I got my set," says a noted commercial artist, "I got an idea for a South Seas folder out of it that made me two hundred dollars. What an investment, in addition to the pleasure I get out of it."

And here is a mother's comment: "My twelve-year old girl never showed the slightest interest in geography. But since Lands and Peoples came into the house, she can't get enough of it."

Dear Sirs:

We acknowledge receipt of your August 16th inquiry concerning prices and types of available school desks. Unfortunately, we are unable to supply the required details as at the present time, we are not producing any type of school desk.

During the war years, it became necessary to eliminate many of our lines due to material shortage and one of these was the school desks which was hardest hit not only because of a lack of good lumber but also pig iron and scrap iron was unavailable to produce the castings. Since cessation of hostilities, the lumber market has been anything but good and in fact, we would not produce school desks from the very poor stock that is available on the market. Consequently we have not re-entered this line nor can we see any future improvement for quite some time.

Most desk manufacturers are much in the same position as ourselves and we hesitate offering even a suggestion as to where you might contact a possible source of supply.

Yours very truly,

What are die-impressed stencils? Stencils furnished with your ruled form or heading already stenciled into the stencil sheet. You add necessary typed or handwritten information and from this master produce both the form and added text on blank paper stock, in one duplicating operation. Saves time and cost of printed forms, and all problems incident to their storage.

How die-impressed stencils are used. These stencils are used to add variable fill-in copy to constant forms. They save time and labor when used for individual daily or weekly reports or notices. They expedite production and simplify controls when used to produce papers needed for paper-work systems or procedures.

For complete procedures. By using die-impressed stencils and blocking out portions of the constant form and the variable fill-in copy, complete systems and routines can be worked out so that rewriting of the fill-in copy is eliminated. This is done by designing the forms needed for a complete procedure in such a way that all data needed for all forms used in the complete procedure will appear on the stencil, but will be so located that certain portions, not needed for certain steps in the procedure, may be blocked out as required.

Charges... only three cost factors are involved: 1. The cost of the stencil sheets. 2. Type composition for special die (applies only to the first order). Submit copy for estimate. 3. Die-impressing charge—based on quantity ordered. Quotation on request.

These two services of A. B. Dick Company eliminate the delays and errors due to rewriting of fill-in copy on forms used singly or in procedures. They also provide a practical and efficient method of producing the forms needed.

What are form-topped stencil sheets? Stencil sheets prepared with facsimile of your printed form in contrasting color on each stencil sheet surface to guide typists in positioning fill-in copy accurately. The form-topped stencil, with copy typed in position, is used on the Mimeograph duplicator to reproduce the fill-in information on preprinted forms.

How form-topped stencil sheets are used. Form-topped stencil sheets are used when duplicated copy is to be added to preprinted forms. If identical copy must be added to several different preprinted forms, the forms should be so designed that the fill-in copy will be located in the same position on each printed form.

For complete procedures. Form-topped stencils are used for complete procedures in the same way that die-impressed stencils are used. The main advantage of form-topped stencils is that as many copies as you need can be produced from one typing, and several different printed forms may be filled in from only one typing. This reduces production time sharply and eliminates retyping errors. Unless it is necessary to use printed forms, die-impressing is usually preferred to form-topping because it eliminates the cost of printing and storing large quantities of forms.

October 29, 1948.

Memorandum:

Major MacKay

Non-delivery of School Supplies.

As I have advised you personally, this matter is now one of the most serious problems facing our Education Division. Last year, as in former years, there were some delays in deliveries of school supplies. This year, the following two steps were taken in order to expedite the passing of requisitions from here to the Stationery Branch of the Department of Public Printing and Stationery:

1. In the November 1947 issue of the Indian School Bulletin, we sent out a standard school requisition form, a copy of which is attached. This was sent in duplicate and Principals of Residential Schools were asked to forward it to the Department by December 31, 1947. Day School Teachers were asked to forward it to the Department by May 31, 1948. These attached forms were designed to assist both our own clerks and those in the Stationery Branch by having all items listed in a standard order. In the past, a requisition form such as appendix (b) attached had been used.

2. The date upon which requisitions were to reach the Department was advanced from June 30, 1948, to May 31, 1948, as indicated above. In this way, it was felt we would provide an extra month for the Stationery Branch to fill requisitions and thus ensure their arrival at the schools concerned before school opening in September.
Just how badly these requisitions have been filled can best be indicated by the three samples which I have attached. In each instance, these requisitions were sent from here in three or four days after their arrival to the Stationery Branch on the special forms provided. It would then seem that long delays occurred before the orders were even typed on these special delivery record slips used. The chart hereunder shows the long delays which occurred in the filling of these requisitions.

I would emphasize that these three requisitions were selected by me at random from the top of the last batch of delivery records sent here from Stationery:

| Name of School | Date sent to Stationery Branch | Date typed on Delivery Record | Date parcel sent School |
|----------------|--------------------------------|-------------------------------|------------------------|
| Bella Coola, B.C. | May 26 | July 2 | September 14 |
| Old Sun, Alberta | May 20 | July 2 | September 9 |
| Ahtahkakoops, Sask. | May 26 | July 2 | September 10 |

It can be seen from the above that these teachers did as requested. Not only were their requisitions forwarded to the Department before May 31, but the requests were sent to the Stationery Branch from here before that date.

As I have previously told you, we are now receiving a deluge of complaints from teachers, principals, superintendents and regional supervisors. We are forwarding a letter in each case to the Stationery Branch to indicate to them the serious discontent on the part of our teachers with the way in which these school supplies are being handled.

I have visited Mr. Driscoll, the Superintendent of Stationery, from whom I have always received the utmost in
co-operation. He informed me that these delays were mainly due to shortages of staff and to absences because of illness and holidays. He has promised that two or more extra men will be put immediately on to filling back requisitions.

I feel, however, that this will merely alleviate the present condition and will in no way remedy it.

I find that I am answering letters and handling problems which should never reach my attention if these supplies were being issued properly. For example, the requisition for the Fort McPherson Indian Day School was sent from here on June 8, 1946. We were quite confident that it would reach Waterways in July. Instead, it reached there in late August or early September. As a result, it was necessary for my staff and our field staff to take the following action:

1. The parcel was returned here from Waterways.
2. It was opened here and divided into two parts, namely Essential and Non-essential.
3. Two smaller parcels were made up and were shipped to Mr. Indian Superintendent Robertson at Edmonton.
4. He was asked to send the small parcel of essential supplies by Air Express to Fort McPherson.
5. He was asked to send the large parcel, next Spring, on the first boat.

I do not feel that my time or that of the field staff should be taken up in remedying such situations as are caused by the apparent inefficiency of another department. Therefore I feel strongly that this other department must improve the facilities for handling our supplies or must be prepared to have these supplies taken out of their charge and handled by this Branch. I have prepared a draft letter for the Deputy Minister's signature to the King's Printer, with specific recommendations for the improvement of the delivery of our school supplies.

Bernard F. Heary,
Superintendent of Education.
November 5, 1948.

Dear Sir:

You will recall that on October 31, 1947, I wrote to you with regard to the delays which have occurred in the delivery of school supplies from the Stationery Branch to our Indian day and residential schools across Canada. In your reply dated January 27, 1948, you stated as follows:

"I may add that with the return to normal conditions it is hoped that the unavoidable delays complained of by your teachers in Indian schools will be completely eliminated."

Our Indian schools have now been open for nearly two months of the academic year. In most instances the teachers at these schools submitted their requisitions in the late spring and these were forwarded to the Stationery Branch in May or June. Every day's mail brings another series of letters of complaints from these teachers concerning the non-delivery of these supplies. I understand that our Superintendent of Stationery has discussed this matter with your Superintendent of Stationery and that efforts are being made to catch up on back requisitions as fast as possible. However, while this might alleviate the condition, it will not remedy it.

The children in our Indian schools are now reaching higher grades than previously. It no longer suffices to give them a ruler, an arithmetic book and a few scribblers and pencils. In the senior grades they must be provided with
the history, geography and literature texts as prescribed in provincial courses of study. We must also equip our schools with supplementary reading and library books, as recommended by provincial departments of education.

I realize only too well that this means an increased number of books to be handled by your Stationery Branch. However, I would point out that as the years go by, we have every hope that more Indian children will reach higher grades and that even more books will be required than are at present being supplied.

Therefore, I would again ask you to consider the recommendation made in my letter of October 31, 1947. I feel that by authorizing the Indian Affairs Branch to purchase its own textbooks as indicated in this letter, it will do a great deal towards reducing the volume of work being required of your Stationery Branch.

It is quite possible that you might wish to present some other solution to this problem. If so, I would welcome an opportunity of discussing this matter with you and possibly some of your senior officials.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Minister.
November 2, 1948.

B.F. Neary, Esq.,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Bern:

I am sending you under separate cover a copy of a T.B. Unit which we have developed for use in our B.C. schools. Probably I should have referred this to you before taking any specific action but I was anxious to get it in operation in the current year and I felt that you would certainly approve of the idea. I am afraid the unit is a little bit rough in spots but possibly it could be improved in subsequent years. I would be very pleased to have your reaction towards it. A considerable amount of help has been received from Dr. Barclay, who was primarily responsible for its development. A lot of the work in organizing it was done by Mr. George Sinclair who was formerly employed at the Alberni Residential School. Mr. Sinclair suffers from a severe arthritic condition and is unable to do very much in the way of classroom work. He has now accepted an appointment to the elementary correspondence branch in Victoria, where I believe, he is doing quite well.

I have just returned from a long trip in the North, including visits to the Lejac and Cariboo Residential Schools. The matter of the supply of books is still a considerable headache and I cannot see why there should be the long delay which occurs in almost every school before the receipt of the supplies requisitioned.

As you will have heard by now the Hazelton School Board has approved in principle the operation of a combined Indian and white school at that point, and as you know we have also received applications from two other school boards for
assistance in capital expenditures. I believe that this is distinct progress and I hope that the Department will be able to give us an early reply as to the possibility of assistance towards capital expenditures in these cases. I know that the Lytton school board, which is one of the cases mentioned, is awaiting the Department's reply before determining its policy for admitting additional Indian pupils to their schools.

On the whole the work is going much more smoothly and at the moment I am considerably encouraged by an improvement in the calibre of teachers we are securing. There are however one or two notable exceptions which may have been brought to your attention.

While up North I visited the Anaham Indian Day School where the Sister in charge conducted a potato club with considerable success. I have asked her to send me a synopsis of their activities which I will forward on to you. I should like very much to have an account of this activity included in one of the issues of the bulletin as I feel that in this particular case it has been very worthwhile, not only from the standpoint of the educational value to the pupils, but the parents also have, I believe, learned something from this activity. One of the parents is saving the crop harvested by the pupil for seed for next year. However I will give you more on this when I hear from the teacher.

I am sorry that you were unable to get out to B.C. on your last trip but we will be looking forward to a visit from you some time in the near future. I notice that you have a number of problems that you will be bringing along with you and I am sure that we can add considerably to your troubles. A visit by you to the Coast would certainly be worthwhile as both Mr. Arneil and myself have several things which could best be decided by a conference with you.

With very best wishes,

Yours sincerely,

Bob.
November 5, 1948.

A copy of this letter is attached, and you will note that we discontinued the sending over of supplementary reading book requisitions in order that the standard supplies could be shipped out in time for school opening.

As a result of the lack of supplies, the progress of our pupils is not being maintained at the rate which our school inspectors have a right to expect. This situation also has a serious effect on our teachers; they are doing everything possible to improve the standard of our schools. Particularly in the higher grades, it is most discouraging for them to start the school year without the texts which they ordered some four or five months previously. We realize only too well the growth in the amount of supplies which have to be purchased by your department. I feel that by authorizing the Indian Affairs Branch to purchase its own textbooks, as indicated in this letter, it will do a great deal towards reducing the volume of work being required of your Stationery Branch at the present time.

I have answered your letter of November 12 and today had an opportunity of discussing its contents with our new Director. He knows Mrs. Thornton quite well because of his previous experience as Indian Commissioner of B. C.

It has been decided that we would have to have an opportunity of reading Mrs. Thornton's manuscript before we can commit ourselves as to the purchase of some five hundred copies. We would like to ascertain its value for use as a school book and library book.

I would be glad to hear further from you in this regard.

November 12, 1948.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Neary,

I was so sorry to miss you in Ottawa last time I was there. I met Miss Juliette Gauthier de la Verendrye. I do think that she has a good deal of interesting material, and we have asked her to prepare a manuscript for us. This obviously is the first thing to do.

I discussed very briefly with Mr. Phelan the possibility of publishing Mrs. Thornton's book on her interviews with outstanding West Coast Indians. She has built the book around interviews with Indians whose portraits she has painted in oil. Personally I think her paintings are very fine, and certainly the book is worthy of publication. As I explained to Mr. Phelan, however, we would have to print a minimum of 1500 copies of this book to make it a publishing venture and even then we can not foresee a market of more than 600 or 700 copies of the book in Canada. The only way, however, that we can make Mrs. Thornton an offer for her book would be to find someone who would be willing to underwrite a certain number of copies in order to make publication possible. We have a tentative quotation on producing 1500 copies of the book. It would make a 240 page book and would contain 44 black and white photographs of Mrs. Thornton's oil paintings and coloured frontispiece, as well as four four-colour photos. We should have to sell this book for about $4.00 a copy.

We are wondering if the Department of Indian Affairs would care to go into the question of making the publication of this book possible by purchasing 500 copies of the book at $4.00 less one-third discount. Even with this assistance, I can assure you that the book would be, so far as we are concerned, not in the category of the usual commercial publication but rather what we call a prestige book. By this we mean that we believe that the book is worth publishing, but that its character prevents it from finding a market wide enough to make it a paying proposition from our point of view.

I am hoping very much that the Department will interest themselves in this book, since I believe it will constitute a permanent record of the appearance and life stories of a number of very interesting Indian characters whose lives will otherwise not be known to posterity.

Yours sincerely,

C.J.E./h

C. J. Eustace

Memorandum:

Major MacKAY

Non-delivery of School Supplies.

As I have advised you personally, this matter is now one of the most serious problems facing our Education Division. Last year, as in former years, there were some delays in deliveries of school supplies. This year, the following two steps were taken in order to expedite the passing of requisitions from here to the Stationery Branch of the Department of Public Printing and Stationery:

1. In the November 1947 issue of the Indian School Bulletin, we sent out a standard school requisition form, a copy of which is attached. This was sent in duplicate and Principals of Residential Schools were asked to forward it to the Department by December 31, 1947. Day School Teachers were asked to forward it to the Department by May 31, 1948. These attached forms were designed to assist both our own clerks and those in the Stationery Branch by having all items listed in a standard order. In the past, a requisition form such as appendix (b) attached had been used.

2. The date upon which requisitions were to reach the Department was advanced from June 30, 1948, to May 31, 1948, as indicated above. In this way, it was felt we would provide an extra month for the Stationery Branch to fill requisitions and thus ensure their arrival at the schools concerned before school opening in September.
Just how badly these requisitions have been filled can best be indicated by the three samples which I have attached. In each instance, these requisitions were sent from here in three or four days after their arrival to the Stationery Branch on the special forms provided. It would then seem that long delays occurred before the orders were even typed on these special delivery record slips used. The chart hereunder shows the long delays which occurred in the filling of three requisitions.

I would emphasize that these three requisitions were selected by me at random from the top of the last batch of delivery records sent here from Stationery:

| Name of School | Date sent to Stationery Branch | Date typed on Delivery Record | Date parcel sent School |
|----------------|--------------------------------|-------------------------------|-------------------------|
| Bella Coola, B.C. | May 26                          | July 2.                      | September 14            |
| Old Sun, Alberta | May 20                          | July 2.                      | September 9             |
| Ahtahkakoops, Sask. | May 26                        | July 2.                      | September 10.           |

It can be seen from the above that these teachers did as requested. Not only were their requisitions forwarded to the Department before May 31, but the requests were sent to the Stationery Branch from here before that date.

As I have previously told you, we are now receiving a deluge of complaints from teachers, principals, superintendents and regional supervisors. We are forwarding a letter in each case to the Stationery Branch to indicate to them the serious discontent on the part of our teachers with the way in which these school supplies are being handled.

I have visited Mr. Driscoll, the Superintendent of Stationery, from whom I have always received the utmost in
co-operation. He informed me that these delays were mainly due to shortages of staff and to absences because of illness and holidays. He has promised that two or more extra men will be put immediately on to filling back requisitions.

I feel, however, that this will merely alleviate the present condition and will in no way remedy it.

I find that I am answering letters and handling problems which should never reach my attention if these supplies were being issued properly. For example, the requisition for the Fort McPherson Indian Day School was sent from here on June 8, 1948. We were quite confident that it would reach Waterways in July. Instead, it reached there in late August or early September. As a result, it was necessary for my staff and our field staff to take the following action:

1. The parcel was returned here from Waterways.
2. It was opened here and divided into two parts, namely Essential and Non-essential.
3. Two smaller parcels were made up and were shipped to Mr. Indian Superintendent Robertson at Edmonton.
4. He was asked to send the small parcel of essential supplies by Air Express to Fort McPherson.
5. He was asked to send the large parcel, next Spring, on the first boat.

I do not feel that my time or that of the field staff should be taken up in remedying such situations as are caused by the apparent inefficiency of another department. Therefore I feel strongly that this other department must improve the facilities for handling our supplies or must be prepared to have these supplies taken out of their charge and handled by this Branch. I have prepared a draft letter for the Deputy Minister's signature to the King's Printer, with specific recommendations for the improvement of the delivery of our school supplies.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir:

You will recall that on October 31, 1947, I wrote to you with regard to the delays which have occurred in the delivery of school supplies from the Stationery Branch to our Indian day and residential schools across Canada. In your reply dated January 27, 1948, you stated as follows:

"I may add that with the return to normal conditions it is hoped that the unavoidable delays complained of by your teachers in Indian schools will be completely eliminated."

Our Indian schools have now been open for nearly two months of the academic year. In most instances the teachers at these schools submitted their requisitions in the late spring and these were forwarded to the Stationery Branch in May or June. Every day's mail brings another series of letters of complaints from these teachers concerning the non-delivery of these supplies. I understand that our Superintendent of Education has discussed this matter with your Superintendent of Stationery and that efforts are being made to catch up on back requisitions as fast as possible. However, while this might alleviate the condition, it will not remedy it.

The children in our Indian schools are now reaching higher grades than previously. It no longer suffices to give them a reader, an arithmetic book and a few scribblers and pencils. In the senior grades they must be provided with
the history, geography and literature texts as prescribed in provincial courses of study. We must also equip our schools with supplementary reading and library books, as recommended by provincial departments of education.

I realize only too well that this means an increased number of books to be handled by your Stationery Branch. However, I would point out that as the years go by, we have every hope that more Indian children will reach higher grades and that even more books will be required than are at present being supplied.

Therefore, I would again ask you to consider the recommendation made in my letter of October 31, 1947. I feel that by authorizing the Indian Affairs Branch to purchase its own textbooks as indicated in this letter, it will do a great deal towards reducing the volume of work being required of your Stationery Branch.

It is quite possible that you might wish to present some other solution to this problem. If so, I would welcome an opportunity of discussing this matter with you and possibly some of your senior officials.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Minister.

Every day's mail brings another series of letters of complaints from these teachers concerning the non-delivery of these supplies. For example, our District Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia recently reported as follows:

"I have just returned from a long trip in the North, including visits to the Lejac and Cariboo Residential Schools. The matter of the supply of books is still a considerable headache and I cannot see why there should be the long delay which occurs in almost every school before the receipt of the supplies requisitioned."

I have been advised that our Superintendent of Education has recently discussed this matter at some length
with your Superintendent of Stationery, and that every effort is being made to fill all requisitions forwarded to the Stationery Branch.

Our Education Division has done its utmost to expedite the passing of requisitions to your Stationery Branch. The following two steps have been taken during the recent academic year in order that there would be no unnecessary delay from the time the requisitions left the teacher until the time they were typed and sent over to your Stationery Branch:

(1) A standard school requisition form, a copy of which is attached, has been prepared and sent out in duplicate to all our teachers. Residential school principals were asked to forward this requisition, as well as a requisition for other than standard supplies, to our department by November 30, 1947.

This year, the date upon which day school requisitions were to reach the department was advanced from June 30 to May 31, 1948. In this way, it was felt that we would provide an extra month for the Stationery Branch to fill requisitions and thus ensure their arrival at the schools concerned before the opening date in September.

In each instance, our records show that the requisition was sent from our Education Division within three or four days after its arrival here to the Stationery Branch on the special forms provided. | 28975               | Old Sun, Alberta     | May 20                        | July 2                       | September 9            |

After our representations of last year, there was an improvement in the shipping of these school supplies. In most instances, the residential school requisitions were shipped out in fairly good time; however, after the Stationery Branch re-opened following the stock-taking period, it became evident that the shipping of supplies was slowing up again, either due to the shortage of staff or to the holiday season. Because of this, our Superintendent of Education wrote to Mr. Driscoll on July 23, drawing his attention to the fact that delivery was falling behind the receipt of requisitions. A copy of this letter is attached, and you will note that we discontinued the sending over of supplementary reading book requisitions in order that the standard supplies could be shipped out in time for school opening.

As a result of the lack of supplies, the progress of our pupils is not being maintained at the rate which our school inspectors have a right to expect. This situation also has a serious effect on our teachers, who are doing everything possible to improve the standard of our schools. Particularly in the higher grades, it is most discouraging for them to start the school year without the texts which they ordered some four or five months previously.
