Dear Colonel Neary:

We have had a letter dated January 4 from the Department of Public Printing and Stationery in which they inquire if all or part of their orders 45828-29-30 may be returned for credit. These three orders cover 300 copies each of Teaching First Grade Reading I, Teaching First Grade Reading II, Teaching First Grade Reading III and the First Grade teachers' manuals for the Faith and Freedom series.

Our rule, as stated on our invoice form, is that books sent as ordered are not returnable, but we would not want to interpret this too strictly as against a good friend and customer such as you. The trouble, however, is that in this particular case, these books are of American manufacture and were imported especially for you. The schools are now pretty well supplied with these manuals and as a result, orders now are infrequent and small in number. While they can be returned across the border, there is a very considerable amount of red tape involved. We have an adequate stock here in Toronto to meet our estimated requirements for 1949. If we take back from your Department 200 copies, that would probably see us through 1950. We do not like to look further ahead than that because it may be that there will be a revision in the pupils' books, which would render the manuals out of date and unusable.

Would it be entirely satisfactory to you if we offer to take back 200 copies of each manual which would amount to one-quarter of the total order?

I do think it important that all your teachers using Faith and Freedom be supplied with the teachers' manuals and I wonder if it would be possible for you to distribute the other 600 copies of each manual to your schools, either immediately or eventually. On the other hand, we want to avoid embarrassing you in the slightest degree and if you say so, we shall take back the full amount, endeavouring to make the necessary arrangements to send all your stock of them back to the United States.

With all good wishes

Cordially yours,

[Signature]

MEMORANDUM:

DIRECTOR

Manuscript - Mrs. Mildred Valley Thornton

I have now had reports from our officials concerning this book and have read most of it myself. It is interesting and well written, but it deals mainly with the personalities of the Indians met by Mrs. Thornton in her travels as an artist among them. While these verbal descriptions of the Indians and their surroundings are informative and accurate, I doubt the value of the manuscript as a textbook or even as a reference book in our schools.

The vocabulary is such that I doubt if it would hold the interest of any but Indian boys and girls in the senior grades. Therefore, I feel that we could only recommend the purchase of about 250 copies for use as library books. This number, of course, would depend entirely on the price which Dent's set for the published text.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Indian Education.

Dear Mr. Neary:

This is in reply to your letter of 22nd February respecting the supply of HIGHROADS TO READING. One aspect of the situation about which you inquire is this: HIGHROADS TO READING, Book IV, will not be used in any of the Provinces during the coming school year except possibly in Quebec, and because of the very small quantity required in the Province of Quebec, we have asked the Department there if they would be willing to discontinue it. Book V and VI are both used this year in Saskatchewan and Manitoba, and Book VI, this year, in British Columbia, I believe, as well.

Next year we expect that Book V will be discontinued and we would no doubt declare it out of print; that is, Book V is unlikely to be available for the school year 1950-51. Whether the two Provinces of Manitoba and Saskatchewan will continue Book VI in that year, we do not know, but certainly by the following year, Book VI also will be out of use.

At the moment, therefore, we do not expect to have further copies of Book IV; we shall have copies of Book V available throughout the school years 1949-50; and we expect that Book VI will still be available for the school year 1950-51. On this latter point, we are not absolutely sure.

Might I ask whether you feel that it is more appropriate to use, as Readers, the texts authorized in a given Province? The reason that I ask this is that for Indian children, you might find it useful to continue in Grades IV, V and VI with the New Basic Readers. These books are used widely across the country, and are authorized in the Province of Quebec. If you have not seen these books, a note to me would get them to you quickly.

Dear Sir:

Re: Highroads to Reading Books 4, 5 and 6.

As you are aware, the Highroads to Reading readers are published by Thomas Nelson and Sons Limited and W.J. Gage & Co., Limited. As only a few of the Provinces have decided on an authorized reader for these grades, our position is not clear for we are anxious to use the readers authorized for the province in which the schools are located. To overcome this situation we would like to use the Highroads until such time as a definite decision is made by the different Departments of Education.

I wrote the two publishers asking whether the publication of these readers will be totally discontinued or whether there will be a limited publication for some time.

In reply, Thomas Nelson and Sons Company have stated that they are definitely discontinuing the printing of Highroads to Reading and are publishing a revised Highroads to Reading. I am not particularly interested in this reader at the present time unless it becomes authorized by the Provincial authorities.

W.J. Gage and Company reply that because of a desire on the part of the Department of Education in Quebec to maintain these books as authorized texts in that Province, they will continue to print for some time to come. In view of the above stand taken by W.J. Gage and Company, it is respectfully requested that all our requests for these books be booked with W.J. Gage and Company. It would not be wise to place a quantity of these Readers in stock; therefore, orders should be placed as requisitions come in.

Kindly let me have a reply to my letter of April 10th, reading as follows:

"Sometime ago, we ordered Poster Paper, Assorted Colours, 100 sheets 6 x 9, from G.M. Hendry Company. In place of poster paper the Company supplied folding paper. Upon asking for an explanation, I received the following letter:

"We have your letter of March 23rd, regarding the paper which we supplied on your orders, numbers 21502, 21308 and 20449, and wish to submit the following explanation.

This paper as originally received from the mill is known as Poster Paper. However, for the sake of clarity, so that all of our customers may know the purpose for which it is intended, we have adopted the trade name of "Economy Folding Paper" since the texture of the paper lends itself readily to work which involves considerable folding. In other words there is absolutely no difference between Poster Paper and Folding Paper, other than the name."
The only reason for maintaining our Poster Paper listing is that in past years our catalogue listing was confined to Poster Paper, and then we conceived the name Economy Folding Paper; we felt that to avoid confusion it would be best to indicate both names irrespective of the fact that the paper is identical.

We trust this explanation will serve to clarify the situation, but if further information is required, please feel free to get in touch with us at your convenience."

Kindly let me have your comments as soon as possible.

J. W. DRISCOLL

June 2, 1949.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary, Supt. of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

We thank you for your letter dated May 18,
and on checking our mailing list, we find that we do
have a plate addressed to the -

Superintendent of Indian Education,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

We do not show the names of individuals
on these address plates, just in case of change of
personnel. We hope that you have been getting our
circulars, as they have been issued from time to time,
but regret that it is now some time since we have
issued a complete catalogue, and we will not likely have
a new one ready until early in the new year. We will,
however, send one along as soon as ready.

Our reason for asking for a list of the
Post Office addresses of Indian Residential and Day Schools
was to send to the principals, circulars covering special
items which a school principal might be purchasing for
his own personal use, and would, perhaps, not be requisitioning
through the Department so that if it is possible to get a
list it would be appreciated. Perhaps it might show in
the annual report of the Department of Indian Affairs.

We do hope that you have in your files, a copy
of one of our large catalogues, or perhaps a copy of the
catalogue of the Western School Supply, which was a branch
of ours in Regina but which is now closed.

These catalogues were issued some time ago,
and of course, prices are entirely out of line but they
may be used for the selection of goods.

Assuring you of our very best attention to
your commands at all times.

Yours truly,

CHRISTIE SCHOOL SUPPLY LIMITED

Managing Director

THE PINES

LIMBER PINE

Pinus flexilis James

Rocky Mountain pine, Rocky Mountain white pine.

The limber pine, like the white-bark pine which it closely resembles, is a small alpine tree 25 to 40 feet in height and 1 to 2 feet in diameter. The trunk is short, thick, limby, and crooked, and the crown is irregular on account of the irregular whorls of thick limbs. On exposed slopes at high altitudes much of the limber pine growth is prostrate and shrubby. In old trees the lower branches are very long and tend to droop. The young branches are very tough and flexible, hence the name limber pine.

This tree is found in Canada in the mountains of southern British Columbia and Alberta, at an altitude of 5,000 to 6,000 feet. It is adapted to a great variety of soils, but is most often found on dry, rocky, and exposed slopes. It occurs in small pure stands or singly in mixture with mountain hemlock, whitebark pine, lodgepole pine, Douglas fir, and Engelmann spruce. In southern Alberta it is also found on the tops of the foothills.

LEAVES—Needle-like, in bundles of 5, stout, stiff, slightly curved, 1\(\frac{1}{2}\) to 3\(\frac{1}{2}\) inches long, dark green, mostly clustered on the ends of the twigs.

FLOWERS—Late June; unisexual; small reddish bodies, usually in clusters, male and female on the same tree.

FRUIT—September of the second year; a cylindrical cone, 3 to 8 inches long, short-stalked, with long, narrow, pointed, yellowish-brown scales, rounded, somewhat thickened at the tips; opening at maturity and falling during the winter. Seeds nearly wingless.

TWIGS—Stout, tough; at first hairy, orange-green; later, smooth, darker; buds ovoid, pointed.

BARK—On young stems, smooth grey or silvery-white; becoming rough, dark brown to almost black, deeply fissured into wide, scaly plates.

WOOD—Light, moderately soft, close-grained, non-porous; lemon-yellow with nearly white sapwood.

The limber pine, although occasionally used locally for fuelwood, has no commercial importance.
The SPRUCES *Picea* A. Dietr.

The spruces are widely distributed throughout the cooler parts of the northern hemisphere. About 40 species have been named, of which 7 are found in North America. Five of these and one variety are native to Canada. One native species, the red spruce, is found only in the East, and 2 others, the Sitka and the Engelmann spruces are confined to the West. The remaining 2 species, the white and the black spruce, range from the Atlantic Coast westward almost to the Pacific and northward to the limit of tree growth in the arctic regions. The range of the variety western white spruce is not fully known as yet, but it has been reported from Manitoba, Alberta, and British Columbia. Two foreign species widely planted in Canada for ornamental and other purposes are the Norway spruce, *Picea abies* (L.) Karst., from Europe, and the blue or Colorado spruce, *Picea pungens* Engelm., from the mountains of the Western United States.

The spruces are evergreen trees and have long, often cone-shaped crowns and straight, gradually tapering trunks. They have thin, scaly bark and slender, often drooping, lower branches. In the open the branches usually extend down the trunk nearly to the ground. Since the root systems are nearly always shallow, spruce trees are easily uprooted by wind.

The short, needle-like leaves are stiff and sharp-pointed, and, with one exception, are 4-sided in cross-section. They are single and stemless, and each is attached to a tiny peg-like base. They never appear to be 2-ranked, as is often the case with the firs and hemlocks, but either bristle out all around the twig or are curved and twisted toward the upper side.

Spruce flowers are unisexual—either male or female, never both—but the two sexes are found on the same tree. The mature cones always droop from the branches. They ripen in the autumn of the first season, open to discharge the seeds, and then either drop off before the new crop is formed, or in one case remain on the tree for many years. The seeds are very light and each has a broad wing attached to one end.

The Norway spruce is easily distinguished from the Canadian spruces by its yellowish-green foliage and larger cones. The blue spruce is distinguished chiefly by the colour of its leaves and the smooth, hairless twigs.

The wood of the different species is very similar in colouring and mechanical properties. Light-weight spruce timber resembles somewhat that of the white pines and it is often used for the same purposes. Its light colour, its freedom from resin, and the length and strength of the fibres make spruce the premier pulpwood of the world. It is also widely used in general construction, interior finish, and boxes and crating. Its tasteless character makes it of exceptional value for food containers.

Dear Mr. Eustace,

I have answered your letter of July 10th and note that Miss Gaulthier's book will run from 300 to 400 pages.

We were primarily interested in a book which could be used in our Indian schools for Social Studies. We wanted a text which would cost between $1.00 and $1.50 and which could be used in all schools across Canada.

Our former Director Mr. Hoey, was very interested in this material and I understand, advised Miss Gaulthier that we would handle about 5,000 copies. I also understand that the Boy Scouts Association is interested and you might write to them for their ideas as to the type of book which they require. I wonder whether it would be possible to publish in one volume form the material which has a "popular appeal" and to do the sections on medicine, ocean life, etc., in pamphlet form.

I hope that the above classifies our position in this matter. Thank you for your words of sympathy and I do appreciate this expression on your part.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Colonel Neary,

Miss Gaultier de la Verendrye was in the office last week and brought us her material which is now in some sort of shape. As a matter of fact, there seems to be a vast amount of material in the five or six booklets she brought in, and we have not yet been able to estimate how long this material would be if put into book form. I should think, however, that it would make a book of 300 or 400 pages, which would probably be both too unwieldy and expensive for the Department of Indian Affairs to interest itself in the publication as a book which should be placed in the schools for the use of the students.

This letter, therefore, is to explore the situation from your point of view. Miss Gaultier tells us that you are interested in seeing the book published, and that it might be possible for the Department to purchase five thousand copies. If this is so, I should very much welcome your tentative suggestion as to the size of the book that you would want, and whether or not all the material that Miss Gaultier has collected should be used.

The legends and myths are arranged at the moment in sections. One section contains legends and myths concerning Medicine, another consists of ocean life, another of animal life, and so forth. Do you think we should publish them in sections, or should we make a selection of the best material in all the sections and publish this material in one volume? I do hope you will forgive me asking these rather pointed questions, but from what you know of Miss Gaultier you will gather that she might be as explicit as we would wish about this matter.

Could you please advise if the Department would be interested in purchasing some copies of her book if we publish it? Also, could you please tell us if you want to place this material in your schools for the use of the Indian children themselves? Could you also confirm the possibility that the Department might be interested in the material
Col. B.F. Neary  
July 10, 1949.

to the extent of purchasing five thousand copies?

I should say, of course, that we are very interested in the material which is evidently authentic and seems to us to be very interesting. We think it is material that should be published, and we see a small market for it through other channels than the Department of Indian Affairs, although it is doubtful if these alone would justify publication.

I was terribly sorry to hear from Miss Gaulthier about the very sad loss you sustained recently in your family. Having children of my own, I can only send you my profound sympathy.

Yours sincerely,

To All Staffs
R.C.S.S. DISTRICT DIVISION VII

We are again reminded of the urgency of providing as much suitable reading material as possible for all classes, particularly Grades 1, 2, and 3; you are again commended on the considerable improvement in most of your schools during the past year, in reading material available, and therefore in reading proficiency.

May I repeat that you should aim to make it possible, as far as you can, for grades to have reading mastery (recognition, pronunciation and meaning) of the following numbers of words:

By the end of: Gr. 1 Gr. 2 Gr. 3 Gr. 4 Gr. 5 Gr. 6
600 additional 800 additional 900 additional 1400 additional 800 additional 1100 additional

A Grade I pupil needs to have a daily average of 3 words throughout the year; many come to school with a very limited stock. Since most of the Grade I groups provide about 200 words, at least three Grade I groups of titles are advisable; further, something relatively difficult—a toughening agent—such as "Happy Days" or "Mary, John and Peter", before the end of Grade I, is an important supplement to the "pre-digested baby food" provided by most of the easy and more attractive titles.

This constitutes a costly set of books for any, particularly a Grade I, pupil; if you can't have all you need from the Board, the library might provide part and the parent the balance.

One copy of each title in each of several of the following series is advisable for at least every 3 pupils in Grades 1 and 2; (at least enough for 1/3 of class):

Alice and Jerry - Copp Clark
Faith and Freedom - Ginn
Cathedral Basic (Dick and Jane) - Gage
Reading for Meaning - Nelson
Tags and Twinkie, etc. - MacMillan plus Playmates, with or without Let's Play, its pre-Primer - Ginn and Mary John and Peter.

Beyond Grade II it is suggested that all pupils of each grade have identical "class readers" in at least one title, and that there be, for Grade 3, one copy, for at least every three pupils, in as many as possible of such as Dick and Jane, Faith and Freedom, Corona Readers—Ginn (Playmates, etc.). The Public School Reader, which have not been chosen as the "class reader".

Beyond Grade III, each pupil should have a copy of his "class reader"—Cathedral Basic, Corona, Public School Reader, and the following might be provided, at least one copy per grade—supplementary reading—in all the following which have not been selected as the class reader:

Canadian Parade Readers - Dent (Gr. 4, 5, 6)
New World Readers - MacMillan (Gr. 4, 5, 6)
Cathedral Basic - (Gr. 1 - 8)
Corona - (Gr. 1 - 8)
Public School - (Gr. 1 - 8)
Canadian Reading Development Series - Clark (Gr. 4, 5, 6)

Grades 7 and 8 will read those 4's and 5's and 6's, with interest and benefit.
Have something Catholic and something Canadian in each grade.

With limited resources, provision of suitable and sufficient reading material may be a five-or-six-year program.

The above may be of some guidance through the maze of good material available; above are only some of the titles which are good.

It is believed that where there isn't money enough for both, it should be spent on books, rather than on work books.

Our Land and Our Living - Reid and Hamilton - Don't - is excellent 6-8 Geography, for teacher or good pupil use. At least one copy, for teacher guidance, of each of the three titles in Getting Ready to Write etc., Gage, at 20¢ per title, would be of great help to each primary teacher.

Please order for September, as far as money will permit, particularly if you are not returning.

Wm. H. Bulger
Inspector of Separate Schools.

Replying to your letter of the 8th, the tremendous demand for school furniture of all kinds at this particular season of the year has exhausted stocks to an extent that we have only a few items available for immediate shipment. Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY

Mr. M.J. McLean, President, McLean's Merchandize Sales Limited was in town on September 28th soliciting business for books and reading materials he is handling.

Among other things, he interested me in a set of Richard's Topical Encyclopedia. These books were originally planned as a 20 volume set for use in schools retailing at $150 a set. Through some miscalculation they overprinted eight volumes each dealing with a different topic as shown on the attached circular. Each volume carries an index for the volume and there is no reference from one volume to another, making each book complete in itself.

The binding, quality of paper, illustrations, vocabulary material etc., are exactly the same as in the Book of Knowledge. Mr. McLean tells me that the Department of Education for Saskatchewan and Quebec have purchased these sets. The price of $15. for each set of eight volumes is very reasonable.

In view of the fact that many of our residential schools have a set of the Book of Knowledge and the Grolier Encyclopedia, I would respectfully recommend that Mr. Driscoll be requested to place in stock ten sets of these Encyclopedias.

Colonel Bernard Neary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Colonel Neary,

It was very nice of you to give me so much of your time in Ottawa, and I am sorry that I did not telephone you about the result of my deliberations with Miss Gaulthier. Actually I have her manuscript and I am a little puzzled as to what we are to do with it, although she has given us carte blanche to edit it as we please.

After thinking over the matter of this manuscript in relation to your own requirements I have come to a few conclusions which I am passing on to you for what they are worth.

It seems to me that there are two books that you require for your schools according to your needs as you outlined them to me during our conversation. The first book is a reader of about Grades VI and VII level telling something of the traditions and social customs of the Indians with a chapter on their contribution to our present civilization. The object of this book is to make the Indian youngsters proud of their own people and also to tell them something of the traditions of their people.

The second book is to show the part that Indians played in Canadian history, this to be done through a series of historical biographies or incidents.

Our Western Director is to be here next week and I am writing to him asking him to be sure to bring with him details of a book our Firm decided to do about a year ago on Indians. When we have this before us, we can find out exactly how we can help you in planning a book to meet your needs.

When in Montreal I spoke to Mr. E.C. Woodley, who is now retired from the Department of Education in Quebec, about the little book on Indian achievements, as I believe that Mr. Woodley would have both the time and ability to collect some material for us on this subject. I will, therefore, be writing to you about this at a later date. It occurs to me that we might get into the same book something about Indian customs and traditions, although possibly two books may be necessary.
Colonel Bernard Neary

October 11, 1949.

How much material we shall be able to use from Miss Gaulthier's book, I do not know, but there does seem to be an opportunity to publish a third book for general consumption on the subject of the customs, legends and habits of the Gatineau Indians. Evidently the Federal Commission intends to publicize the Gatineau Park as a sort of national centre outside Ottawa, and it is expected that a good many thousands of people annually will visit the park. What we may do here, therefore, is to select from Miss Gaulthier's material sufficient matter to produce a reasonably sized book on the Indians and their customs and legends.

I saw General Spry about these matters and he expressed an interest in all three projects.

Once again I am grateful to you for your interest in this matter; I will keep you in touch with developments and will probably be writing to you again in the near future.

As you requested, I am sending you a copy of MASTERING THE READING SKILLS and ANSWER BOOK with our compliments.

Kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

C.J.E./DP

Dear Colonel Neary:

It would be appreciated if you would have Mr. Track send me a copy of requisitions covering supplies which have been shipped to Indian schools in the Northwest Territories. The Lands and Development Services Branch have been following this policy. It is a good procedure in that I know what has been shipped to schools and am thus in a position to scrutinize requisitions and make recommendations knowing what is on hand.

I would also like to suggest that, in future, non-denominational readers be supplied to our schools and that we use books as authorized by the Alberta Curriculum. Otherwise, we shall have a hodge-podge of books in our schools -- with each individual school using practically anything they wish. In this connection, Indian Agent Kirkby informed me upon his return from Roche River that the parents of the children in that area were quite annoyed that the Faith and Freedom Readers have been introduced into the school. In all our schools in the Northwest Territories, we have children of every denomination. Therefore, it seems to me that it is most unfair to request all these pupils to follow books expostulating the faith of any particular denomination. The only fair and satisfactory solution is to provide books as authorized by the curriculum for non-denominational schools as Protestant and Roman Catholic parents alike do not wish readers of a denominational nature introduced into our schools.

Yours very truly,

J.W. McKinnon,
Superintendent of Education,
Mackenzie District, N.W.T.
November 4, 1949.

Dear Mr. McKinnon:

I have your letter of October 17th in reference to copies of requisitions covering supplies which have been shipped to Indian schools in the Northwest Territories.

We feel that it is not possible and not feasible to send you copies of requisitions as many of the requisitions are not filled for a considerable length of time after the requisition is placed. In fact, we have a large quantity of supplies in the office now to be shipped to the North early next Spring.

As you are aware, when the supplies are forwarded by the Department of Public Printing and Stationery a delivery slip is sent to the teacher with the parcel. The teacher is required to sign the receipt and return it to Ottawa. It would appear that if you wish to be informed on what supplies have been shipped to the school, you might ask the teacher to sign the receipts and forward them to you. After you have noted them you should forward them to the Department of Public Printing and Stationery.

The contents of your letter regarding the readers and other text books for the schools in the Northwest Territories have been noted. There will be an article with reference to this in the next issue of the Indian School Bulletin.

Raoul de Navery

Nous devons au talent fécond de Raoul de Navery, un grand nombre de romans d’une belle tenue littéraire et morale. La Librairie Granger a heureusement choisi un choix des douze meilleurs livres de cet auteur si estimé. Ce sont des romans puissamment agencés, très dramatiques, mais toujours irréprochables. Dear Colonel Neary:

I note in your letter of November 4th, (your file 1-1-4(EB)) that you are unable to supply this office with copies of requisitions covering supplies which have been forwarded to schools in the Mackenzie District of the Northwest Territories for the current school year. I regret that you are unable to supply our office with this information as we are most anxious to keep a complete inventory of all equipment and supplies provided to schools in the Mackenzie District.

You will recall that when Miss Davis was in charge of requisitions, you were good enough to provide us with this information. I also find that the Lands and Development Services Branch have found it quite possible to provide this office with copies of requisitions covering all supplies forwarded to schools in the Mackenzie District for the present school year.

There are various difficulties in getting this information from the blue delivery slips as suggested in your letter. This method is unfeasible and practically impossible at this time of the year as most of the blue delivery slips will have been returned to Ottawa by now. Even if this were possible, we have not sufficient help to do this work.

You may have misunderstood my request as all that we require is that the officer in charge of requisitions in your Branch run off an additional copy for our files when he is preparing the requisitions. Then, in turn, this list would be checked by this office against the blue delivery slips and a notation made of all supplies provided.

We shall not have any difficulty in this regard another year as all requisitions will be submitted through this office to Ottawa. This will enable us to keep a complete record of all equipment and supplies ordered for the coming school year and, by checking these lists against the blue...
delivery slips, we shall keep our records up to date. However, it would be appreciated if you would, in future, have additional copies of such information forwarded to this office as our files should be completely up-to-date in every way.

Yours very truly,

J.W. McKinnon,
Superintendent of Education,
Mackenzie District, N.W.T.

It is in my home, is in various departments and branches of the library, in school libraries and wherever young people and children need it, we have it.

I happen to know considerable about the internal organization of the Compton Company. I am familiar with their methods as well as their officials and staff and can say they do a most meticulous and careful job of whatever they undertake. They use only the best authorities for compiling their articles which are geared to the school curriculum wherever possible. Their material is accurate, up-to-date and presented in a pleasing and attractive manner.

It is the illustrations which are a special feature of their encyclopedia and on which I wish to comment particularly. They spend an enormous amount of time and money on their art work, all of which is designed to be educational as well as informational and recreational. The pictures are simple but illustrate the text clearly and as completely as possible. Their maps and diagrams are clear and easily understood by the youngest child. I can safely say, there is no more attractive set on the market today than Compton's at any price.

Their method of keeping the set up-to-date is costly but effective. They are constantly revising it and re-writing those parts which need changing or the addition of new material. You can present this encyclopedia to any home, school or library without fear that it will not do the work required of it. I can only congratulate you on your connection with Compton's and wish you every success in introducing it in Canada where we lack such first-rate encyclopedias for children.

Dear Colonel Neary,

Subsequent to my recent letter to you in which I sent you a first tentative outline for a projected reader for the Indian schools. Since writing to you, we have heard from our Western Director who has made some good suggestions for amplification of Mr. Woodley's outline, and I shall hope to send you a revised outline very shortly for your approval or suggestion.

Mr. Woodley tells me that there will be no difficulty in checking the language, as he is acquainted with your Inspector of Schools at Caughnawaga and will use his Sixth Grade for testing the selections.

My own feeling is that Mr. Woodley is on the right track with his outline. I hope you will let me know whether you think it interesting, and whether the venture is practical before we proceed further with it.

We have been over a part of Miss Gaulthier's manuscript, and we are of the opinion that the material is in such a state that the editorial task is too great for us to undertake in this office. We are informing Miss Gaulthier that unless she can submit to us a manuscript that is in some kind of order, we cannot undertake publication of it. We realize that there is some immensely valuable material in the manuscript, but Miss Gaulthier really needs the services of an editorial assistant who can reorganize and partly rewrite her manuscript for publication. We wish we had the time in this office to do this, but unfortunately we have not.

We shall look forward to hearing from you about the other matter.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Woodley:

I have just answered your letter of the 25th of November and I will contact you on my next trip to the Caughnawaga School.

In the meantime I am arranging to have you mailed a copy of Dr. Jameson's book on the Indians of Canada. It is a copy from our own library and I know you will take care of it while doing the necessary research.

It is probably the most authoritative book and should give you very valuable background concerning the various tribes, their characteristics and environment.

I am also sending you a copy of the Story Workbook in Canadian History, which has proven to be very satisfactory in our Indian schools. This type of book appeals greatly to our pupils and to our teachers because of the following reasons:

(a) The work is divided into connected units.
(b) Each unit is followed by seatwork problems.
(c) The content is simple and yet interesting.
(d) The black and white illustrations help to make the book more appealing to our Indian children.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Colonel Neary,

Mr. C.J. Eustace of J.M. Dent and Sons has suggested that I should write you regarding a prospective Reader for Indian children, in which his firm is interested. He mentioned the book to me last month when visiting Montreal and asked me if I would consider its preparation.

I understand that Mr. Eustace has communicated with you about the Reader and that, naturally, you are greatly interested in anything related to Indian education.

Some time ago I made a tentative outline in accordance with the objectives described to me by Mr. Eustace. I think that he has sent you a copy of this outline. The outline was only intended to be an initial step and will probably be changed to some extent before the actual writing begins. One of the major problems will be the accommodation of the language to the understanding of Grade VI pupils.

Would it be possible for us to meet during one of your visits to Montreal? I should like to discuss a number of aspects of this proposed book before I go much further. If you will let me know when you will be in Montreal I shall gladly arrange for our meeting.

In his letter to me, Mr. Eustace mentions your inquiry regarding my knowledge of Mr. Jenness' work on the Indians of Canada. I know the book well. I have a copy of the Bulletin of Dr. Jenness on the "Indian Background of Canadian History" but do not possess a copy of the larger work which I have been able to consult only at libraries. Can the larger book still be procured? I thought that it was out of print. If the book is still available, through your Department, I shall be glad to purchase a copy, as it will facilitate my work.

Very sincerely yours,

E.C. Woodley

The majority of children lack factual experience with the geographical terms which confront them when they commence the study of geography. By illustrating and naming the various geographical terms in common usage, J100—Map of Standard Geographical Terms aids considerably in the acquisition of proper visual conceptions of the geographical formations of the earth.

Section J100—COMPOSITE LANDSCAPE

Portrayed above is a halftone reproduction of Section J100 of the map, depicting a composite landscape. This illustration is in three colors only; the actual map is lithographed in full natural colors. Directly beneath the landscape scene, but not shown here, is a complete dictionary of definitions.

Illustrated overleaf is Section J100b of the map, showing various types of natural phenomena. There are 20 black and white photographs, averaging 6x8 inches each.
A BASIC MAP

The Standard Map of Geographical Terms has been produced by the Denoyer-Geppert Company to aid the school children in gaining a clear understanding of the various physical features of the earth represented by the common geographical terms. By acquainting the children with the different types of land forms, this basic map or chart lays the foundation for correctly interpreting the regular maps to which they are eventually introduced, and on which all physical or natural features are necessarily portrayed by means of symbols.

IN TWO SECTIONS

The two sections of this map supplement each other, and each is 44x36 inches in size. The first section (J100) consists of an artificial landscape, lithographed in full natural colors. It is done on a composite plan that illustrates all manner of land forms, with the names thereof printed on. Immediately below the landscape appear definitions of the geographic terms illustrated in the landscape.

The second section (J100b) consists of 20 black and white photographs, depicting various natural features of the earth. Several of them also illustrate how men have adapted themselves to different natural surroundings. At the top of the sheet appears an explanation of the type of phenomenon illustrated by each picture.

Both sections, J100 and J100b are hand-mounted on a heavy quality of closely woven muslin. Mounted together as a single unit, or separately as individual maps.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I am pleased to tell you that our work on the manuscript of the fourth grade Faith and Freedom reader, *This is Our Land*, is well along and practically the only writing which remains to be done is for some of the exercises. We cannot finally determine the length of the exercises until the main part of the book is actually in type. We have therefore commenced to set the type.

I am sending you a copy of the manuscript and would be grateful if you would read it and let us have any observations that you care to make. I should point out that we are sending you a copy which has not been carefully read against the original. It is quite possible, therefore, that there are errors of spelling, a word omitted, or something of that nature. You may be quite sure that this will not be carried into the finished book.

The manuscript has involved almost complete re-writing. We have had numberless conferences with the authors and various school people about the material, and we are just about as sure as we can be that it is what is wanted. You will be pleased to note that all the features of the American book have been retained and that the plan and purpose of the Canadian book is in full accord with the aims of the whole Faith and Freedom programme.

Following the plan of the American book, we take the children on a sweep right across Canada which, of course, is in accordance with the title, *This is Our Land*. I think you will enjoy reading the selections. The writing is all excellent, - in some cases, I think, brilliant. The more I have worked with this manuscript, the happier I have felt about it.

The manuscript is being read also by a priest in Montreal, to make sure that we have nothing unfortunate from the French-Canadian angle. I believe we have guarded quite well against anything which might cause trouble in the Indian schools, but I should like you to read the manuscript particularly from this point of view. The authors have been very careful to omit any references to the Indians being cruel, bloodthirsty, wild savages, or anything
To Colonel B. F. Neary

That nature which occurs so frequently in the usual story about Indians for white children. We felt it quite important to have several stories about Indians such as, for example, the story of Father Brebeuf. Similar stories in the Corona Readers have, as far as I know, been quite acceptable and I hope these will prove to be the same.

Apart from the necessity of having the material in type to determine the space available for the exercises, it is even more important to determine exactly the space for illustrations and get the artists started on their work. The book will have the same type of illustrations as in the original edition.

We hope to publish This is Our Land next spring. If, therefore, you could read and return the manuscript and let us have your observations at the earliest possible moment, I shall be very grateful indeed.

My wife and I enjoyed seeing you in Fredericton. I hope, if you are in Toronto, you will give me a ring and come out to the house to have a meal, if you can spare the time.

Dear Colonel Neary,

I have pleasure in enclosing herewith a first outline, necessarily tentative, of a reader designed to be written at Grade VI level and following along the lines that we discussed when I was in Ottawa. The author of this is Mr. E.C. Woodley, M.A., F.R.Hist.S., who is retired now from the Department of Education in Quebec where he occupied the position of Education Officer to the Director of Protestant Education. Mr. Woodley is well known as a competent Canadian historian and he has written a number of text books for the schools. He will guarantee to present these little stories in language suitable for Grade VI, and if you are interested at all in this book, perhaps it would be possible to arrange for someone in your Department to check the material from the point of view of comprehension by Indians, as it is written.

In the meanwhile, would you be kind enough to look over this outline and make any suggestions either for additions or omissions.

It occurs to me that the last section "The Indians To-day" could probably be enlarged as there must be other contributions that Indians have made to our present life in Canada which Mr. Woodley has not mentioned.

I should also like to have your comments on the sections he suggests such as (a) the games they played (b) the things they made, etc.

You will not want a book that is too long, and it occurs to me that perhaps two books might be necessary if you want a good deal of material devoted to the games they played, etc. However, it would be best to have everything in one reader.

You may also be interested to know that our Firm has completed a manuscript on the "Life of the Eskimos" at Grade III level and we are at work on one on the Indians. The book on the Eskimos will be published during 1950 and the manuscript of the Indian book will probably be finished some time next year also.

Please be assured that we appreciate very much your interest and cooperation in this venture, and for our part we shall do our best to produce an interesting and attractive looking book. However, since this book will

Dear Sir:

Re Your File 1-1-5-(E)

Replying to your letter of December 15th regarding the use of Cinoplate blackboards, there has been very little blackboard material of any kind sold to schools since the depression and we do not know of any installation in the neighbourhood of Ottawa. Canadian Commercial Corporation have bought this material on a number of occasions and some few months ago for the Department of National Defence, Royal Canadian Engineers, Camp Borden, Ontario. One of our Toronto architects who builds a number of schools, Mr. C. P. Band, specifies Cinoplate blackboards along with slate. Natural slate, however, is the blackboard material used in 90% of Ontario schools.

We have been supplying this material for fifteen or twenty years and have had no complaints of its character or quality, consequently, have no hesitation in recommending it to you.

We will be glad to know if there is anything further we can do for you in this connection.

Yours very truly,

Dear Colonel Neary,

I have a reply from Mr. Woodley to my recent letter to him. He encloses a new tentative outline of the book on the Indians, which I attach hereto. You will note that he has followed your suggestions and eliminated the section "Tales told by the Camp Fire and in the Tepee".

I like the outline now better than I did the first one, as it seems to me to deal rather definitely now with the history of the Indians and to do it in a factual manner. Perhaps, however, the title "The Indian Heritage" is not a very good one if the legends and myths are to be left out, since these are part of the heritage of the Indian, although you will know better than I what influence, if any, these myths and legends would have on modern Indians.

I hope it will be possible for you to contact Mr. Woodley when next you are in Montreal. He is anxious to proceed with the writing of this book, but feels that he should not do so until the outline is approved. Is there any possibility that we can get the outline approved, - at least unofficially - in the near future?

Yours sincerely,

C.J.E./DP

Dear Father O'Grady:

Please find enclosed two copies of my booklet, "What a Canadian Should Know", an illustrated primer in Citizenship.

Some time ago I sent a copy of it to the Indian Affairs Branch in Ottawa. In reply Mr. Neary, the Superintendent of Indian Education suggested that we try this booklet in your school.

The booklet enclosed are the original notes as prepared for my Citizenship Classes for New Canadians. I might add here that my eight year's work with the Indians helped for I have not forgotten their needs.

Shortly before Christmas I completed a revision of this booklet. The number of questions and answers have been reduced to a hundred, and I have added Word Study and Work Book sections. The word count is well within the bounds set by Basic English Authorities and every illustration has a definite teaching value as a teaching device. All material used has been carefully tested in classroom (both High School and Night school) for interest, language, and general suitability.

Since I have not the time to cut the stencils for the revised booklet I wondered whether you would undertake to publish this booklet as a classroom project, that is, if you have a duplicating or mimeographing machine. If you are interested, I can send you my handwritten copy.

While it is true that the trend has been away from factual presentation of historical facts towards the storybook type of history, many teachers and business men feel that it has resulted in no learning! To prove this loss I conducted three separate experiments with control groups among our Grade 9 classes. The results indicated without doubt the need for mastery of at least some minimum essentials.

During the past three years I have examined a great number of books dealing with the same material and I invariably found that they were written at a reading level above that required of most public school students.
Now that the Indians of British Columbia have the right to vote, I feel that the booklet should be made available to all Indian Students as well as to adults of voting age.

I have received very favorable comments from various educators, including the Extension Department of the University of British Columbia. Mr. John Fisher heard about our work here and showed considerable interest. He gathered much information which he will use in a future broadcast. It might be added that the booklet is also under consideration for use in some of the provincial school systems.

With best wishes for a Happy New Year.

Sincerely yours,

J. M. Barr.

Dear Mr. Eustace:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of January 9 and Mr. Woodley's outline, attached.

We are now approaching the type of thing which we have in mind but I think that more stress will have to be laid on the Western Indians. I am having mailed to Mr. Woodley two or three books which might help him in giving more details concerning these Indians. There will certainly have to be more mention of the Prairie Indians and of the B. C. Indians. I am sure that Mr. Woodley will get some ideas from the books I am sending to him. There should be more detail also concerning the social life of the various tribes of Indians.

I believe that Mr. Woodley could start to write his book now and that he could deal with the outline already given. He could then fill in to his outline sections on the Western Indian as I have mentioned. Exercises in seatwork should certainly follow each section as we are anxious to make this as practical a book for use in our schools as possible.

I have had to postpone my trip to Montreal on several occasions but believe I should be down there during February.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

CANADA

Canada! O Canada!
A land so great, so grand,
A land of wealth and beauty,
Free gift from God to man.

Canada, your borders are the oceans;
Your length the Polar Sea;
Your rocks are full of silver;
Your forest tall pine trees.

Your soil is rich and fertile;
Your streams they teem with fish;
Your fields of wheat and barley
Are all that heart could wish.

Canada's vast prairies
Afford abundant grass
For the countless herds of cattle,
Like the buffalos of the past.

Your lofty snow-capped mountains
Are huge majestic mounds,
Where the giant furs and cedars
Are in abundance found.

Oh! Canada, you have now become a nation;
Your population's small;
Your land is well divided,
Ten provinces in all.

Canada, loyal Canada,
Your ruler is a King;
Your emblem the Maple Leaf;
Oh! how your banners stream.

Blessed law-abiding people,
You have a fair and just;
Your homes have been protected
With God's almighty hand.

Ottawa is Canada's grand capital,
Where all her M.P.'s meet
To transact the country's business,
With the Prime Minister in his seat.

Canada! Proud Canada!
You ha'e a bonnie Queen;
She's a native of Old Scotland,
Whence Bruce and Wallace came.

Canada's Governor General,
Who represents the King,
Is a native of Old Ireland,
That little Isle of green.

Canada, you have a friendly neighbor;
They call him Uncle Sam;
He's very free with money
To lend a helping hand.
And when you call to him,
He'll always use you grand.

Canada's old historic records
Are engraved upon her coins;
They date from Indian Wampum,
And to us they're handed down.

Canada! O Canada!
You're just the land for me;
You flow with milk and honey
And grow the sugar maple tree.

If you ever wish to travel
Over land or sea or air,
You will find first-class accommodation
In Canada everywhere.

Canada's armed defence forces
On land and sea and air
Have proved themselves victorious
By the medals they now wear.

—W. H. Kernohan.

Forest, Ontario.

Re: Cataloguing Equipment and Supplies

At a recent meeting of the teachers and agent of the Tyendinaga Reserve, the above subject was discussed. We feel that it is desirable that all equipment and supplies on hand in the schools should be catalogued, and that the equipment at least should be checked at regular intervals. This would protect the teacher, enable us to transfer equipment from one school to another without the teacher carrying any of the responsibilities, enable us to list requirements with the minimum of work, and finally in the event of a change of teachers, both the new and the old teacher would be protected.

The Ontario Department of Education has a standard type of catalogue, but this does not meet with my approval because we want a type of catalogue that could be used for checking purposes over a number of years. With the Ontario Catalogue it is necessary to erase the check marks each year or as is usually done, write out a list of the equipment each year and check from this written list. If your Department has no standard catalogue in supply, I would be in favor of using No.200 Government of Canada Register, with a supply of Index Tabs. We would require at least 5 of these books to start with.

We also discussed the cataloguing of Library Books. Some of our schools are building up a nice library and consequently it is proving quite a chore to find any particular book. We are therefore interested in systems of cataloguing libraries. If the Department has no standard system in their schools we would like to catalogue the books according to the subjects on our curriculum. This system has many disadvantages, but I feel its simplicity outweighs them all. We would require for our book shelves some type of metal card holder. I would suggest that 3 dozen of these would be sufficient at the present time.

DRC.R

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Plastic Drinking Cups

We always have a demand for drinking cups for our day schools and have been providing various types over the past few years. Recently we have been providing plastic tumblers and they have proved to be very satisfactory, providing they are heavy enough.

Unfortunately the heavy plastic cups are quite expensive and often cost forty or fifty cents each. We have secured an excellent price from Maple Leaf Plastics Limited of Toronto quoting $2.50 per dozen on a heavy plastic cup. We have received samples of these cups and they are just what we want.

I have, therefore, prepared requisitions for the stocks which we will need for the next year in our Indian day schools.

I am grateful to you for your letter of February 23rd advising us that we may dispose of the type of the Joe and Ruth Workbook. We have 2900 copies left, and we shall be glad to let you have these at a special price of 24 cents a copy.

I shall be seeing Mr. Woodley in Montreal in a couple of weeks time on my way back from a trip to the Maritimes. I will see what progress he is making on the book on the Indians. I appreciate very much your sending Mr. Woodley the Indian books, as I know these will be useful to him. I will also suggest to Mr. Woodley that he get in touch with our Mr. Stephen of Vancouver about books on the B.C. Indians.

I am hoping to be in Ottawa in the early Spring, and shall look forward to seeing you at that time.
